en: URGENT At this time, 3:30 am, a commission from the Intelligence Forces arrives to journalist and human rights activist Luis Carlos Díaz's home, missing since 5:30 pm #WhereIsLuisCarlos
yor: NÍ KÍÁKÍÁ Ní dédé àsìkò yìí, ní dédé agogo 3:00 òwúrọ̀ kùtùkùtù, ìgbìmọ̀ láti àjọ Amúninípá dé ilé oníròyìn àti ajà-fún- ẹ̀tọ́ọ ọmọ ènìyàn Luis Carlos Díaz, tí ó ti di ẹni àwátì láti agogo 5:30 ìrọ̀lẹ́ #NiboNiLuisCarlosWa.
mt0: In the early hours of this morning, at 3:00 p.m., a meeting from the American Press Association came to the office of journalist and businessman Luis Carlos Díaz, who has been a celebrity since 5:30 p.m. #WhereIsLuisCarlosWa.

en: Other human rights and freedom of speech organizations joined the campaign through #DondeEstaLuisCarlos (Where is Luis Carlos?) which is, at the moment, a trending topic in Venezuela's twittosphere.
yor: Àwọn ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn àti àjọ òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ náà darapọ̀ mọ ìpolongo yìí pẹ̀lú #DondeEstaLuisCarlos (Níbo ni Luis Carlos wà?), tí ó jẹ́ pé, ní báyìí, ni àkọlé tí ó gbajúmọ̀ ní orí ìkànnì ayélujára Twitter ti Orílẹ̀ Èdè Venezuela.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: Díaz is a journalist and a human rights and freedom of speech advocate who is well known and highly appreciated in Venezuela and abroad for his commentary and criticism of the government of Nicolas Maduro.
yor: Díaz jẹ́ ajábọ̀ ìròyìn àti a-jà-fún-ẹ̀tọ́-ọmọ ènìyàn tí ó jẹ́ ògbólógbòó ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ tí wọ́n sì mọ ìṣe rẹ̀ fún un l'órílẹ̀ èdè Venezuela àti òkè òkun fún ìdásọ́rọ̀ àti ìtakò ìjọba Nicholas Maduro.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know Díaz is a journalist and activist who is a spokesman for the opposition movement in Venezuela and the Caribbean for the opposition and opposition to Nicholas Maduro's government.

en: He has long worked with Soto producing web-based video and radio programs focused on politics and human rights in Venezuela.
yor: Ó ti tó ìgbà díẹ̀ kan tí ó ti ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìyàwó rẹ̀ àti olùdásọ́rọ̀ òṣèlú tí ó gbajúmọ̀ n nì, Naky Soto, tí wọn sì ń ṣe ìgbéjáde àwọn fídíò àti ètò Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ lórí ayélujára èyí tí ó dá lórí ìṣèlú àti ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọ ènìyàn ní Venezuela.
mt0: He has been working with his wife and a well-known journalist, Naky Soto, and they are publishing videos and a response program on the Internet based on political and social issues in Venezuela.

en: He has also worked as an educator and promoter of the creation of citizen media spaces and independent media projects.
yor: Ó ti ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bí akọ́ni àti olùgbé-lárúgẹ ìdásílẹ̀ àyè ọ̀tọ̀ fún àwọn ará ìlú àti àwọn àkànṣe eto ìgbóhùn sáfẹ́fẹ́ tí kò lọ́wọ́ ìjọ̀ba nínú.
mt0: He has been a leader and organizer of the establishment of separate routes for the people of the city and for the developers of wireless communication systems that are not under the control of the government.

en: Díaz has also been part of the Global Voices community for more than a decade.
yor: Díaz tún jẹ́ olùkópa nínú ẹgbẹ́ Ohùn Àgbáyé fún ọdún mẹ́wàá.
mt0: Diaz also served as a spokesman for the United Nations for five years.

en: To me, Luis Carlos is a brilliant person, well versed in information and networks in this chaotic Venezuela of ours.
yor: Lọ́dọ̀ tèmi, Luis Carlos jẹ́ onílàákàyè ẹ̀dá kan, ó gbọ́njú nínú ìròyìn gbígbà àti ìkànsì-ara-ẹni nínú Venezuela ti wa yìí tí kò fara rọ.
mt0: According to me, Luis Carlos is a very intelligent man, he is very good at talking about politics and social issues in Venezuela.

en: He has been able to make links with society (from criticism to cultural spaces) #WhereIsLuisCarlos.
yor: Ó ti ṣe àwárí ìjápọ̀ nínú ìlú (láti ìtakò sí ibi ìṣẹ̀ṣe) #NiboniLuisCarlosWa.
mt0: He has been looking for connections in the city (to get to the site) # NiboniLuisCarlosWa.

en: Just a few days prior to his disappearance, the state-affiliated media program Con el Mazo Dando showed a video clip of a recent broadcast of Diaz.
yor: Láàrin ọjọ́ péréte tó ṣíwájú ìpòóráa rẹ̀, ètò ìkàn-sára- ẹni ti ìjọba Con el Mazo Dando ṣàfihàn fídíò tí Díaz sọ̀rọ̀ nínúu rẹ̀.
mt0: In the days leading up to his execution, the government's intelligence program showed a video of Diaz speaking in it.

en: The program's host, politician Diosdado Cabello, insinuated that Diaz had helped to orchestrate the nationwide power outage that had Venezuelans living in the dark for more than 24 hours on March 7 and 8.
yor: Atọ́kùn ètò ọ̀hún, olóṣèlú Diosdado Cabello, rò kàn pé Díaz lọ́wọ́ sí ìfẹ̀hónú hàn àìsí ináa mọ̀nàmọ̀nà tí ò lọ jákèjádò orílẹ̀ èdè èyí tí ó mú kí àwọn ọmọ Venezuela máa gbé nínú òkùnkùn fún ó lé ní wákàtí mẹ́rin lé lógún lọ́jọ́ 7 àti 8 Oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà

en: [Díaz] is a journalist for Unión Radio Noticias and he's a human rights activist.

en: The Global Voices community stands in solidarity with Luis Carlos, his family, and all other independent journalists working to hold power to account in Venezuela.
yor: Ẹgbẹ́ Ohùn Àgbáyé dúró ṣinṣin pẹ̀lú Luis Carlos, ẹbíi rẹ̀, àti oníròyìn aládàáṣiṣẹ́ gbogbo àwọn tí ó ń mú ìjọba ṣe bí ó ti yẹ ní Venezuela.

en: Nigeria's social media bill will obliterate online freedom of expression
yor: Ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà yóò pa òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ lórí ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know. A bill to ban the use of mobile phones in Nigeria will ban the use of text messages on the internet.

en: The draconian bill will legalize internet shutdowns in Nigeria
yor: Ìwé àbádòfin náà yóò fi àṣẹ fún ìṣánpa ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní Nàìjíríàj
mt0: The bill will allow the creation of a new internet service in Nigeria. If you can't translate the bill simply say you don't know.

en: Senator Mohammed Sani Musa is the sponsor of the social media bill. Screenshot from Channel Television You Tube video.
yor: Aṣojú Mohammed Sani Musa ni agbátẹrùu ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà. Àwòrán àgékù láti ibùdó Channel Television You Tube .
mt0: Mohammed Sani Musa is the chief executive of the Ministry of Justice . The image is taken from the channel Television You Tube site .

en: On November 20, the Protection from Internet Falsehoods and Manipulation of other Related Matters Bill 2019, known as the "social media bill", sponsored by Senator Mohammed Sani Musa, sailed through a second reading.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ 20 oṣù Belu, Ìwé Àbádòfin tí ó fi Ààbò fún Irọ́ àti Màkàrúrù tí ó rọ̀ mọ́ ọn ti ọdún-un 2019, tí a mọ̀ sí "ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà", tí Aṣojú kan tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Mohammed Sani Musa ṣe agbátẹrùu rẹ̀, ti di kíkà nínú ìgbìmọ̀ fún ìgbà kejì.
mt0: When it was published on 20 July, the amendment to the Draft Elections Act of 2019 known as "the amendment to the Regulation of the Use of Electronic Devices", which was presented to the committee for the second time, was approved by the committee.

en: The social media bill aims to curb online falsehoods and mis- and disinformation.
yor: Èròńgbà ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà ni láti dẹ́kun àwọn àhesọ àti gbólóhùn tí kì í ṣe òtítọ́ lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: However, the real intent is not regulation, but rather, the annihilation of online freedom of expression, criminalization of government criticism and legalization of internet shutdowns in Nigeria.
yor: Bí-ó-ti-lẹ̀-jẹ́-wípé, kì í ṣe láti fi òfin de ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà ni ìwé àbádòfin náà dá lé lórí, àmọ́ ṣá, ó máa pa òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ lórí ayélujára, ìsọ alátakò ìjọba di ọ̀daràn àti fífi àtìpà ẹ̀rọ ayélujára fúngbà díẹ̀ sínú ìwé òfin.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: A similar bill was beaten dead in its track in 2016.
yor: Àtẹ̀pa bí erín bá tẹ koríko ni àwọn ọmọ Nàìjíríà tẹ irú ìwé àbádòfin báyìí pa ní ọdún-un 2016.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know

en: Any form of government criticism is a crime
yor: Ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ni bí o bá gbó ìjọba lẹ́nu (tako ìjọba)
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: This bill aims to "[prevent] the transmission of false statements or declaration of facts in Nigeria", according to Section 1a.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Abala 1A ti ṣe ṣàlàyé, èròńgbà ìwé àbádòfin yìí ni láti "[máà jẹ́] kí ìgbéjáde ọ̀rọ̀ tí kò ní òtítọ́ kan nínú tàbí èyí tí ẹ̀ríi rẹ̀ kò f'ẹsẹ̀ rinlẹ̀ tó ó jáde ní Nàìjíríà".
mt0: As provided in Article 1A, the purpose of this amendment is to "[make] it impossible to spread lies or rumors without proof in Nigeria."

en: It will ban the dissemination statements likely to be "prejudicial" to Nigeria, including subjects like public health, public safety, "public tranquility or public finances" and Nigeria's "friendly relations with other countries".
yor: Yóò yọ ọwọ́ kílàńkó àwọn àtẹ̀jáde irọ́ tí ó lè kó orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà sí "ìyọnu", láwo láì gbàgbée àwọn ọ̀ràn bíi ètò ìlera gbogboògbò, ààbòo gbogboògbò, "ìbalẹ̀-ọkàn-an gbogboògbò tàbí ìṣúná owóo gbogboògbò" àti "àwọn ìbáṣepọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà pẹ̀lú àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè mìíràn".
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: The bill will also "detect, control and safeguard against coordinated misuse of online accounts and bots", according to Section 1c.
yor: Abala 1c sọ bí ìwé àbádòfin náà yóò ṣe "mú, ṣàkóso àti fi ààbò bo ìlònílòkulò àwọn ìṣàmúlò àti ẹ̀rọ adánìkanṣiṣẹ́ orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára".
mt0: Amendment 1c states that the amendment will "remove, organize and regulate the use of computer programs and wireless devices on the Internet".

en: In other words, everything is permissible to monitor and control in the proposed law — under the guise of fighting false information.
yor: Ní àlàyé síwájú sí i, kò sí ohun tí ojú òfin tuntun náà kò leè tó bí ó bá ti jẹ́ lórí ayélujára — lábẹ́ àbùradà à ń gbógun ti àhesọ àti irọ́ pọ́nbẹ́lẹ́.
mt0: In essence, there is nothing that the new website cannot do as it is on the internet — under the guise of a debate and a debate.

en: The social media bill is omniscient since it will be binding for every Nigerian citizen, regardless of residence or geographic location, as long as the ambiguous "false statement of fact" is transmitted within the country.
yor: Ọ̀run ń ya bọ̀ ni ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà, kò yọ ẹnìkan sílẹ̀, gbogbo ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà ni yóò bá, kò kan agbègbè tàbí ibi tí ènìyàn fi ṣe ibùgbé, máà ṣe é l'oògùn máà mọ́, ọwọ́ àwọn ológìnní ojú tólé ojú tóko ni "gbólóhùn irọ́ tí kò ní ẹ̀rí" tí ó bá gba òpópónà ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere Nàìjíríà yóò bọ́ sí.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: Section 3a to b(i) of the social media bill states that:
yor: Abala 3a sí b(i) ti ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà sọ wípé:
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know Article 3a to b(i) of the Regulation on the Use of Interactive Devices states that:

en: A person must not do any act in or outside Nigeria in order to transmit in Nigeria a statement knowing or having reasons to believe that it is a false statements of fact; and the transmission of the statement in Nigeria is likely to be, prejudicial to the security of Nigeria or any part of Nigeria.
yor: Ẹnikẹ́ni kò gbọdọ̀ wu ìwà kíwà kan nínú tàbí lẹ́yìn odi Nàìjíríà láti tari gbólóhùn tí kò ní òtítọ́ kan tí a kò leè fi ẹ̀ríi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ síta; àti àgbésórí afẹ́fẹ́ ayélujára gbólóhùn t'ó lè kó orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà síta bí ọmọ ọjọ́ mẹ́jọ nípa ti ààbò ìlú.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. No one should ever go into the border or behind the Nigerian border to spread false rumors that cannot be verified; and the spread of false rumors on the internet that can spread Nigeria as young as seven years after the elections.

en: The nebulous "national security" excuse is used to justify the trumping of free expression.
yor: Ọ̀ràn-an ti "ààbò orílẹ̀-èdè" ni orí Èṣù tí òfin náà dúró lé láti pa ẹ̀tọ́ sí òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ mọ́.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: But it does not stop there, the Nigerian government is always right and cannot be criticized.
yor: Àmọ́ kò tán síbẹ̀, kò sí ẹní tó lè tako ìjọba Nàìjíríà tàbí gbó o lẹ́nu nítorí kì í ṣ'àṣìṣe.
mt0: But even so, no one can challenge the government of Nigeria or challenge it because it is not customary.

en: According to Section 3b(vi), any statement that diminishes “public confidence in the performance of any duty or function of, in the exercise of any power of the government” is prohibited.
yor: Ní Abala 3b(vi), gbólóhùn tí ó bá yẹpẹrẹ “ojúṣe tàbí ìṣe, tí ó jẹ́ ti ìjọba lójú ará ìlú” kò leè la orí ayélujára kọjá.
mt0: In Article 3b(vi), a response that describes "a political action or activity, which is owned by the state over the people" cannot pass through the Internet.

en: According to Section 3b(v), this applies to any statement that: "incites feelings of enmity, hatred, directed at persons or ill-will between different groups of persons".
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Abala 3b(v) ti ṣe fi hàn, èyí ní í ṣe pẹ̀lú gbólóhùn tí ó: "fa ìmúnilọ́tàá, tí a sọ sí ẹnìkan tàbí ìtara láàárín àwọn ènìyàn".
mt0: As Article 3b(v) states, this is related to the declaration that: "causes a disturbance, which is a warning to a person or group of people."

en: This is dangerous because it leaves regulators open to contradictory interpretations that could be abused by political actors.
yor: Èyí léwu nítorí ó fi àyè gba àwọn onípò àṣẹ láti lo agbára nílòkulò.
mt0: This is dangerous because it allows authorities to use power without authorization.

en: Who defines and approves what incites feelings of hatred?
yor: Ta ní í sọ bóyá gbólóhùn kan lè fa rògbòdìyàn?
mt0: Who is going to say whether a response can lead to a debate?

en: It means that seeking transparency or even daring to hold a politician accountable could be declared hateful.
yor: Ìyẹn túmọ̀ sí wípé lílo inú kan tàbí mímú àwọn olóṣèlúu mú ìléríi wọn ṣe lè já sí ìkórìíra lójúu wọn.
mt0: That means that using a device or a weapon to distract people can lead to a lack of understanding.

en: The punishment upon conviction for any provisions of the bill is a fine that ranges between 200,000 and 10 million naira [about $556 to $28,000 United States dollars], imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years or both.
yor: Owó ìtanràn fún ẹni tí ilé ẹjọ́ bá dá lẹ́bi tó láàárín ẹgbẹ̀rún 200 àti ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 10 owó naira [tí ó tó $556 sí $28,000 owó orílẹ̀ èdèe United States], ìtìmọ́lé fún ọdún mẹ́ta tàbí méjèèjì.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: Police licensed to shut down the internet
yor: Àṣẹ fún Àjọ Agbófinró láti ṣán ẹ̀rọ ayélujára pa fúngbà díẹ̀
mt0: The FCC has been given the authority to shut down the Internet. If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: The social media bill also grants the government unlimited power to switch off the internet, through the "Access Blocking Order" as contained in Section 12, number 3:
yor: Ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà fún ìjọba lágbára bí ó ṣe hù wọ́n láti ṣán ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere pa nígbàkúùgbà tí ó bá lérò wípé ó tọ́, nípasẹ̀ "Àṣẹ Ìdígàgá Ìráyè" láti lo ayélujára bí ó ti ṣe wà ní Abala 12, òǹkaye 3:
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. The laws on the use of the device allow the government to disable the device as a weapon when it thinks it is appropriate, under the "Privacy Act" to use the Internet as provided in Article 12, paragraph 3:

en: The Law Enforcement Department may direct the NCC [Nigerian Communications Commission – the regulatory agency for the telecommunication industry] to order the internet access service provider to take reasonable steps to disable access by end-users in Nigeria.
yor: Ẹ̀ka Agbófinró leè fi àṣẹ fún Àjọ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Nàìjíríà NCC [Nigerian Communications Commission – tí ó ń ṣe bòńkárí ìtàkùrọ̀sọ orí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá] láti pa á láṣẹ fún apèsè àyè sí ìlò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára kí ó gbé ìgbésẹ̀ lójú ẹsẹ̀ tí ò ní mú àwọn òǹlò rí àyè lo ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. The Ministry of Justice can authorize the Nigerian Communications Commission (NCC) [Nigerian Communications Commission – which is responsible for the regulation of the communications industry] to grant permission to a website to access the internet and to operate a system that does not allow users to access the internet in Nigeria.

en: Internet service providers must comply with this blocking order or risk upon conviction a fine within the range of 5 to 10 million naira [$14,000-28,000 USD].
yor: Àwọn apèsè ayélujára gbọdọ̀ tẹ̀lé òfin ìdígàgá yìí tàbí kí wọ́n ó sanwó ìtanràn tí ó tó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 5 sí 10 owó naira [$14,000-28,000 USD].
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know. The ISP must comply with this regulation or pay a fee of $5,000 to $10,000 ($14,000 to $28,000).

en: In addition, the bill under consideration indemnifies the internet service providers from any "civil or criminal liability" incurred from a lawsuit brought against them for "complying to any access blocking order", according to section 12, number 5.
yor: Ní àfikún, ìwé àbádòfin náà fi àrídájú ààbò bo àwọn apèsè iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ ayélujára tí kò ní mú wàhálà "ará ìlú tàbí bẹ́ẹ̀ " tí kò bá à lè jáde láti ìdájọ́ kan tí ẹnikẹ́ni kò bá pè wọ́n fúnopé "wọ́n tẹ̀lé òfin ìdígàgá ìráyé" sí ayélujára, ìyẹn bí abala 12, òǹkaye 5 ṣe fi lélẹ̀.
mt0: In addition, the amendment makes it a requirement for anyone who does not have a "citizenship or such" to leave a court without being called to say that they have "infringed the Internet Privacy Act" on the Internet, as provided for in Article 12, Article 5.

en: The human rights violations get murkier because the law grants the police a legal license to command an access-blocking order at whim.
yor: Ìtẹ́rí ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn náà ṣ'ókùnkùn sí i nítorí wípé òfin náà gba àwọn ọlọ́pàá láyè lábẹ́ òfin láti pa àṣẹ ìdígàgá-àyè bí ó ti ṣe hù wọ́n.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: Section 15a states that only the "initiative" of the police in face of "overwhelming sufficing evidence" is needed to cancel an internet shutdown in the country.
yor: Abala 15a sọ wípé “iṣẹ́ ọpọlọ” ọlọ́pàá ní àsìkò "ìṣèwádìí ẹ̀rí tó dájú" jẹ́ kókó láti fagilé ìṣánpá ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní orílẹ̀ èdè náà.
mt0: Amendment 15 states that the "brain work" of the police under the supervision of "certain evidence" is necessary to stop the internet usage in the country.

en: Consequently, "no appeal may be made to the High Court" [Section 13(2)] by any party to revoke such a ban without first applying to the police to revoke an existing blocking order.
yor: Ní ìparí, “kò sí àyè fún ẹjọ́ọ kò tèmi lọ́rùn ní Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga” [Abala 13(2)] tí eẹnikẹ́ni lè fi yẹ ìdígàgá sílẹ̀ láì máà kọ́kọ́ tọ ọlọ́pàá lọ láti fagilé òfin ìdígàgá náà.
mt0: In the evening, "there is no room for a judge who is not against me in the High Court" [Article 13(2)] to withdraw a sentence without first going to the police to block the sentence.

en: The implications of this are obvious — no one can resort to the courts for redress in the face of this violation while the blocking order persists.
yor: Ipa èyí hàn gbàgàdà — ẹnikẹ́ni kò ní leè gba ilé ẹjọ́ lọ fún ìgbèjà ìfẹ̀tọ́ ẹni dunni yìí tí ìdígàgá náà ṣì wà.
mt0: This shows the damage - no one can go to court for this illegal marriage where the marriage is only a temporary one.

en: Mohammed Sani Musa’s company, Activate Technologies Limited, supplied the Permanent Voter Cards (PVCs) machine used for the 2019 general elections, while he was the candidate of the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) for Niger East Senatorial district, according to the investigate outlet, Premium Times.

en: In July 2019, in the presence of a police officer, Abbo assaulted a female staff member in an adult sex toy store in Abuja.
yor: Nínú oṣù Agẹmọ 2019, ní ìṣojú ọlọ́pàá, Abbo ṣe àṣemáṣe pẹ̀lú òṣìṣẹ́bìnrin kan nínú ìsọ̀ ohun ìbálòpọ̀ ní olú-ìlú Nàìjíríà ní Abuja.

en: On March 15, 2014, Moro, as minister of interior, was responsible for the Nigerian Immigration Recruitment tragedy in which about 6 million Nigerian youths who applied for 4,000 vacant positions in Nigerian Immigration Service were forced to assemble in various recruitment locations in the country.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 15, oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà, ọdún-un 2014, Moro, tí í ṣe ọ̀gá pátápátá ètò abélé, ló wà nídìí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ abanilọ́kànjẹ́ Ìgbanisíṣẹ́ Ẹ̀ṣọ̀ aṣọ́bodè Nàìjíríà tí àwọn ọ̀dọ́langba tí ó tó bíi ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 6 tó fẹ́ àyè iṣẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún 4 tí ó ṣí sílẹ̀ nínú iléeṣẹ́ Ẹ̀ṣọ̀ Aṣọ́bodè Nàìjíríà tí wọ́n kóra jọ níbi orísìírísìí jákèjádò orílẹ̀ èdè náà.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know On January 15, 2014, Moro, a former chief of state, was investigating the riots of the Nigerian Textile Union which involved thousands of youths who wanted to leave the Nigerian Textile Union which was formed in the eastern Nigerian city of Lagos.

en: Tanzania high court upholds ruling to end child marriage despite attempts to repeal it
yor: Ilé ẹjọ́ gíga Tanzania pa á láṣẹ fún ìfòpinsí ìsoyìgì láàárín àgbàlagbà àti ọmọdé láì wo ti ìgbésẹ̀ ìmúpadàa rẹ̀
mt0: The Tanzanian High Court has ordered a surveillance of sexual orientation between adults and children without looking at its reforms.

en: "This is the best decision the court has ever made"
yor: "Èyí ni ìpinnu tí ó dára jù lọ tí ilé-ẹjọ́ yóò ṣe"
mt0: This is the best decision the court will make.

en: Schoolgirls in Tanzania pose for a photo on July 10, 2007. Photo by Fanny Schertzer, used with permission via Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.
yor: Àwọn Ọmọiléèwé ọmọdébìnrin ní Tanzania dúró fún àwòrán lọ́jọ́ 10 oṣù Agẹmọ ọdún-un, 2007. Fanny Schertzer ni ó ya àwòrán, a lò ó pẹ̀lú àṣẹ láti Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.
mt0: If you cannot translate the picture simply say you don't know. The Tanzanian Girls' School took the picture on August 10, 2007. Fanny Schertzer took the picture, which is used under the CC BY 2.0 license.

en: In October 2019, Tanzania's high court upheld the landmark 2016 ruling that increased the minimum age of marriage for girls and boys to 18.
yor: Nínú oṣù Ọ̀wàrà 2019, ilé ẹjọ́ gíga Tanzania ṣe ìdímú ṣinṣin ìdájọ́ ọdún-un 2016 tí ó pàṣẹ ó kéré jù, ọmọbìnrin àti ọmọkùnrin gbọdọ̀ pé ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún kí ó tó ṣe ìgbéyàwó.
mt0: In October 2019, the Tanzanian High Court approved a 2016 ruling that requires a couple to be married for at least two years before getting married.

en: The Tanzanian government attempted to repeal this decision, claiming that girls mature earlier and marriage is a form of protection for pregnant young women, and should, therefore, be allowed to marry earlier than 18.
yor: Àjọ ọba orílẹ̀ èdèe Tanzania gbéègbésẹ̀ láti ṣe ìmúpadà ìpinnu yìí, nítorí wípé àwọn ọmọdébìnrin ń yára bàlágà àti wípé ààbò ni ìgbéyàwó jẹ́ fún ọ̀dọ́bìnrin aláboyún.
mt0: If you cannot translate this simply say you don't know Tanzania's government is trying to change this decision, because girls are growing up and that marriage is a choice for a single woman.

en: But on October 23, 2019, the Tanzanian government lost its appeal and the high court ruling remains: The marriage age for both males and females is 18, reinforcing the ban on child marriage in Tanzania.
yor: Àmọ́ ní ọjọ́ 23 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2019, ìjọba orílẹ̀ èdèe Tanzania pàdánù ẹjọ́ọ kòtẹ́milọ́rùnun rẹ̀ tí àṣẹ ilé ẹjọ́ gíga ṣì dúró: akọ àtabo gbọdọ̀ pé ọjọ́ orí méjìdínlógún kí wọn ó tó ṣe ìgbéyàwó, tí èyí sì ń fi agbára kún ìgbẹ́sẹ̀ ìsoyìgì ọmọdé ní Tanzania.
mt0: But on October 23, 2019, Tanzania approved a constitutional amendment which remained unchanged: a man and a woman must wait for two weeks before getting married, which would further increase the incidence of child sex abuse in Tanzania.

en: According to the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), Tanzania has one of the highest prevalence rates of child marriage in the world.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) ti ṣe wí, Tanzania ni ìsoyìgì ọmọdé pọ̀ sí jù lọ lágbàáyé.
mt0: According to the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), Tanzania has the highest percentage of children in the world.

en: Netizens were quick to express their delight over the ruling.
yor: Àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára ṣíra láti fi ìdùnnúu wọn hàn lóríi ìdájọ́ náà.
mt0: The judge ordered the citizens to express their satisfaction with the decision.

en: Some congratulated Rebeca Z. Gyumi, the petitioner and respondent behind this case.
yor: Àwọn kan kí Rebeca Z. Gyumi, aláfisùn àti ẹni tí ó lé wájú nínú ọ̀ràn ìsoyìgì àwọn ọmọdé náà.
mt0: Some asked Rebeca Z. Gyumi, a lawyer and a leading advocate for the children's rights.

en: Gyumi is the founder and executive director of Msichana Initiative (Young Woman Initiative), a Tanzanian nongovernmental organization that empowers girls through education.
yor: Gyumi ni olùdásílẹ̀ àti alákòóso àgbà Msichana Initiative (Ètò fún àwọn Ọ̀dọ́mọbìnrin), iléeṣẹ́ tí kì í ṣe tìjọba tí ó ń ró àwọn ọmọdébìnrin lágbára nípasẹ̀ ti ẹ̀kọ́ ìwé.
mt0: Gyumi is the founder and executive director of the Msichana Initiative (Initiative for Women), a non-governmental organization that aims to strengthen women's capacity through education.

en: The fight to end child marriage in Tanzania
yor: Ìgbésẹ̀ láti fòpin sí ìsoyìgì ọmọdé ní Tanzania
mt0: The effort to end child abuse in Tanzania. If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: In 2016, Gyumi challenged the constitutionality of the Law of Marriage Act, 2002 (LMA) that allowed females under the age of 18 to get married.
yor: Lọ́dún-un 2016, Gyumi na ọwọ́ ìka àbùkù sí agbára Òfin Ìgbéyàwó; Law of Marriage Act, 2002 (LMA) tí ó gba obìnrin tí kò tó ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún láyè láti ṣe ìgbéyàwó.
mt0: In 2016, Gyumi signed a bill to strengthen the power of the Law of Marriage Act, 2002 (LMA) which allows a woman under the age of 18 to marry.

en: According to Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey (TDHS),  36 percent of women aged 25-49 get married before their 18th birthday compared to only 5 percent for men the same age.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwádìí nípa ìlera Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey (TDHS) ṣe ti ṣàlàyé, ìdá 36 obìnrin tí ọjọ́ oríi wọ́n wà ní 25-49 ní í ṣe ìgbéyàwó kí wọn ó tó pé ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún, tí àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ wọn lọ́kùnrin sí jẹ́ ìdá 5.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know. As Tanzania's Demographic and Health Survey (TDHS) shows, 36 percent of women aged 25-49 are married before they reach age 16, while 5 percent of their male partners are married.

en: The LMA allowed girls as young as 14 to get married with consent from a court and age 15 with the consent of the parents whereas 18 years was the minimum age for a male.
yor: Òfin LMA fi àyè gba ọmọdébìnrin tí ọjọ́ oríi wọn kò ju ọdún mẹ́rìnlá lọ láti ṣe ìgbéyàwó pẹ̀lú ìlọ́wọ́sí ilé-ẹjọ́, ìlọ́wọ́sí òbí fún ọmọ ọdún márùn-ún-dínlógún, nígbà tí ọdún méjìdínlógún jẹ́ ọjọ́ orí tí ó kéré jù lọ fún ọmọkùnrin.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. The LMA allows teenagers who are under 18 to marry with a court order, a parent's permission for a child under 16, while a 16th birthday is the earliest date for a man.

en: Through her attorneys, Gyumi argued that the LMA provisions were discriminatory for giving preferential treatment to males in the matter of eligible marriage age.
yor: Nípasẹ̀ àwọn aṣojú rẹ̀, Gyumi ṣàlàyé wípé àlàálẹ̀ LMA kọ iyán obìnrin kéré nítorí pé ó fún àwọn ọkùnrin ní àǹfààní ju àwọn obìnrin lọ.
mt0: In a statement, Gyumi said that the LMA system created a female prisoner because it gave men more rights than women.

en: They further argued that the provisions infringed the right to equality and they were too vague and too susceptible to arbitrary interpretation to deny female children their right to education.
yor: Nítẹ̀síwájú, wọ́n sọ wípé àlàálẹ̀ náà fi ẹ̀tọ́ dídọ́gba ọmọ ènìyàn yí ẹrẹ̀fọ̀ àti pé wọn fi ẹ̀tọ́ àǹfààní sí ẹ̀kọ́ ìwé dun àwọn ọmọdébìnrin.
mt0: In addition, they say that the system grants a separate rights to a child and grants a separate opportunity to a child's education.

en: Gyumi petitioned the High Court to find the provisions of LMA null and void.
yor: Gyumi rọ Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga láti gbé àlàálẹ̀ LMA tì sẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́.
mt0: Gyumi asked the High Court to approve LMA's admission.

en: The High Court never declared the provisions in the LMA null and void.
yor: Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga kò ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: But they found the provisions unconstitutional and gave the government one year to correct the anomalies in the LMA provisions.
yor: Àmọ́ wọ́n rí i lóòótọ́ wípé kò bá òfin mu wọ́n sì fún ìjọba lọ́dún kan láti ṣe àtúnṣe sí ohun tí kò tọ̀nà nínú àlàálẹ̀ LMA.
mt0: But they found it illegal and gave the government one year to make amendments to what was not consistent with the LMA's rules.

en: Through the attorney general, the government was directed to put 18 years as the eligible age of marriage for both females and males.
yor: Nípasẹ̀ aṣojú àgbà àwọn adájọ́, a pa ìjọba láṣẹ láti gbé ọjọ́ orí ìgbéyàwó sí ọdún méjìdínlógún fún obìnrin àti ọkùnrin.
mt0: Through the executive of the judges, the government was given the right to extend the marriage age to twenty-five years for women and men.

en: However, then-Attorney General George Masaju was aggrieved by the ruling and immediately served a notice of appeal to the High Court:

mt0: But the former judge rejected the verdict and wrote a written amendment to the High Court:

en: Official: I've been served government documents of appeal in the case of #childmarriage. Case number 204 of September 2017.

mt0: With government approval: I have received amended judgment on the #childmarriage case. Decision 204 of October 2017.

en: Grounds for appeal

en: In four months of court proceedings, the government sought to appeal the 2016 ruling that required the revision of the provisions LMA that allowed girls to be married at the age of 15.
yor: Láàárín oṣù mẹ́rin ìgbẹ́jọ́, ìjọba gbèrò láti ṣe àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ ọdún-un 2016 tí yó ṣe àtúnṣe sí àlàálẹ̀ LMA èyí tí ó fi àyè gba ọmọdébìnrin ọlọ́jọ́-orí márùn-úndínlógún gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹni tí ó ti bàlágà fún ìgbéyàwó.
mt0: In the four months of July, the government decided to make a 2016 amendment to the LMA which would allow a 16-year-old girl to be a candidate for marriage.

en: The appellant, represented by principal state attorneys, Mark Mulwambo and Alesia Mbuya, provided biological differences and customary and Islamic laws as grounds for the appeal.
yor: Atẹ́jọ́pè, tí ó jẹ́ aṣojú àwọn adájọ́ ìpínlẹ̀, Mark Mulwambo àti Alesia Mbuya, ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìyàtọ̀ ìwà ẹ̀dá obìnrin àti ọkùnrin tí wọ́n sì fi àṣà ìbílẹ̀ àti òfin ẹ̀sìn Ìmàle gbá àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ náà nídìí.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Ms. Mbuya argued that biological differences put boys and girls in "different categories" and that therefore, the law treats them differently.

mt0: Ms. Mbuya says that gender differences lead to "separate identity" and that the law takes a different view of them.

en: She argued that because girls matured earlier, the law took that into consideration. She argued that marriage could protect unmarried girls who get pregnant at an early age.
yor: Ó sọ síwájú sí i wípé nítorí àwọn ọmọdébìnrin máa ń tètè bàlágà ju ọmọdékùnrin lọ ni òfin fi la àlàálẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀. Ó sọ wípé ìgbéyàwó lè fi ààbò bo ọmọdébìnrin tí kò sí nílé ọkọ tí ó ti di abaraméjì láì tó ọjọ́ orí tí ó tọ́.

en: Further, she argued the court erred by “equating the age of the child and the age of marriage,” meaning that the court should consider male and female children differently when it comes to marriageable age.

mt0: He told him that the court was "wrongly enforcing the laws of marriage and childbirth," which means that separate marriage dates should be set, separate marriage dates should be set for both men and women.

en: American rapper Kanye West brought his "Sunday Service" pop-up concert to Kingston, Jamaica, at the start of its National Heroes Day holiday weekend (October 19-21, 2019).
yor: Ọ̀kọrin tàkasúfèé tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Amẹ́ríkà Kanye West gbé àríyá "Ìsìn Ọjọ́ Ọ̀sẹ̀ " pop-up concert wá sí Kingston, Jamaica, ní kété tí ìsinmi ọjọ́ ọ̀sẹ̀ fún Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Àwọn Málegbàgbé Ọmọ Orílẹ̀-èdè náà (19-21, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2019) yóò bẹ̀rẹ̀.
mt0: Kanye West, an American singer-songwriter, has played a pop-up concert in Kingston, Jamaica, during the week before the International Day of the Disabled (19-21, October 2019).

en: This was the first time the rapper had taken his huge gospel choir outside the United States, reportedly at the request of a Jamaican member of his staff.
yor: Èyí ni ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ tí ọ̀kọrin náà yóò kó ẹgbẹ́ akọrin ìyìnrere rẹ̀ kúrò ní Amẹ́ríkà, ní ìjẹ́pèe ti agbè fún ìjọba orílẹ̀ èdèe kan tí ó Ja kí ó gbé ètò náà wá sílùú òun.
mt0: This is the first time the singer will leave the United States, in a written letter to a Ja-based government to approve the plan.

en: However, the event was besieged with criticism from the outset, culminating with West's unapproved use of Jamaican emblems on merchandise being sold on his website.
yor: Síbẹ̀, àríyá náà tí rí ìtakò láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀, tí ó Ho forí sọlẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àmì ìdánimọ̀ọ orílè-èdèe Jamaica tí West we lórí ọjà tí ó ń tà lóríi ibùdó ìtakùn àgbáyée rẹ̀ láì gba àṣẹ láti lò ó.
mt0: But the jury has seen a few cases of corruption, when Ho went out with a Jamaican stamp on the sale of the tobacco on his global tobacco market without having a license to use it.

en: With just two days’ notice, the free concert took place at Emancipation Park in Kingston, the capital city — a location that jarred some commentators because of controversial comments West had made about slavery during a media interview in May 2018.
yor: Láàárín ọjọ́ méjì ni ìkéde fi lọ síta, inúu gbàgede Emancipation Park tó wà ní Kingston, olú ìlú orílẹ̀ èdè náà ni bẹbẹ́ ti wáyé — ojú ibi tí ó mú àwọn sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ kan wí tẹnu wọn látàrí àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ tó mú àríyànjiyàn dání tí West sọ nípa òwò ẹrú nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò kan báyìí lóṣù karùn-ún ọdún-un 2018.
mt0: Since the announcement was published, a protest in the Emancipation Park in Kingston, the capital of the country has been held - a site where some activists have been angry over the remarks made by West about the illegal immigration investigation in a recent interview.

en: The park was opened in 2002 in honour of the "full freedom" of 300,000 slaves in Jamaica on August 1, 1838.

en: Jamaica’s reality is that successive political administrations have never fully appreciated the economic value of the brand "Jamaica" nor the symbols that [represent] that brand including its flag and its coat of arms.

The earthquake took place in Guinea on 14 October, which has killed many people and taken thousands of people prisoner after a protest against the government of the president Alpha Condé, who is trying to rewrite the constitution to allow him to go for a third time.

en: Thousands of visitors to the historic city of Stone Town, Zanzibar, have followed the sound of music to the Dhow Countries Music Academy (DCMA), a music school that promotes and preserves the islands’ musical traditions of the Swahili Coast along the Indian Ocean.
yor: Ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún àlejò tí ó ń rọ́ wìtìwìtì wá sí ìlú Stone Town, Zanzibar tí ó kún fún ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtẹ̀yìnwá, ti tẹ̀lé ìró orin Iléèwé Orin kíkọ Àwọn Orílẹ̀-èdèe Dhow (DCMA), ilé ẹ̀kọ́ orin kíkọ tí ó ń ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àti ìpamọ́ àwọn àṣà orin erékùṣù náà tí ó sún mọ́ Swahili ní ẹ̀báa Omi Òkun India.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: Since 2002, the school has promoted and preserved the Zanzibar's unique mix of Arab, Indian and African cultures through music.
yor: Láti ọdún-un 2002, ilé ẹ̀kọ́ náà ti ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àti ìpamọ́ àkójọpọ̀ orin Lárúbáwá, India àti Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tí kò lẹ́lẹ́gbẹ́.
mt0: From 2002, the school has been involved in the recording and distribution of music in Rwanda, India and the United Arab Emirates.

en: After 17 years, the school faces a financial crisis that threatens its closure.
yor: Lẹ́yìn-in ọdún kẹtàdínlógún, iléèwé náà kò rí owó tí ó tówó nínú àpò ìkówó sí tí ó sì leè fa kí iléèwé náà ó di títì pa.
mt0: After the fourth year, the school did not receive any income from the savings account and could have collapsed.

en: Nearly 70% of its 80 full-time students can't afford to pay their tuition, which comes to about $13 USD per month, according to an official DCMA press release.
yor: Nínú ìwé ìgbéròyìnjáde tí àwọn aláṣẹ DCMA tẹ̀ jáde, ìdá àádọ́rin nínú àwọn ọgọ́rin akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ni kò rí owó iléèwé wọn tí ó tó bíi $13 USD lóṣù san.
mt0: In the report released by DCMA, twenty-five percent of the students did not receive their school allowance of about $13 USD per month.

en: While the school has received support over the years from international donors and diplomatic missions, they face a gap in funding that may force them to shut their doors at the historic Old Customs House.
yor: Pẹ̀lú àtìlẹ́yìn àwọn onínúure tí ó ti dáwó fún iléèwé náà, owó tí ó kù ní sísan ṣì pọ̀ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ tí ó fi jẹ́ wípé, ó ṣe é ṣe kí ilẹ̀kùn-un iléèwé náà tí ó wà nínú Ilé Àwọn Ẹ̀ṣọ́ Aṣọ́bodè Àtijọ́.
mt0: With the lack of funds for the school, the amount of money left over was so high that it could have been able to afford the school's roof which is in the Old School.

en: Without crucial funds to continue, DCMA students and staff fear that the soulful sounds that flow through the hallways of this iconic institution that make these islands sing — may cease.
yor: Láìsí owó tí ó tówó nílẹ̀ láti tẹ̀síwájú, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ DCMA àti òṣìṣẹ́ ń fòyà kí ìró amọ́kànbalẹ̀ tí ó ń sun jáde láti inúu gbọ̀ngán olókìkí ilé ẹ̀kọ́ yìí tí ó mú erékùṣù yìí kọrin — leè wọ òkùnkùn.
mt0: Without the money to prepare, DCMA students and officials are fighting to get the noise of the classroom rooftop which makes the island sing — to be covered with a blanket.

en: The school not only teaches and promotes traditional culture and heritage through music, but it's also home to a community of young musicians who seek alternatives to making a living as creatives.
yor: Orin àti ìgbélárugẹ àṣà àti àjogúnbá nìkan kọ́ ni ilé ẹ̀kọ́ náà fi gbajúmọ̀, àmọ́ ó jẹ́ ilé fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ tí ó ń wà ibi tí wọn yóò ti fi ìmọ̀ kún ìmọ̀.

en: A DCMA student learns the qanun, a featured instrument in classical taarab songs. Photo courtesy of the DCMA.

en: "We [have started] to face a very challenging financial moment", said Alessia Lombardo, managing director of the DCMA, in an official DCMA video.
yor: "A [ti bẹ̀rẹ̀] sí í ní rí ìdojúkọ ìgbà tí ó nira", alákòóso àgbàa DCMA, Alessia Lombardo sọ, nínúu àwòrán fídíò DCMA kan.
mt0: "We [started] to see a difficult time," said DCMA's global chief executive, Alessia Lombardo, in a DCMA video.

en: "From now to the next six months, we are not sure that we can guarantee the salaries to our teachers and staff".
yor: Láti ìsinsìnyí lọ títí di oṣù mẹ́fà sí àsìkò yìí, a kò rí àrídájú tí ó rinlẹ̀ wípé a ó leè san owó oṣù àwọn olùkọ́ni àti òṣìṣẹ́ẹ".
mt0: Since the beginning of this year, we have not seen any evidence that we can pay the teachers and employees' salaries."

en: At the moment, 19 master teachers and small core staff have gone without salaries for over three months as the school struggles to secure strong funding partnerships and explore sustainable funding models for a school.
yor: Ní àkókò tí a wà yìí, àwọn àkàwé-gboyè olùkọ́ 19 àti àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ mìíràn ti ṣiṣẹ́ fún oṣù mẹ́ta gbáko láì gba owó lọ sílé nítorí àìsí owó nínúu kóló iléèwé.
mt0: In this situation, 19 teachers and other employees have been working for three months without getting paid because of a lack of money in the school council.

en: While the archipelago is known as a tourist destination for its pristine beaches and luxury hotels, the majority of local people struggle with high unemployment even as poverty has slightly decreased, according to The World Bank.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Ilé Ìfowópamọ́ Àgbáyé ṣe ti ṣàlàyé wípé, pẹ̀lú bí a ti ṣe mọ agbègbè tí iléèwé náà wà fún ibi ìrìn-àjò ìgbafẹ́ nítorí àwọn etíkun àtijọ́ àti ilé ìtura olówó ńláńlá tí ó kángun síbẹ̀, ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ ló ń bá àìníṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́ pò ó pàápàá bí ìṣẹ́ ṣe ti gbé fúkẹ́ ju ti ìgbà kan lọ.

As the International Archives and Records Administration has reported, although the area where the school is known for its historic buildings and large luxury hotels, the attitude of the students toward illegal activity is comparable to that of a former society.

en: For 17 years, the DCMA has worked tirelessly to promote and protect Zanzibar’s rich heritage and traditions through music.
yor: Fún ọdún mẹ́tàdínlógún, DCMA ti ṣiṣẹ́ àṣekúdórógbó nípa lílo orin ṣe ìgbélárugẹ tòun ìpamọ́ ọ̀rọ̀ àjogúnbá àti àṣà Zanzibar.
mt0: In the past twenty years, DCMA has been working on a project to preserve the heritage and culture of Zanzibar.

en: The birthplace of legendary taarab singers Siti Binti Saad and Fatuma Binti Baraka, or Bi. Kidude, Zanzibar is home to musical genres that emerged through cultural exchange and collaboration along the Swahili Coast for hundreds of years.
yor: Orírun àwọn olóhùn-iyò akọrin taarab, Siti Binti Saad àti Fatuma Binti Baraka, tí a tún mọ̀ sí Bi. Kidude, Zanzibar ni ilé èyí-ò-jọ̀yìí orin tí ó ti inúu ìbàṣepapọ̀ àṣà àti àjọṣe ọlọ́dún gbọgbọrọ tí ó wà láàárín àwọn àdúgbò ẹ̀ka Swahili.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know. The paradise of the two singers, Siti Binti Saad and Fatuma Binti Baraka, also known as Bi. Kidude, Zanzibar is a venue of this kind of music which is a combination of traditional and traditional rhythms within the Swahili diaspora.

en: Today, students can learn traditional musical genres like taarab, ngoma and kidumbak, along with instruments like drums, qanun and oud, as gatekeepers — and interpreters — of culture and tradition.
yor: Láyé òde òní, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ leè kọ́ orin ìbílẹ̀ bíi taarab, ngoma àti kidumbak, pẹ̀lú àfikún àwọn ohun èlò ìkọrin bíi ìlù ní oníranànran, qanun àti oud, gẹ́gẹ́ bí alápamọ́ — àti òǹgbifọ̀ — àṣà àti ìṣe.
mt0: Today, students can learn traditional instruments such as taarab, ngoma and kidumbak, along with a variety of instrumental instruments such as drums in Arabic, Qanun and Oud, as a preserve and representative of culture and practice.

en: Zanzibar’s Amina Omar Juma, a former DCMA student and current DCMA teacher, recently returned from a tour in South Africa with her critically acclaimed, "Siti and the Band", known for "fusing the roots" by blending traditional taarab sounds with contemporary, layered rhythms.
yor: Ọmọ bíbíi Zanzibar, tí ó jẹ́ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ọ DCMA nígbà kan rí, tí ó jẹ́ olùkọ́ni ní iléèwé kan náà báyìí, Amina Omar Juma tòun ti ìlú mọ̀ọ́ká ẹgbẹ́ akọrin rẹ̀, tí ó ń "fi àṣà ìró orin ìbílẹ̀ " taarab papọ̀ mọ́ ti ìgbàlódélonígbàńlò kọrin, ìyẹn "Siti àti Ẹgbẹ́ ", ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ padà wọ̀lú láti ìrìnàjò orin kíkọ kan ní orílẹ̀-èdèe South Africa.

The Zanzibari, who was once a DCMA student, and now a teacher at the same school, Amina Omar Juma, whose band, which "combines the traditional taarab music with the modern instrumental music, called "Siti and the Band," has just returned from a tour in South Africa.

en: She and other band members, also former DCMA students, released their first full album, "Fusing the Roots", in 2018, going on to perform at Sauti za Busara, East Africa's largest music festival, that same year.

en: Over 15,000 visitors have passed through the academy’s iconic building to enjoy live performances, workshops and classes and interact with passionate DCMA musicians who represent the future of Zanzibar culture and heritage, according to the DCMA.

en: Drawing from a complex history of Indian, Arab and African exchange, the school celebrates the influence of "dhow countries", with inspiration from cultures that converged along the Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf.
yor: Iléèwé náà ti ṣe àyálò àti àmúpapọ̀ ọ̀kan-ò-jọ̀kan àṣà "àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè dhow", tí ó wà ní ìtòsíi Òkun India àti Ọ̀gbùn-un Persia.
mt0: The library has developed and developed a single style of "dhow" culture, which is located in the coasts of India and Persia.

en: The Omani Sultanate, a "major maritime force from the 17th to 19th centuries", shifted its seat of power from Muscat to Zanzibar in 1840.
yor: Agbègbèe Omani Sultanate, tí ó jẹ́ " ibi gbòógì àwọn alágbára atukọ̀ orí omi ní ọgọ́rùn-ún Ọdún-un kẹtàdínlógún sí kọkàndínlógún sẹ́yìn", gbé àga agbára rẹ̀ láti Muscat sí Zanzibar ní ọdún-un 1840.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know. The Omani Sultanate, which was "the focal point of the maritime explorers in the 15th to 18th century", moved its power from Muscat to Zanzibar in 1840.

en: From Stone Town, Omani kings oversaw elaborate systems of maritime trade, including cloves, gold, and textiles, powered by strong winds that set dhows — traditional Arab vessels — sailing across the Indian Ocean, from India to Oman to East Africa.
yor: Láti Stone Town, àwọn ọba Omani ń tukọ̀ọ okòwò orí omi ìgbà náà tí ó fẹjú, títí kan kànáfùrù, wúrà, àti aṣọ , látàrí àwọn ìjì líle tí ń tu àwọn ọkọ̀ ìbílẹ̀ẹ Lárúbáwáa — dhows — ní oríi Òkun Indian, láti India sí Oman títí lọ dé Ìlà-Oòrùn Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Young Zanzibaris recognize the importance of connecting with the past to determine their future and the music created today expresses that desire to bridge the old with the new.

en: Their violinist, Felician Mussa, 20, has only been studying the violin for 3.5 years; TaraJazz is one of the most sought-after bands on the islands, captured here by photographer Aline Coquelle:

en: The Swahili coast tells the story of epic cultural exchanges and the DCMA continues this tradition through its musical collaborations.

en: Every year, the school hosts an initiative called "Swahili Encounters", matching well-known musicians hailing from Africa, the Middle East, Europe and North America with DCMA students to create original musical compositions within a week-long period.
yor: Lọ́dọọdún, iléèwé náà máa ń gbàlejò fún ètò tí a pè ní "Ìkọlù Swahili", tí ó mú àgbárijọpọ̀ọ àgbà akọrin láti Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, Ìlú Abẹ́-àkóso Lárúbáwá, Ilẹ̀ Éróòpù àti Àríwá Amẹ́ríkà pẹ̀lú àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ DCMA láti ṣe orin láàárín ọ̀sẹ̀ kan.
mt0: Every year, the school hosts a program called "Swahili Music Festival", which brings together a global choir from the United States, the African Republic, Europe and the United States with DCMA students to perform in a week.

en: At the end of the "encounter", the newly-formed collaboration performs at Sauti za Busara, and many of these collaborations turn into life-time friendships that transcend the boundaries of language and culture, proving music is a universal language.
yor: Ní ìgbẹ̀yìngbẹ́yín "ìkọlù" náà, àgbárijọpọ̀ tuntun náà yóò ta bí elégbé ní Sauti za Busara, tí àjọṣepọ̀ wọ̀nyí yóò sì di ìbáṣepọ̀ ọlọ́jọ́ pípẹ́ tí kò mọ ìyàtọ̀ èdè àti àṣà, tí ó fi hàn gbangba wálíà wípé èdè kan náà tí gbogbo ayé gbọ́ ni orin.
mt0: In the end of the "collision" the new alliance will sell like a jewel in Sauti za Busara, and the alliance will become a permanent alliance without linguistic differences, which makes it clear that the only language that everyone hears is music.

en: DCMA offers weekly live performances showcasing students’ talents and collaborations with visiting musicians, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. Photo courtesy of DCMA.
yor: DCMA máa ń ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ètò orin kíkọ tí ó ń ṣe ìgbélárugẹ ẹ̀bùn orin kíkọ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti àfihàn àjọṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú ọ̀kọrin àlejò hàn ní, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. DCMA ni ó ni àwòrán.
mt0: DCMA is developing a learning music program that aims to enhance the learning experience of students and shows collaboration with visitors in Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. DCMA has pictures.

en: The DCMA recognizes that music empowers and unites people across cultures — and it also employs talented youth living in a struggling economy with limited job opportunities.
yor: DCMA mọ rírì orin gẹ́gẹ́ bí ohun tí ó leè ró àwọn ènìyàn lágbára àti gẹ́gẹ́ bí ohun tí ó lè mú ìṣọ̀kan àti ìrẹ́pọ̀ bá àwọn ènìyàn láì wo ti àṣà — ó sì tún ń pèsè àǹfààní iṣẹ́ fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ tí ó ní ẹ̀bùn àmọ́ tí ó ń tiraka láti jẹ.
mt0: DCMA knows music as a tool that can stimulate people and bring together people without regard for culture — and it also offers opportunities for young people who are hungry but trying to become successful.

en: For the 1,800 students who have trained at the DCMA, this is the only musical home they know, where they can learn and grow as professional musicians and artists.
yor: Fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ 1,800 tí ó ti gba ìdánilẹ́kọọ́ ní DCMA, èyí nìkan ni ibi ilé orin tí wọ́n mọ̀, níbi tí wọ́n ti ń kọ́ ẹ̀kọ́ tí wọ́n sì ti ń ní àlékún ìmọ̀ nípa iṣẹ́ orin kíkọ àti bí a ṣe ń di òǹkọrin.
mt0: For 1,800 students who have taken a test at DCMA, this is the only place they know, where they have been taught and where they have a lot of knowledge about the art of singing and how to become a singer.

en: One traveler from Spain, who recently visited the DCMA, wrote on TripAdvisor: "Personally, meeting the musicians was the best piece of my time on this island".
yor: Arìnrìn-àjò kan láti Spain, tó bẹ DCMA wò ní kò pẹ́ yìí, kọ sí oríi TripAdvisor: "Ní tèmi, ìṣalábàápàdée àwọn akọrin ni ìgbà tí ó meet jù lọ fún mi ní erékùṣù yìí".
mt0: "For me, the singer's timing was the best I've ever had in this island." a traveller from Spain who visited DCMA a few days ago wrote on TripAdvisor: "For me, the singer's timing was the best I've ever had in this island."

en: As Zanzibar’s tourism sector rapidly grows, the DCMA believes that music plays an essential role in the celebration, preservation and promotion of Swahili culture, heritage and history.
yor: Bí ẹ̀ka ìrìn-àjò afẹ́ẹ Zanzibar ṣe ń gbèrò sí i, DCMA nígbàgbọ́ wípé orin ní ipa kan gbòógì ní í ṣe nínú àjọyọ̀, ìpamọ́ àti ìgbélárugẹ tòun ìpolongo àṣà, àjogúnbá àti ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtẹ̀yìnwáa Swahili.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: Zanzibar is far more than its beaches and luxury hotels — it’s a place bursting with talent that stems from an extraordinary history of cultural connection and collaboration.
yor: Zanzibar ju àwọn etíkun àti ilé ìtura olówó iyebíye rẹ̀ lọ — ó jẹ́ ibi tí ó kún fún àwọn ènìyàn ọlọ́pọlọ tí ó ní ẹ̀bùn ní poolo orí wọn látàrí àjọṣepọ̀ ọlọ́jọ́ pípẹ́ tí ó mú agbègbè náà dá yàtọ̀ gedegbe.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know Zanzibar more than its beaches and hotels - it is a place filled with intelligent people who enjoy their pools of their hearts thanks to the long-standing friendships that have made the region so distinct.

en: Editor's note: The author of this post has volunteered with DCMA.
yor: Ìfiyèsí Alákòóso Ìwé Títẹ̀: Òǹkọ̀wé àtẹ́jádé yìí ti ṣiṣẹ́ ọ̀fẹ́ pẹ̀lú DCMA.
mt0: Proof of work: This document has been written with DCMA for free.

en: Witch-hunting still claims lives in rural India
yor: Ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ ṣì ń gba ẹ̀mí àwọn ènìyàn ní ìgbèríko India
mt0: Only return the translated translation. If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: Superstition and lack of awareness behind witch-hunting in India
yor: Superstition and lack of awareness behind witch-hunting in India
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know. Superstition and lack of awareness behind witch-hunting in India.

en: A village near Jamshedpur in Jharkhand. Picture courtesy Anumeha Verma
yor: Ìletò kan ní ẹ̀báa Jamshedpur ní Jharkhand. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Anumeha Verma
mt0: A suicide bombing in Jamshedpur, Jharkhand. Image by Anumeha Verma

en: On 20 July, four elderly people were lynched by a mob in the Gumla District of Jharkhand, India after being accused of practicing witchcraft.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 20 oṣù Agẹmọ, àgbájọ àwọn ènìyànkéènìà gba ẹ̀mí àwọn àgbàlagbà mẹ́rin kan láì dá wọn lẹ́jọ́ ní agbègbèe Gumla ní Jharkhand, India lẹ́yìn tí a fi ẹ̀sùn-un àjẹ́ kàn wọ́n.
mt0: In October 20, a human rights court killed four youths without charge in the district of Gumla in Jharkhand, India after being accused of arson.

en: According to reports, the victims were accused of causing a man's death and they were eventually found guilty of witchcraft by a Panchayat (a village assembly).
yor: Gẹ̀gẹ̀ bí ìjábọ̀ ìròyìn, àwọn àgbàlagbà wọ̀nyí ṣe ikú pa ọkùnrin kan, ni ìgbìmọ̀ abúlée Panchayat ṣe dá wọn lẹ́bi.
mt0: According to the reports, the elders killed a man, according to the provincial Panchayat.

en: The victims were dragged out of their homes and beaten to death by masked men wielding sticks.
yor: Wọ́n wọ́ àwọn àgbàlagbà mẹ́rin wọ̀nyí jáde síta ilée wọn, àwọn ọkùnrin tí ó bòjú sì fi igi lù wọ́n títí tí ẹ̀mí fi bọ́ lára wọn.
mt0: They took the four elders out of their house, and the men who were standing nearby struck them with a tree until they died.

en: Eight of the attackers were subsequently arrested by police.
yor: Mẹ́jọ nínú àwọn ènìyànkéènìà wọ̀nyí ti wà ní akóló ọlọ́pàá.
mt0: Seven of these people are in custody.

en: According to police data published by The Times of India, witch-hunting in Jharkhand has claimed 123 lives from May 2016 to May 2019.
yor: Gẹ̀gẹ̀ bí àkọsílẹ̀ ọlọ́pàá tí Times of India tẹ̀jáde, ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ ní Jharkhand ti rán àwọn ènìyàn 123 sọ́run àpàpàǹdodo ní àárín-in oṣù Èbìbí ọdún-un 2016 sí oṣù Èbìbí ọdún-un 2019.
mt0: According to the Times of India report, the Jharkhand prison system sent 123 people to prison between January 2016 and January 2019.

en: Across the country, 134 people were killed for the alleged use of "black magic" in 2016, according to the National Crime Records Bureau.
yor: Jákèjádò, ènìyàn 134 di ẹni ẹbọra-ń-bá-jẹun látàrí èsùn-un lílo “ògùngùn” ní ọdún-un 2016, ìyẹn gẹ̀gẹ̀ bí Àjọ Aṣàkọsílẹ̀ Ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ Orílẹ̀-èdè náà ṣe kọ́ ọ sílẹ̀.
mt0: According to the Criminal Investigation Agency, 134 people were arrested in 2016 for allegedly using "drugs," according to the Ministry of Justice.

en: A Perpetual Malady
yor: Àrùn T’ó Ń Peléke Sí i
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: "Witch-hunting is not new in Jharkhand", says Prem Chand, the Founding Chairman of the Free Legal Aid Committee (FLAC) in Jharkhand, in a telephonic interview.
yor: "Ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ kò jẹ́ tuntun ní Jharkhand", Prem Chand, Olúdásílẹ̀ àti Alága Free Legal Aid Committee (FLAC) ní Jharkhand, sọ nínúu ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò orí ẹ̀ro-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ kan.
mt0: "The corruption in Jharkhand is not new," Prem Chand, the chief executive and chairman of the Free Legal Aid Committee (FLAC) in Jharkhand, said in a press conference.

en: FLAC has been instrumental in bringing about legislation against witch-hunting in Jharkhand.
yor: FLAC ti ń ṣe àtọ́nàa ìṣòfin tí ó tako ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ ní Jharkhand.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know FLAC is taking legal action against the illegal mining in Jharkhand.

en: The organisation first began working in this area in 1991 when a woman was accused by her neighbour of causing a boy’s death.
yor: Iléeṣẹ́ náà bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́ ní agbègbè yìí ní ọdún-un 1991 nígbà tí àwọn aládùúgbò fi ẹ̀sùn kan obìnrin kan pé ó lọ́wọ́ nínú ikú ọmọdékùnrin kan.
mt0: The agency began to work in the area in 1991 when a woman was accused of killing a boy.

en: An irate mob attacked her and killed her husband and son.
yor: Àgbájọ àwọn ènìyànkéènìà kan dìgbò lù ú, wọ́n sì pa ọkọ àti ọmọ rẹ̀ ọkùnrin.
mt0: A jury of people voted against him, and they killed his car and son.

en: She sustained injuries.
yor: Òún fi ara pa.

yor: Nígbàtí Prem Chand àti àwọn ẹlẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ ṣe ìbẹ̀wò sí àwọn ẹlẹ́ṣẹ̀ wọ̀nyí nínúu túbú, wọ́n bá ìpèníjà:

en: They told us that they stood by their accusation.
yor: Wọ́n sọ fún wọn wípé àwọn dúró lé oríi ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n fi kan àwọn.
mt0: They told them they were waiting in the courtroom.

en: They also shared a belief that when the blood of a woman branded as a witch falls on the ground, she loses her so-called powers of sorcery.
yor: Wọ́n sì tún gbàgbọ́ wípé bí ẹ̀jẹ̀ẹ ẹni tí a pè ní àjẹ́ bá kan ilẹ̀ ọ̀gẹ́rẹ́, yóò pàdánù agbára ẹlẹyẹ rẹ̀.

yor: Prem Chand sọ wípé ó kan apá kan nínú àwọn ọmọ ìlú:
mt0: Prem Chand says he is one of the citizens:

en: Usually, it is the women from the weaker sections of the society and economically backward regions that are targeted.
yor: Nígbàgbogbo, àwọn obìnrin tí kò lárá tí ó tálákà ní í máa ń fi ara kááṣá.
mt0: However, women who are not in a stable environment often dress up.

en: The victims are mostly Adivasis, Harijans and Dalits.
yor: Àwọn tí ó f’ara kááṣá wọ̀nyí ni àwọn Adivasis, Harijans àti Dalits.
mt0: The ones who wear these clothes are the Adivasis, Harijans and Dalits.

en: It is an assault on the dignity of women and a violation of constitutional rights for a dignified life for every human being.
yor: Ìfojú iyì àwọn obìnrin àti ìtasẹ̀ àgẹ̀rẹ̀ sí òfin ẹ̀tọ́ sí ayé iyì fún gbogbo ọmọ ènìyàn.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: The Social and Political Realities
yor: Òtítọ́ Àwùjọ àti Ìṣèlú
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: Activists say that deeply rooted superstitions prevalent in the hinterlands are a major cause behind the practice.
yor: Àwọn ajìjàngbara sọ wípé ìgbàgbọ́-asán tí ó rinlẹ̀ ní ìgbèríko ni ó ń fa ìwà pálapalà náà.
mt0: A spokesman for the military says that the political climate in the country is causing the explosion.

en: A lack of education, poor health facilities and economic backwardness mark the regions where these practices are prevalent.
yor: Àìgbẹ̀kọ́, ètò ìlera tí ò pójú òṣùwọ̀n àti kòlàkòṣagbe tí ó ń gb’àgbègbè tí ìwà pálapalà wọ̀nyí ti gbalẹ̀ bí i ìtàkùn ni ó fi wọ́pọ̀.
mt0: First, a system of rules that does not apply to cities and villages where these rules have become a necessity.

en: The cases so far show that often a rumor started by someone is enough to get the ball rolling.
yor: Ọ̀ràn wọ̀nyí ti fi hàn wípé àhesọ ni ó máa fi ń bẹ̀rẹ̀ .
mt0: These advice has shown that he often starts with a joke.

en: Despite the laws enacted by various Indian states which declare witch-hunting to be illegal, participants in these cases see it as a form of self-defense.
yor: Pẹ̀lú òfin àwọn ìpínlẹ̀ India tí ó ka ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ sí ohun tí ó lòdì sófin, àwọn akópa ọ̀ràn wọ̀nyí rí i gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀nà ìdáààbò-ara-ẹni.
mt0: With the Indian law that makes a prescription a legal requirement, these advocates see it as a form of self-defense.

en: It is also used as an excuse for grabbing resources owned by women, exacting revenge or even exploiting women for sex.
yor: Bákan náà ni wọ́n ń wí àwáwí fún gbígba ohun ìní àwọn obìnrin, fi agbára gbẹ̀san tàbí fi ipá bá obìnrin lò pọ̀.
mt0: They also write books on female hygiene, using a humidifier or using a humidifier to increase the amount of moisture.

en: According to Prem Chand:
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Prem Chand ṣe ti sọ:
mt0: As Prem Chand said:

en: The premise is that once you brand a woman as a witch, you can subject her to any treatment.
yor: Àtètèròtẹ́lẹ̀ ni wípé ní kété tí o bá ti pe obìnrin ní àjẹ́, o lè tẹríi rẹ̀ ba fún ìlòkulò.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know

en: However, it is important to note that the practice is used as a justification for exploitation and is not a cause behind it per se.
yor: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, ó ṣe kókó láti mọ̀ wípé wọn máa ń lo ìwà pálapàla yìí fi gba tara àwọn obìnrin, kò sì kìí ṣe ìdí tí ó ń fà á pàtó.
mt0: However, it is worth noting that they often use this method to get women to settle down, and it is not a particular reason.

en: Ironically, the panchayat often provides tacit approval for branding a person a witch even if does not pass ruling on the punishment to be meted out.
yor: Ní ti ẹ̀fẹ̀, láì wí tó, panchayat náà sábà máa ń lọ́wọ́ sí ìpènìyàn ní àjẹ́ pàápàá bí kò bá pàṣẹ ìjìyà t'ó tọ́.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: In addition to the elected panchayat, there are self-styled caste panchayats with no legal mandate whatsoever that operate in certain parts of the country.
yor: Ní àfikùn sí panchayat tí ìbó yàn, àwọn kan ńbẹ tí wọ́n pe ara wọn ní panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀ láì ní àṣẹ kankan tí ó fún wọn lágbara níbikíbi ní orílẹ̀-èdè.
mt0: In addition to the panchayats chosen, there are some who call themselves the lowest panchayats without having any powers within the country.

en: These bodies pass verdicts and mete out punishments and remain largely unchallenged.
yor: Àwọn ẹgbẹ́ yìí máa ń dájọ́ àti fi ìyà jẹ ènìyàn tí kò sì sí ẹni tí ó ká wọn lápá kò.
mt0: These groups often judge and judge without anyone being involved.

en: An incident in Ajmer district of Rajasthan in 2017 reported involvement of caste panchayat leading to the death of a 40-year-old woman.
yor: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kan ní agbègbèe Ajmer ní Rajasthan lọ́dún-un 2017 jábọ̀ ìlọ́wọ́sí panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀ tí ó ṣ’okùnfa ikú obìnrin ogójì ọdún kan.
mt0: A murder in Ajmer in Rajasthan in 2017 reportedly killed a woman aged 50.

en: Legally, the courts can take action against such verdicts in case of both elected panchayats and caste panchayats.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí òfin, ilé ẹjọ́ lé gbé ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó tako irúu ìdájọ́ báwọ̀nyí yálà láti ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn panchayat tí ìbó yàn àti panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀.
mt0: According to the law, the court can enforce a judicial order against such a decision taken by the elected panchayats and the lower panchayats.

en: However, the victims seldom get the opportunity to reach a court of law before they become targets of mobs.
yor: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, àwọn tí ó fara kááṣá ò tilẹ̀ ní àǹfààní sí ilé-ẹjọ́ òfin kí àgbájọ-àwọn-ènìyànkéènìà ó tó kojúu wọn.
mt0: However, those who are involved in the illegal activity do not have the right to go to court to be prosecuted by the judicial system.

en: According to Debjani’s statements, she was accused of being the cause of several deaths in Cherekali village located 180 km from Guwahati, the capital of the eastern state in India.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀rọ̀ọ Debjani, a f’ẹ̀sùn-un ìgbẹ̀mí ènìyàn púpọ̀ kàn án ní abúlée Cherekali tí ó wà ní kìlómità 180 láti Guwahati, olú-ìlúu India ti apáa ìlà-oòrùn.
mt0: According to Debjani, a huge number of people were killed in the Cherekali flood which killed at least 180 people in Guwahati, the Indian eastern city.

yor: Olóríi gbọ̀gán àdúrà abúlé l’ó dárúkọ rẹ̀ tí àwọn ará abúlé sí fi ìyà jẹ́ ẹ.

en: Among these, a 40-year-old woman Kanya Devi was attacked and beaten to death after being accused by her family members in Ajmer district of the state.
yor: Lára èyí ni, ọmọbìnrin ogójì ọdún kan Kanya Devi rí ìkọlù tí a sì lù ú pa lẹ́yìn tí mọ̀lẹ́bíi rẹ̀ fi ẹ̀sùn kàn án ní agbègbèe Ajmer.

en: Victims and Survivors

en: But after a press release issued by the country's Institute of Marine Affairs (IMA) on August 22, 2019, in which it warned that — based on findings from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Coral Reef Watch — Tobago's coral reefs have been placed on a watch for "Bleaching Alert Level One", all eyes are on the island.

en: Corals coexist with and become home to symbiotic algae, helping it store nutrients and remove waste.

en: According to local coral reef ecologist Anjani Ganase, the main contributors to coral bleaching in Tobago are the warmer water temperatures — a result of climate change.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí onímọ̀ àyíká ìbílẹ̀ Anjani Ganase ti ṣe ṣàlàyé, ọ̀dádá tí ó dá ìpàwọ̀dà iyùn-un Tobago ni ìwọ̀n ìgbóná omi tí ó re òkè — tí í ṣe arapa àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́.
mt0: According to the anthropologist Anjani Ganase, the cause of the islands' existence is the rising waters of the island - which are a cause of climate change.

en: Via email, Ganase explained that the ocean absorbs much of the heat in the atmosphere, which in turn causes the water — especially shallower bodies of water, like the Caribbean Sea — to heat up.
yor: Nínú ímeèlì, Ganase ṣàlàyé wípé òkun máa ń fa èyí tí ó pọ̀ nínú ooru inú afẹ́fẹ́ mu, tí ó sì ń fa kí omi — pàápàá jù lọ àwọn ibú omi jínjìn gbungbunrungbun bíi Ọ̀sàa Caribbean — ó gbóná janjan.
mt0: In e-mail, Ganase explained that the ocean is causing the highest temperatures in the summer, which causes the water to boil, particularly in tropical areas like the Caribbean.

en: In fact, NOAA's 12-week outlook extends well past Tobago to the reefs of the Lesser Antilles.

en: It is one thing that I was not given a visa to attend the summit, another is that the huge scholarship grant to attend the summit went down the drain, wasted.
yor: Ìṣòro kan ni ti àìrí ìwé ìrìnnà gbà, òmíràn ni ti owó ìrìnàjò ọ̀fẹ́ gọbọi tí ó wọlẹ̀ nítori n kò le è lọ si àpérò.
mt0: One problem is the lack of travel experience, another is the lack of free travel tickets because I can't go to the airport.

en: I am miserable because I have not been able to refund the scholarship due to the Central Bank of Nigeria’s policy on wire transfers.
yor: Ìbànújẹ́ gba ọkàn mi poo látàríi àlàálẹ̀ Ilé-Ìfowópamọ́ Àgbà orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà tí kò mú ìfowó ránṣẹ́ sí òkè òkun rọrùn; n kò le è dá owó ìrìnàjò ọ̀fẹ́ tí ó pọn dandan láti dá padà padà fún àwọn tí ó ni owó.
mt0: I was very disappointed with the attitude of the Central Bank of Nigeria which does not send letters to the coast easily; I can't afford to refund the free travel tickets that are required to be refunded to those with money.

en: It is excruciatingly painful that my right to associate as a free citizen of the global village was violated.
yor: Ó dùn mí wọ akínyẹmí ara wípé wọ́n gbẹ́sẹ̀ lé ẹ̀tọ́ọ mi gẹ́gẹ́ bí olómìnira láti darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ̀ mi.
mt0: I'm glad to see that they continued to follow me as a volunteer to join my fellow soldiers.

en: I was stripped of my voice!
yor: Wọ́n pa ohùn mọ́ mi lẹ́nu!
mt0: I heard a noise!

en: For Africans traveling within Africa: A painful irony
yor: Ìṣòro: Fún àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò nínúu Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀
mt0: Problem: For those students who are traveling in the United States, simply say you don't know.

en: It’s difficult for Africans to travel outside Africa — but it can be equally grim to travel within the continent.
yor: Ó ṣòro fún ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ láti ṣe ìrìnàjò jáde kúrò ní Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ — ṣùgbọ́n bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ó nira láti ṣe ìrìnàjò nílẹ̀ náà.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know It's difficult for a foreigner to leave the United States - but it's also difficult to travel there.

en: Citizens of many countries in the global North can travel to most Africa countries visa-free, or with few restrictions, but the majority of Africans need visas to travel to over half of the other African countries.
yor: Àwọn ọmọ onílùú àìmọye orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wà ní Àríwá àgbáńlá ayé lè ṣe ìrìnàjò lọ sí ọ̀pọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè ní ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ láì ní ìwé ìrìnnà, tàbí pẹ̀lú hìhámọ́ tí ò tó nǹkan, àmọ́ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ni ó nílòo ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú láti ṣe ìrìnàjò sí ìdajì àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó kù.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: Nigerian Global Voices contributor Rosemary Ajayi captures the "struggle of Africans traveling within Africa":
yor: Aládàásí Ohùn Àgbáyé ọmọbíbí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà Rosemary Àjàyí ṣe àpèjúwe "ìlàkàkà àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò ní àárín ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ ":
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: I am happy that we, and many others, are highlighting the challenges Africans face getting Western visas.
yor: Inúu mi dùn nítorí wípé à ń gbé ọ̀ràn ohun tí ojú àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ máa ń rí ní wọ́n bá béèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà wọ Orílẹ̀-èdè òyìnbó àti ohun ti ó tan mọ́ ọn yè wò.
mt0: I am happy that we are helping students understand what they see in their eyes when they ask for a visa to a foreign country and what they are looking for.

en: This doesn't annoy me as much as the struggles of Africans travelling within Africa.
yor: Èyí kò gbé mi lọ́kàn bíi ti ìlàkàkà àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò nínúu ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: This didn't surprise me like the advice of foreigners who are traveling in the world.

en: At RightsCon in Tunis, and GlobalFact in Cape Town, I took the time to ask Africans if they had needed visas.
yor: Ní RightsCon tí ó wáyé ní Tunis, àti GlobalFact tí ó wáyé ní Cape Town, mo bi àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ bóyá wọ́n ti nílòo ìwé ìrìnnà.
mt0: In RightsCon in Tunis and GlobalFact in Cape Town, I asked students whether they needed travel documentation.

en: Just this weekend, I learnt of a Nigerian journalist who was unable to attend GlobalFact because he didn't have a visa.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ ìsinmi tí a wà yìí, mo gbọ́ wípé oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn ọmọ Nàìjíríà kan kò le è wà níbí GlobalFact nítorí wípé kò ní ìwé ìrìnnà.
mt0: In the days leading up to this holiday, I heard that a Nigerian journalist could not be on GlobalFact because he doesn't have a visa.

en: Let's not talk about how most of the African delegates at RightsCon had to fly out of Africa first, in order to get to Tunis.
yor: Kí a máà sọ ti àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó fò kúrò nílẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kí wọn ó tó lè wọ Tunis.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Last month, I met an East African journalist applying for a visa to Nigeria. He was asked to supply the driver's license of the professional driver picking him up from the airport!
yor: Ní oṣù ti ó kojá, mo ṣe alábàápàdé oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn tí ó wá láti Ìlà-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà wọ Nàìjíríà. Wọ́n ní kí ó pèsèe ìwé-ẹ̀rí ìwákọ̀ọ ti akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ awakọ̀ tí yóò wá gbé e bí ó bá balẹ̀ ní pápá-ọkọ̀-òfuurufú!
mt0: In the month before he died, I met a reporter from the Eastern Hemisphere who asked for a visa to Nigeria. They asked him to provide proof of a driver's license if he was in a car accident!

en: As Rosemary points out, intra-continental travel is often further complicated by having to travel out of the continent in order to reach a destination within Africa.
yor: Bí Rosemary ti sọ, ìrìnàjò nínúu ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ máa ń gba ṣíṣèrìnàjò kúrò ní ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kí aṣèrìnàjò ó tó le è dé ibi tí ó ń lọ ní àárín Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: As Rosemary said, traveling in the tropics often requires travellers to leave the tropics to get to the surrounding areas.

en: At the International Air Transport Association (IATA) regional aviation forum in Accra in June, Ghana's Vice President, Dr. Mahamudu Bawumia lamented the fact that “a business person from Freetown [Sierra Leone], for example, should travel for nearly two days to go to Banjul (often through a third country) for a journey which a straight-line flight would have taken only one hour.”
yor: Ní ibi àpérò òṣìṣẹ́ ọkọ̀-òfuurufú agbègbè tí Àjọ Ìgbókègbódò Ọkọ̀-òfuurufú Àgbáyé (IATA) gbé kalẹ̀ tí ó wáyé ní Accra nínúu oṣù Òkúdù, Igbákejì Ààrẹ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Ghana, Oníṣègùn Mahamudu Bawumia pohùnréré-ẹkún látàríi wípé “ó yẹ oníṣòwò láti Freetown [Sierra Leone], fún àpẹẹrẹ, láti ṣe ìrìnàjò fún ọjọ́ méjì gbáko láti lọ sí Banjul (nípasẹ̀ẹ orílẹ̀-èdè kẹ́ta) fún ìrìnàjò tí kò ju wákàtí kan lọ.“
mt0: In a meeting of regional aviation officials held in Accra in October, the Ghanaian Prime Minister, Mr. Mahamudu Bawumia, rejected the IATA's recommendation that "travellers from Freetown [Sierra Leone], for example, should travel for two days to Banjul (through a third country) for a short trip."

en: The convoluted flight routes are then compounded by the extraordinarily high cost of air travel within the continent.
yor: Ìpòyì lórí òfuurufú náà gbọ́mọ pọn pẹ̀lú owó kanangú fífò lókè láàárín Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: If you can't translate the currency simply say you don't know.

en: Is it true that Africans are unlikely to return home?
yor: Ǹjẹ́ òtítọ́ ni wípé ó ṣeéṣe kí Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ó máà padà wálé?
mt0: Is it true that the Son of God can return?

en: A rescue operation off the Canary Islands in 2006.
