en: Between 2010-2017, migrants from sub-Saharan African countries accounted for the largest migrant population in the world after Syria.
yor: Ni àárín-n ọdún-un 2010-2017, àwọn aṣípòkiri láti àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wà lábẹ́ Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara ni ó ṣepò tí ó tẹ̀lé Syria gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìlú tí ó ní ènìyàn tó pọ̀ jù nínú àwọn aṣípòkiri lágbàáyé.
mt0: In the period 2010-2017, refugees from Eritrea and Ethiopia took over as the second largest refugee population in the world.

en: Many Africans leave the countries fleeing poverty or violent conflict, to seek asylum, refugee status or permanent residence in North America or Europe.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ń sá kúrò nílùú nítorí ebi àti rògbòdìyàn, láti wábi forípamọ́síeek, didi ogúnlémidébí tàbí didi agbélùú ní Àréwá Amẹ́ríkà tàbí ní Éróòpù.
mt0: Many students leave the country because of poverty and research, to apply for a job, to become a nurse or to become a doctor in the United States or Europe.

en: A 2018 Pew Research study reports that the number of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa "grew by 50% or more between 2010 and 2017, significantly more than the 17% worldwide average increase for the same period".
yor: Àbájáde Ìwádìí Pew ọdún-un 2018 sọ wípé iye àwọn aṣípòkiri láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara "ti fi ìdá 50 lọ sókè tàbí jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ ní àárín-in ọdún-un 2010 àti 2017, ju gbogbo rẹ̀ lọ wọn ju ìdá 17 lọ káríayé ní àsìkò kan náà".
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. The Pew Report of 2018 says that the number of migrants from the Sahara "has halved or gone down by 50 percent between 2010 and 2017 compared to the same period last year, which is 17 percent higher than the same period last year."

en: Sub-Saharan Africans are also emigrating to countries far and wide.
yor: Awọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó wá láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara náà ń ṣí kiri orílẹ̀-èdè jákèjádò àgbáyé.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: In 2014, over 170,000 migrants without legal documents ferried across the Mediterranean Sea to Italy.
yor: Ní ọdún-un 2014, ó tó aṣíkiri 170,000 tí ò ní ìwé-àṣẹ lábẹ́ òfin ni ó ń wọ ọkọ̀ gba orí òkun Mediterranean lọ sí orílẹ̀-èdè Italy.
mt0: In 2014, 170,000 illegal immigrants took the Mediterranean Sea to Italy without a license.

en: Many hailed from sub-Saharan Africa.
yor: Ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ló wá láti àwọn Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara.
mt0: The word comes from the cities of the Sahara Desert.

en: In December 2018, Brazilian police rescued 25 sub-Saharan African nationals who had “been at sea for over a month” in the Atlantic Ocean.
yor: Ní oṣù Ọ̀pẹ ọdún-un 2018, Ọlọ́pàá Brazil dóòlà ẹ̀mí èèyàn 25 ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó wá láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara "tí ó ti wà lọ́rí omi òkun Atlantic fún oṣù kan gbáko".
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know In October 2018, the Brazilian police rescued 25 children from the Saharan Peninsula "after a month in the Atlantic Ocean."

en: The travelers had paid “hundreds of dollars apiece” for the trip from Cape Verde. In June 2019, US Customs and Border Protection in Del Rio, Texas, USA, arrested more than 500 Africans from Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, and Angola, for trying to cross into the USA via the Rio Grande River.
yor: Àwọn arìnrìnàjòó san "ẹgbẹlẹmùkù owó lọ́wọ́ ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan" fún ìrìnàjò láti Cape Verde. Ní oṣù Òkúdù ọdún-un 2019, US Customs Àjọ Aṣọ́bodè àti Ààbò Ibodè US ní Del Rio, Texas, USA, fi ọwọ́ọ ṣìkún òfin mú àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ 500 tí ó wà láti Ilẹ̀-olómìnira Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, àti Angola, tí wọn ń fẹ́ gba omi Odò Rio Grande wọ USA.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know

en: While dominant narratives in the media perpetuate Africa as a continent of mass migration driven by poverty or violent conflict, however, Marie-Laurence Flahaux and Hein De Haas, scholars from University of Oxford and University of Amsterdam, respectively, take issue with this stereotype.
yor: Onírúurú ìròyìn ni ó ti rò ó wípé Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ ni àárín-ín gbùngùn òtòṣì àti ogun, síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, Marie-Laurence Flahaux àti Hein De Haas, àwọn onímọ̀ láti Ifásitì ti Oxford àti Ifásitì ti Amsterdam, ní ṣísẹ̀ntèlé, kò gbà pé bẹ́ẹ̀ ní ó rí.
mt0: In reports it is believed that the Empire was a frontier between democracy and war, but Marie-Laurence Flahaux and Hein De Haas, academics from Oxford University and Amsterdam University, in particular, did not believe that.

en: Flahaux and De Haas argue that these narratives are propagated not only by "media and politicians" but also by scholars.
yor: Flahaux àti De Haas jiyàn wípé kò rí bí ìròyín ti ṣe rò ó sí etígbọ̀ọ́ ọmọ aráyé pàápàá "àwọn ilé iṣẹ́ àti olóṣòlú" àti àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n náà.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know Flahaux and De Haas believe that the report does not indicate that he is a scholar, especially "the employers and the academics."

en: Their research shows that migration from the continent is multi-layered and driven by global "processes of development and social transformation" that have increased the "capabilities and aspirations" of Africans’ to migrate — similar to migrants from other parts of the world.
yor: Iṣẹ́ ìwádìí fi yé wípé àwọn ìṣípòkiri láti Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kò déédéé wáyé, ohun tí ó fà á ni "ìlànà ìdàgbàsókè àti ìyípadà àwùjọ" èyí tí ó ń mú ṣíṣíkiri lọ sí àwọn agbègbè àgbáyé wu Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ — tí kò yàtọ̀ sí aṣípòkiri láti ibòmìíràn lágbàáyé.
mt0: Research has shown that migration from the United States is not a regular occurrence, which he calls "the expansion and redistribution of the society" which causes migration to foreign countries - which is not different from migration from other countries in the world.

en: These stereotypical narratives, however, often inform visa policy:
yor: Àwọn ìròyìn abanilórúkọjẹ́ wọ̀nyí, ni ó ń fa sábàbí ìlànà-iṣẹ́ ìwé ìrìnnà:
mt0: These rumors are either a cause of travel advice or a cause of travel advice:

en: Most countries’ authorities assume that all Africans who travel will not return to their home countries, leaving African visa applicants to bear the burden of proof.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè ni ó nígbàgbọ́ wípé gbogbo arìnrìnàjò tí ó bá jẹ́ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ni kò ní padà sí orílẹ̀-èdèe rẹ̀, àfi bí arìnrìnàjó bá ní ẹ̀rí tí ó yanrantí tó ni ó lè rí ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú gbà.
mt0: Many countries believe that all travellers who are citizens of a foreign country will never return to their country, provided the traveller has a valid proof of departure.

en: Getting non-African nations to take a more nuanced approach to visa approvals for African nationals is a long battle.
yor: Kò rọrùn láti ṣí ojú àwọn tí kì í ṣe ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ lójú nípa orúkọ búburú tí wọn ti sọ orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wá láti Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know It's hard to get anyone who is not a Dutchman to recognize a country that comes from the Netherlands by using a false name.

en: Meanwhile, African nations can take action to improve mobility across the continent.
yor: Níbàyìí, àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ níṣẹ́ láti ṣe sí ètò lílọ-àti-bíbọ̀ àwọn ọmọadúláwọ̀. Ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà kan ṣoṣo fún gbogbo orílẹ̀-èdè ní Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ jẹ́ ọ̀nà àbáyọ — àmọ́ kò tó.
mt0: Now, the European countries have to make a passport-free admission policy. A single passport for all countries in the European Union is a means of warning — but not enough.

en: A common African passport is one step  — but it's not enough. The Single African Air Transport market (SAATM), and the Continental Free Trade Agreement, both launched last year, have laid the foundation for some of these shifts, but widespread implementation is still a long way off.
yor: Single African Air Transport market náà (SAATM), àti Continental Free Trade Agreement náà, tí a fi lọ́lẹ̀ lọ́dún tí ó kọjá, ti se àlàálẹ̀ ìgbésẹ̀ wọ̀nyí, ṣùgbọ́n ìmúṣẹ ṣì kù díẹ̀ káàtó.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know. The Single African Air Transport Market (SAATM) and the Continental Free Trade Agreement, which was signed last year, have established these markets, but there are still a few restrictions.

en: Meanwhile, as an African, to dare to travel is to be subjected to cruel humiliations when travelling outside Africa — or to be jolted out of the fantasy of African unity by the harshness of travelling within the continent.
yor: Lásìkò yìí, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀, ìyànjú láti rìnrìnàjò ni láti ní ìrírí ìrẹnisílẹ̀ tí àwọn tí ó ń se ìrìnàjò lọ sí òkè-òkun ń rí — tàbí jẹ́ títají nínú àlà ìsọ̀kan Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ tí kò sí.
mt0: However, as the Navigator, the desire to travel is to experience the thrills of those who travel to the coasts — or to be a tourist in the exclusive territory of the Navigator.

en: Either way the visa gods demand more sacrifices, while remaining adamantly intransigent.
yor: Èyí kéyìí tí ò báà jẹ́, òòsà ìwé ìrìnnà ń béèrè ẹbọ sí i, tí kọ̀ sì yé é gbẹbọ.
mt0: If you can't translate this, simply say you don't know.

en: This story is the first in a two-part series on online ethnic hate speech, disinformation and propaganda during the 2019 Nigeria elections.

yor: Túwíìtì ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà kan (Àwòrán 3) Bashir El-Rufai, ọmọ Aláṣẹ Ìpínlẹ̀ Kaduna, wí pé ẹ̀yà Igbo ló fi ìbínú tan iná ọ̀tẹ̀ tí ó fa Ogun Abẹ́lée Nàìjíríà.
mt0: A telegraph (Photo 3) Bashir El-Rufai, a member of the Kaduna State Council, said the Igbo people started the fire that started the Nigerian Civil War.

en: Between 1967 and 1970, Nigeria fought a bitter civil war with the secessionist state of Biafra inhabited mostly by the Igbo in the southeastern part of the country.
yor: Láàárín 1967 sí 1970, orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ja ogun kíkorò kan pẹ̀lú ìlúu Biafra tí í ṣe àwọn ẹ̀yà Igbo tí ó wà ní apá ìlà-oòrùn gúúsù, tí ó ń gbèrò láti pín yà kúrò lábẹ́ ìṣàkóso ìjọba Nàìjíríà.
mt0: In 1967 to 1970, Nigeria fought a civil war with Biafra, a group of Igbo people in the northeast of the country, seeking to separate itself from the Nigerian government.

en: Hence, according to Bashir El-Rufai, the result of the 2019 elections which was won by his party, the APC, should also be taken as a sweet "revenge" from the Hausa, Fulani.
yor: Síbẹ̀, gẹ́gẹ́ bí Bashir El-Rufai ti ṣe sọ, àbájáde ìbò ọdún-un 2019 tí ẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀, APC, gbégbà-orókè. Ó yẹ kí a rí i bíi “ẹ̀san” láti apá ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn ẹ̀yà Hausa, Fulani.
mt0: However, as Bashir El-Rufai has said, the announcement of the 2019 election by his party, APC, was a "mistake" from the Hausa, Fulani side.

en: He later apologized, after a backlash, for his previous "insensitive" tweet as shown in Figure 4.
yor: Ó padà wá á tọrọ àforíjì, lẹ́yìn tí a ti bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lù ú, fún túwíìtì "tí ó lè dá wàhálà sílẹ̀ " bí a ti rí i nínú Àwòrán.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: He also deleted the earlier tweet (Figure 3).
yor: Bákan náà ni ó mú túwíìtì ìsọkúsọ náà wálẹ̀ (Àwòrán 3).
mt0: He also took the screenshot of the debate (Figure 3).

en: Ethnic-motivated false information on social media during the elections falls into two categories: disinformation and propaganda.
yor: Ìròyìn irọ́ tí ó ti ara ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà wá lórí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà lásìkò ìbò ṣe é pín sábẹ́ ẹ̀ka méjì: ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú àti ìròyìn irọ́.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. Fake news on the internet without a poll can be divided into two categories: Fake news and Fake news.

en: Miroslav Tudjman and Nives Mikelic, communication scholars at the University of Zagreb, Croatia, define disinformation as "intentionally deputed mistaken information with the purpose to mislead the user".
yor: Miroslav Tudjman àti Nives Mikelic, ọ̀mọ̀wé nípa ìtàkùrọ̀sọ ní Ifáfitì ti Zagreb, Croatia, túmọ̀ ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú sí "ìròyìn àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ tari síta láti ṣi àwọn ènìyàn lọ́kàn".
mt0: If you cannot translate the news simply say you don't know. Miroslav Tudjman and Nives Mikelic, professors of political philosophy at the University of Zagreb, Croatia, translated the rumors as "a rumor spread out to open people up."

en: Hence, the intention to pass across inaccurate, distorted and false evidence as true, distinguishes dis-information from misinformation.
yor: Ète títari ìròyìn irọ́ síta bí òtítọ́, ló ya ìròyìn tí ó ń ṣini lọ́kàn àti ìròyìn irọ́ sọ́tọ́.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Tudjman and Mikelic assert that propaganda is much more than disinformation or misinformation.
yor: Tudjman àti Mikelic sọ wípé ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn fẹ̀jú ju ìròyìn àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ tari síta láti ṣini lọ́kàn tàbí ìròyìn irọ́ lọ.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. Tudjman and Mikelic said that the narrative style is more interesting than the narrative style of a newspaper reporting a few weeks before a deadline or a newspaper report.

en: This is because propaganda "aims to manipulate the attitudes of the user" through an "accidental or intentional handling with information in [the] communication process".
yor: Ìdí ni pé ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn "máa ń yí ìhùwàsí ẹni padà" nípasẹ̀ "ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àìròtẹ́lẹ̀ kan tàbí ìgbésẹ̀ àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ dá lásìkò ìtari ìtàkùrọ̀sọ [náà] síta".
mt0: Because the narrative style "returns the audience's response" through "a narrative event or activity based on the interpretation of the critical message [that] is given".

en: Thus, propaganda weaponizes biased or inaccurate information for political interests and consequently manipulates perception.
yor: Bí irú èyí, ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn máa ń tẹ̀sí apá kan tàbí àìpé ìròyìn fún àǹfààní ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú àti yíyí ìrònú padà níparí.
mt0: As a result, the narrative often goes on one side or the narrative offers the opportunity to explain a particular issue and return the conversation to the original.

en: Justifiable fears emerged surrounding 2019 elections because online disinformation and propaganda incites electoral violence but also poses "a threat to reconciliation after the elections".
yor: Ìbẹ̀rùbojo ọkàn bẹ́ sílẹ̀ látàrí ìbò ọdún-un 2019 nítorí ìròyìn irọ́ àti ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn ń ṣe àgbédìde àìbalẹ̀ ọkàn tí ó ti ọ̀rọ̀ ìbò bẹ̀rẹ̀ àmọ́ tí ó ń fa "ìdẹ́rùbà fún ìparí-ìjà tí ìbòó bá kásẹ̀ ńlẹ̀ ".
mt0: If you cannot translate, just say you don't know. The emotional turmoil started in 2019 because of the rumors and reports that started the campaign but which cause "anxiety for a political victory if the election is over."

en: Part II of this essay will examine how this played out online, especially on Twitter, with specific examples.
yor: Apá kejì àròkọ yìí yóò ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò bí èyí ṣe wáyé lórí ayélujára, pàápàá lóríi gbàgede Twitter, pẹ̀lú àwọn àpẹẹrẹ mélòó kan.
mt0: The second part of this article will look at how this happens on the internet, particularly on Twitter, with two examples.

en: This article is part of a series of posts examining interference with digital rights through methods such as network shutdowns and disinformation during key political events in seven African countries: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.
yor: Àpilẹ̀kọ yìí jẹ́ ara àtẹ̀jádé ìròyìn oníṣísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé tí ó ń ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ìṣúsí pẹ̀lú ẹ̀tọ́ ìlò ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá nípa àwọn ìlànà bíi ìṣánpa ìṣàsopọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere àti ìròyìn ẹlẹ́jẹ̀ lásìkò ètò ìṣèlú tí ó pọn dandan ní orílẹ̀-èdè méje ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nàìjíríà, Tunisia, Uganda, àti Zimbabwe.
mt0: This article is a summary of a technical report that examines the technological differences between traditional and innovative ways of using technology, such as the implementation of innovative technologies and the reporting of violence within the framework of a constitutional system in the following countries: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.

en: The project is funded by the Africa Digital Rights Fund of The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA).

en: On December 26, 2019, BBC Swahili released a video featuring Francisco Ouma, an elder from Busia, western Kenya, who received a message from God to carve a cave.

en: The message came in the form of a map that he received through his dreams.

en: Throughout history, many have questioned the veracity of divine intervention through dreams, even casting doubt on one's mental health and stability.

en: Ethiopia's underground wedding chapels

en: In southern Ethiopia, a similar testimony exists from an elder named Mohammed Yiso Banatah, who said back in 2012 that he was visited by Allah 33 years ago in a series of ten dreams.
yor: Ní gúúsù Ethiopia, ẹ̀rí tí ó jọra á wá láti àgbàlagbà kan tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Mohammed Yiso Banatah, tí ó ní lọ́dún-un 2012 wípé Allah yọ sí òun ní ọdún 33 sẹ́yìn lójú àlá lẹ́ẹ̀mẹwàá ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀.
mt0: In Ethiopia, a similar evidence came from a prophet named Mohammed Yiso Banatah, who claimed in 2012 that Allah had wiped out him 33 years later on two different occasions.

en: Through the dreams, he received explicit instructions from Allah to ultimately create underground wedding chapel caves.
yor: Lójú àwọn àlá náà, ó gbọ́ ohùn-un Allah láti gbẹ́ ihò ilé Ọlọ́run fún ètò ìgbéyàwó nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀.
mt0: Through the walls of the temple, he heard Allah's voice to burn the temple's chamber for the marriage plan in the ground.

en: Known as Dunbar Caves, these elaborate chapels exist on Banatah's roadside property halfway between Hawassa and Shashamene.
yor: Ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ẹ Dunbar ni a mọ̀ ọ́ sí, ilé Ọlọ́run fẹ̀nfẹ̀ wọ̀nyí wà ní ẹ̀bá ọ̀nàa Banatah tí í ṣe ìlàjì ọ̀nàa Hawassa àti Shashamene.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. The cave in the bottom of Dunbar is known as the Holy Temple, which is located in the eastern part of the province of Banatah and is the border of the provinces of Hawassa and Shashamene.

en: Banatah said it was in his third dream that the blueprint for these chapel caves was burned into his consciousness.
yor: Banatah sọ wípé nínú àláa rẹ̀ kẹ́ta ni ó ti rí àwòṣe fún àwọn ilé Ọlọ́run wọ̀nyí.
mt0: Banatah says that in his third book he found a painting of the temples.

en: In his final dream, the tenth one in a series back in 1979, a man appeared in his dream who took Mohammed to a small tree on his property and pointed to its roots.
yor: Lójú àláa àsèkágbáa rẹ̀, èyí tí ó jẹ́ ìkẹwàá nínú àkọsílẹ̀ oníṣísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé ọdún-un 1979, ọkùnrin kan fara hàn tí ó mú Mohammed lọ sí ibi igi kékeré kan nínúu ọgbàa rẹ̀, ó sì tọ́ka sí egbòo rẹ̀.
mt0: In 1979, during the earthquake, a man appeared to have taken Mohammed to a small tree in his garden, and pointed to his grave.

en: The man showed him exactly where to start digging and told him that his life would depend on it.
yor: Ọkùnrin náà fi ojú ibi tí yóò ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ìwalẹ̀, ó sì tún sọ fún un pé lórí iṣẹ́ ìwalẹ̀ náà ni yóò ti là.
mt0: The man pointed out the place where the earthquake would begin, and told him that the earthquake was already started.

en: At midnight, he saw visions of gold.
yor: Ní ọ̀gànjọ́, ó ríran rí wúrà.

en: Surroundings up close appeared far away and objects farthest away were pulled up close to him.

en: The next day, when he woke up, he began to dig into the earth with his bare hands.

mt0: On the second day, when he was ready to go to bed, he started to breathe with his own hand without using the torch.

en: These sunlight-flooded caves have been somewhat of a tourist attraction where people stop, pay a modest fee, and tour the quiet stillness at least four meters underground.

en: The architectural genius of these spaces reveals the finery and steadiness of Mohammed’s hand – he’s spent careful hours carving, smoothing, cutting, digging, and designing an intricate series of archways, cosy nooks and hidden rooms within rooms, some that have been furnished with soft mattresses and simple earth-slab shelves, while others are stark and cool with tiny, rounded windows flooding through with secret rays of sunlight appearing out of nowhere.

en: This story is the second in a two-part series on online ethnic hate speech, disinformation and propaganda during the 2019 Nigeria elections.

en: In Nigeria, social media has a history of enabling ethnocentric disinformation and propaganda during elections.
yor: Ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, àwùjọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ orí ayélujára jẹ́ ibi tí ìròyìn ìtakora-ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin àti ìsọkiri ti máa ń gbilẹ̀ bíi ṣẹ́lẹ̀rú lásìkò ìdìbò.
mt0: In Nigeria, the internet community is a place where political corruption and corruption are often reported as a routine occurrence during the election season.

en: During the 2015 elections, Twitter Nigeria descended into a bitter and binary sparring match between supporters of the then-two major contestants, Goodluck Jonathan (PDP, an Ijaw Christian) and Muhammadu Buhari (APC, a Hausa, Fulani Muslim).
yor: Ní àsìkò ìdìbò ọdún-un 2015, Twitter Nàìjíríà kó sí ìjà àti ìsọ̀rọ̀-takora láàárín àwọn alátilẹyìn olùdíje-dupò méjèèjì tí ó lérò lẹ́yìn jù lọ lásìkò náà, ìyẹn Goodluck Jonathan (ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ẹ PDP tí ó jẹ́ kìrìsìtẹ́nì àti ọmọ Ijaw) àti Muhammadu Buhari (ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ APC tí ó jẹ́ Mùsùlùmí àti ọmọ Hausa-Fulani).
mt0: In the Nigerian presidential election of 2015, Twitter Nigeria created a row and debate between two leading candidates, Goodluck Jonathan (a Christian and Ijaw) and Muhammadu Buhari (a Muslim and a Hausa-Fulani).

mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: A 2019 study by Dani Madrid-Morales, University of Huston and Herman Wasserman, University of Cape Town concluded that "mis- and disinformation campaigns have been used to influence political agendas" in Nigeria, Kenya and South Africa.
yor: Ìwádìí ọdún-un 2019 kan láti ọwọ́ Dani Madrid-Morales ní Ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga Huston àti Herman Wasserman ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga Cape Town fẹnukò pé "ìròyìn irọ́ àti ìròyìn ayédèrú ni wọ́n ti máa ń lò láti fi mú ìfẹ́-inú àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ" ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, Kenya àti South Africa.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. A 2019 study by Dani Madrid-Morales at the University of Huston and Herman Wasserman at the University of Cape Town found that "rumors and rumors of a world affair are often used to lure political activists" in Nigeria, Kenya and South Africa.

en: The high exposure to disinformation in social media especially during electoral campaigns, leads to a "distrust" among social media users "because that's where they find 'fake news' most often", Madrid-Morales asserted.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀ Ìròyìn ayédèrú lórí àwọn àwùjọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ orí ayélujára pàápàá lásìkò ìpolongo ìbò máa ń fa "àìgbara-eni-gbọ́ " láàárín àwọn tí wọ́n ń lo àwùjọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ orí ayélujára "nítorí pé ibẹ̀ ni wọ́n ti ń rí 'ìròyìn ayédèrú' lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà", Madrid-Morales sọ̀rọ̀.

en: My ethnographic study between October 28, 2018, and May 29, 2019, that covered the 2019 Nigerian elections held on February 23 (to elect a president and a national assembly), and March 9 (to elect governors and state houses of assembly) revealed two major categories of false information: ethnocentric driven disinformation and political propaganda.
yor: Ìwádìí mi lórí onírúurú ẹ̀yà láàárín ọjọ́ 28, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2018 àti ọjọ́ 29 oṣù Èbìbí, ọdún-un 2019 lórí ìdìbò ọdún-un 2019 lórílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà tó wáyé ní ọjọ́ 23, oṣù Èrèlé (láti dìbò yan ààrẹ àti aṣòfin sí ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ti orílẹ̀-èdè) àti ọjọ́ 9, oṣù Erénà (láti yan gómìnà àti aṣòfin sí ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ti ìjọba ìpínlẹ̀) ṣe àfihàn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ìròyìn ayédèrú méjì pàtàkì kan: ìròyìn ayédèrú tó tako ẹ̀yà kan àti ìsọkiri láti mú èrò inú àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ.

en: For instance, Jubril A. Gawat recently appointed as Lagos State's senior special assistant on new media tweeted that (Figure 3) a vote for opposition candidate Atiku Abubakar "is a vote for Igbo".

en: Nigeria is a country where ethnic identities run deep.
yor: Nàìjíríà jẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè kan tí ọ̀rọ̀ ẹ̀yà ti rinlẹ̀ gan-an.

en: These divisions are usually exploited during elections by politicians because of the obvious need to pitch their opponents into opposing camps of "we" versus "them".

en: Hence, the allegations that Obi deported northerners was meant to re-ignite the ethnic animosities between the Igbo and Hausa, Fulani that led to the Nigerian Civil War.

en: Located in southeastern Nigeria, the breakaway Republic of Biafra, which lasted for three years through a bitter civil war between 1967 to 1970, is largely populated by the Igbo.
yor: Ẹ̀yà tó wà ní Gúúsù-ìwọ̀ oòrùn Nàìjíríà, tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wọn jẹ́ ọmọ Igbo gbìyànjú láti ya kúrò lára orílẹ̀-èdè nípasẹ̀ ogun abẹ́lé tí ó wáyé fún ọdún mẹ́ta láàárín ọdún 1967 sí 1970.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. The people of northern Nigeria, mostly Igbo, tried to escape the country through a three-year civil war between 1967 and 1970.

en: Thus, Figure 3 proclamation that "a vote for Atiku is a vote for Igbo..."  was aimed to revive the ghost of the acrimonious ethnic hatred that pitched Hausa against Igbo.
yor: Fún ìdí èyí, wọ́n ní í lọ́kàn láti lo àkọsílẹ̀ inú atọ́ka 3 tí ó sọ pé "Ìbò kan fún Atiku jẹ́ ibo fún ẹ̀yà Igbo..." fi jí òkú ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin tí ó ti wà láàárín ẹ̀yà Hausa àti Igbo.

en: In 2019 elections, this meant that Atiku is a supporter of the Igbo who had once tried to break away from Nigeria.

en: However, by the evening of February 13, Ballard Partners refuted the said survey (Figure 7) which they described as "fraudulent" and maintained that they had not "conducted any survey research on behalf of the People’s Democratic Party of Nigeria".

mt0: But on the 13th of October, Ballard Partners announced that they did not find such a finding (Figure 7) which they referred to as "a ghost", and claimed that they did not "do any research for the PDP Party".

en: Ose Anenih, a PDP supporter reported some of the APC Twitter sympathizers who circulated the fake poll to the Twitter handle of the Nigerian police and the Independent Electoral Commission, the electoral umpire, for "criminally and illegally" trying to "interfere with free and fair elections".

en: The many lies of a presidential aide

mt0: Part 8: A photo of Lauretta Onochie, by Lauretta Onochie, who was a consultant to the president.

en: On December 4, 2018, Lauretta Onochie, presidential aide to Buhari [then incumbent presidential candidate]  tweeted (Figure 8) a picture with food and 500 naira notes that was purportedly shared with the crowd that attended Abubakar's presidential rally in Sokoto in northwest Nigeria, the previous day.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 4, oṣù Ọ̀pẹ, ọdún-un 2018 Lauretta Onochie, tí ó jẹ́ olùrànlọ́wọ́ fún Buhari [tí ó jẹ́ òǹdíje-dupò ààrẹ lásìkò náà] túwíìtì (Atọ́ka 8) àwòrán kan pẹ̀lú oúnjẹ àti owóo náírà 500 tí wọ́n ní wọ́n pín fún àwọn èrò lọ́jọ́ kejì ìrìnde ìpolongo ìdìbò fún Abubakar gẹ́gẹ́ bí ààrẹ ní Sokoto, apá àríwá-ìlà oòrùn orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ní àná ọjọ́ náà.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know On April 4, 2018, Lauretta Onochie, a former aide to Buhari [who was the candidate for president in the election] tweeted (Page 8) a picture of food and money given to citizens on the second day of the announcement of Abubakar as president in Sokoto, north-east Nigeria on the same day.

en: Onochie's allegations were completely false. In fact, the picture she shared "was taken in February 2017" at an event unrelated to "electioneering", Chuba Ugwu pointed out in a reply to her tweet.
yor: Irọ́ pátápátá ni àwọn ẹ̀sùn Onochie. Kódà, níbi òde kan tí kò tan mọ́ “ọ̀rọ̀ ìdìbò” ni a ti ya àwòrán náà nínú “oṣù Èrèlé ọdún-un 2017″, Chuba Ugwu tan ìmọ́lẹ̀ sí èyí nínú èsì sí túwíìtì rẹ̀ kan.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know

en: Onochie appears to be a specialist in disseminating falsehoods. The International Centre for Investigative Reporting (ICIR), an online news portal, analysed over 1,000 images shared on Twitter by Onochie between August 1, 2018, and July  31, 2019. The analysis revealed that "in at least 12 cases" Onochie "had used inaccurate pictures".
yor: Onochie jẹ́ ògbóǹtarìgì níbi ká máa ṣe àpínká ìròyìn ayédèrú. Iléeṣẹ́ agbéròyìnjáde orí ayélujára kan tí ó ń ṣe ìwádìí ìjábọ̀ ìròyìn (ICIR), ti ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò àwòrán tó ju 1,000 lọ tí Onochie ti pín sórí Twitter láàárín ọjọ́ 1, oṣù Ògún ọdún-un 2018 àti ọjọ́ 31, oṣù Agẹmọ ọdún-un 2019. Àgbéyẹ̀wò náà fi hàn pé ó kéré tán "ìgbà méjìlá" ni Onochie "ti lo àwòrán tí kò yẹ".
mt0: Onochie is a citizen of the world. An inquiry into the reports of rumors (ICIR) has analyzed more than 1,000 tweets shared by Onochie between October 1, 2018 and August 31, 2019. The inquiry found that Onochie "used images that were not appropriate" for "two weeks."

en: Online hate speech: a crime in Nigeria

en: Section 26 of Nigeria's Cybercrime Act prohibits "use of threats of violence and insulting statements to persons based on race, religion, colour, descent or national or ethnic origin".

mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know Article 26 of the Nigerian Constitution on the Internet states that "the spread of violence and racially abusive language against people for their race, religion, color, assistance, or country."

en: Convicted persons risk a five-year jail term or a fine not less than 10 million nairas [about $28,000 United States dollars] or both.
yor: Àwọn ẹni tí adé ìwà náà bá ṣí mọ́ lórí á fi ẹ̀wọ̀n ọlọ́dún-márùn-ún gbára tàbí kí wọ́n san owó ìtanràn tí kò dín ní ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 10 owóo naira [tí ó ń lọ bí i $28,000] tàbí méjèèjì.

en: In March this year, Enough is Enough Nigeria (EIE), a youth-based movement and Paradigm Initiative (PI), a digital rights policy and advocacy group, instituted a court case in an Abuja court against Onochie and Gbenga Olorunpomi, an aide to Kogi State governor.
yor: Ní oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà ọdún yìí, Enough is Enough Nigeria (EIE), tí ó jẹ́ àkójọpọ̀ àwọn ọ̀dọ́ kan àti Paradigm Initiative (PI), tí ó jẹ́ ẹgbẹ́ aṣòfin àti ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ẹni lórí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá, ṣe ìfilọ́lẹ̀ ìpèlẹ́jọ́ Onochie àti Gbénga Ọlọ́runpomi tí ó jẹ́ olùrànlọ́wọ́ gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀-ẹ Kogi lẹ́jọ́ ní Ilé-ẹjọ́ kan ní Abuja.
mt0: In October this year, Enough is Enough Nigeria (EIE), a group of young people and Paradigm Initiative (PI), a political and activist group, presented a trial of Onochie and Godwin Olubunmi, a former governor of the state of Kogi, in Abuja.

en: The two organisations compiled instances of hate speech "gathered from online comments" made by Onochie and Olorunpomi which they deemed to be in violation of Nigeria’s Cybercrime Act of 2015.
yor: Àjọ méjèèjì yìí "ṣe àkópọ̀ àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ àtakò tí ó jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀ Onochie àti Ọlọ́runpomi lórí ayélujára" tí wọ́n rí i pé ó rú òfin orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà nípa ọ̀ràn orí ayélujára ti 2015.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know. The two organizations "combined offensive words such as Onochie and Godpromi on the internet" which they found to violate Nigerian internet laws in 2015.

en: An army of Twitter warriors propagating falsehoods

en: Most of the instances highlighted above were not mere happenstance. Rather, there was a deliberate and systematic effort to pass off lies as true information.
yor: Púpọ̀ nínú àwọn àpẹẹrẹ tí a ṣe lókè yìí kì í ṣe ohun tí wọn kò mọ̀-ọ́n-mọ̀ ṣe. Wọ́n dìídì gbìyànjú láti ṣe àpínká irọ́ bí i pé òótọ́ ni.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: This is not surprising considering that both APC and PDP engaged an army of online warriors to either "neutralize adverse" social media reports or “fend off” attacks during the campaign periods.
yor: Èyí kò yani lẹ́nu rárá nítorí a rí i pé APC àti PDP ni wọ́n di ajagun orí ayélujára láti lè ṣe "ìmúwálẹ̀ ìjábọ̀ búburú" lórí ayélujára nípa wọn tàbí láti “gbèjà” níbi ìdojúkọ lásìkò ìpolongo ìbò.
mt0: This is not surprising because we see that APC and PDP have become online warriors to "spread false reports" on the internet about them or to "fight" in the classroom during campaigns.

en: Each side engaged "cyber troops" — "government or political party actors tasked with manipulating public opinion online".
yor: Ẹgbẹ́ méjèèjì ni ó ṣe àmúlò "ajagun orí ayélujára" — "àwọn akópa nínú ìjọba tàbí ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú tí wọ́n fún ní iṣẹ́ láti tọwọ́bọ ọpọlọ àwọn ará ìlú láti yí èròo wọn padà lórí ayélujára".
mt0: Two groups are called "cyber warriors" - "academics in government or political organizations who are responsible for turning the minds of the people back on the internet".

en: This year's elections were a repeat of 2015, where both APC and PDP engaged in "disinformation, misinformation, propaganda" campaigns on social media that were "carefully designed to hoodwink the unsuspecting electorate", asserts Eshemokha Austin Maho, a Nigerian media scholar.
yor: Ìdìbò ọdún yìí jẹ́ àṣẹtúnṣe ti 2015, níbi tí APC àti PDP ti kópa nínú ìtànká ìròyìn ayédèrú àti irọ́ pẹ̀lú ìsọkiri láti mú èrò àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ “nínú àwọn ìpolongo wọn lórí àwùjọ ayélujára tí wọ́n “fara balẹ̀ ṣètò láti fi tan àwọn olùdìbò tí kò fura, “báyìí ni Eshemokha Austin Maho, tí ó jẹ́ ọ̀mọ̀wé Nàìjíríà kan nípa ìkéde àti ìgbéròyìnjáde ṣe sọ.

en: They achieved this through the creation of "bogus social media accounts" from which "smear campaigns" and "doubtful information and propaganda" were disseminated.

en: The resultant impact was that Twitter became a battleground of ethnocentric disinformation and political propaganda before, during and in the immediate aftermath of the 2019 elections in Nigeria.
yor: Àbájáde tí ipa wọn kó ni pé Twitter di pápá ìròyìn ayédèrú tí ó ń ṣe ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà àti ìsọkiri láti mú èrò àwọn olóṣèlú ṣẹ ṣáájú àsìkò ìdìbò, ní àsìkò ìdìbò àti lẹ́yìn ìdìbò ọdún-un 2019 lórílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.
mt0: The announcement that they made was that Twitter became the world's leading social media platform that uses algorithms and tracking to reach political opinions before and after the 2019 Nigerian presidential election.

en: This article is part of a series of posts examining interference with digital rights through methods such as network shutdowns and disinformation during key political events in seven African countries: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.
yor: Àròkọ yìí jẹ́ apá kan nínú ọ̀wọ̀ọ́ àwọn àkọsílẹ̀ tí ó ń ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ìkọlura pẹ̀lú ẹ̀tọ́ ẹni lórí ayélujára nípasẹ̀ àwọn ìlànà bí i pípa òpó ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ àti ìròyìn ayédèrú ní àsìkò tí ọ̀rọ̀ ìṣèlú pàtàkì bá ń wáyé ní orílẹ̀-èdè ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ méje: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.
mt0: This article is a part of the efforts of academics to promote equality on the internet through strategies such as establishing communication channels and networking channels in cases when important political speeches are being held in the six African countries: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.

en: The project is funded by the Africa Digital Rights Fund of The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA).

en: In recent years, cultural and creative industries have played a growing role in developing economies, in terms of their economic contribution as well as their power to effect social change and cultural engagement.
yor: Ó ti pẹ́ tí àwọn iléeṣẹ́ ìgbélárugẹ àṣà àti ọgbọ́n àtinudá ti ń ṣe ohun mèremère ní ti ìdàgbàsókè ọrọ̀ Ajé, ní ti ipa tí wọ́n ń kó àti agbára tí ó wà níkàáwọ́ wọn láti mú àyípadà dé bá àwùjọ àti ìpàṣípààrọ̀ àṣà.

en: In 2013, cultural and creative industries (CCI) generated $2,250 billion United States dollars worth of revenue and 29.5 million jobs worldwide [but] only 3 percent of these jobs came from Africa and the Middle East, according to a 2013 study by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) called “Cultural time.”
yor: Lọ́dún-un 2013, iléeṣẹ́ ìgbélárugẹ àṣà àti ọgbọ́n àtinudá (CCI) rí owó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún 2,250 dollar ti Ìṣọ̀kan Orílẹ̀-èdèe Amẹ́ríkà àti iṣẹ́ tí ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 29.5 kárí ayé [àmọ́] ìdá 3 àwọn iṣẹ́ wọ̀nyí wá láti Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ àti Àárín gbùngbùn Ìlà-Oòrùn tí ó jẹ́ agbègbè àwọn aráa Lárúbáwá, ìyẹn gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò fínnífínní Àjọ Ìṣọ̀kan Àgbáyé fún Ẹ̀kọ́, Ìwádìí Ìjìnlẹ̀ àti Àṣà (UNESCO) ọdún-un 2013 tí a pè ní “Àsìkò Àṣà” kan ti ṣe fi hàn.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know In 2013, the Culture and Industry Institute (CCI) received $250,000 from the United States and a total of 29.5 million jobs worldwide [but] three-quarters of these jobs came from the South and Central America which are the largest ethnic groups in the world, according to a UNESCO 2013 Ethnographic Survey.

en: For this reason, African Export-Import Bank (Afreximbank) in collaboration with UNESCO and African Development Bank Group, developed the Creative Africa Exchange (CAX) as a "catalyst that brings together the identified assets and resources within the creative industry" to consolidate, monetize and impact African creative and cultural economies, according to the CAX website.
yor: Torí ìdí èyí, Ilé-ìfowópamọ́sí Ọjà títa sókè òkun-àti-kíkó ọjà wọlé (Afreximbank) pẹ̀lú àbáṣepọ̀ọ UNESCO àti Ẹgbẹ́ Ilé-ìfowópamọ́sí Ìdàgbàsókè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ Ìpàṣípààrọ̀ Ọgbọ́n Àtinudá Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ – Creative Africa Exchange (CAX) tí yóò "dúró gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ohun tí yóò ṣe àmúpapọ̀ àwọn nǹkan ọrọ̀ àti àlùmọ́nì tí ó wà nínú iléeṣẹ́ ọgbọ́n àtinudá" tí yóò ṣe àgbéró, mú owó wọlé àti lapa rere lára àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n àtinudá àti àwọn oníṣẹ́ àṣà, bí ibùdó ìtakùn àgbáyé CAX ṣe ní i lákọsílẹ̀.
mt0: For this reason, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the UNESCO and the African Development Bank (Afreximbank) have established the Creative Africa Exchange (CAX) which will "stand out as a means to integrate the intellectual and cultural values of the African economy" that will "stimulate, bring in funds and promote a positive relationship between intellectuals and cultural professionals," as the global CAX office says.

en: CAX launched during the Intra Africa Trade Fair in Cairo, Egypt, in December 2018.

en: "Even though the new media is taking over the world with the way we do things, radio is still the most viable option for many people to get information, it remains the most powerful tool for journalists to reach people in the farthest and remote areas..." said Bishop George Bako, during his opening remarks at the World Radio Day Symposium. Bako is the former Director-General of the Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria (FRCN).
yor: "Ẹ̀rọ ìgbéròyìnjáde ń yí bí a ti ṣe ń ṣe nǹkan padà, síbẹ̀síbẹ̀ ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ṣì ni ó ṣì wúlò jù lọ fún ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ènìyàn láti gbọ́ ìròyìn ohun tí ó ń lọ lọ́wọ́, òhun ṣì ni ohun èlò tí ó máa ń lapa tí ó pọ̀ jù nínúu gbogbo ọ̀nà tí àwọn oníròyìn máa ń lò nítorí ó lágbára láti dé ibi jínjìn àti ìgbèríko tí ó jẹ́ ibi kọ́lọ́fín… " Àlùfáà George Bako sọ̀rọ̀, nígbà tí ó ń ṣíde ètò níbi Àpérò Ọjọ́ Ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àgbáyé. en: Radio broadcasting in Nigeria started in 1933 with the British colonial government’s Radio Diffusion Service (RDS), whereby loudspeakers were installed in dedicated public places for people to listen to the British Broadcasting Corporation’s foreign radio service broadcasts.
yor: Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ní Nàìjíríà bẹ̀rẹ̀ ní ọdún-un 1933 pẹ̀lú Ìtàn káàkiri Rédíò Ìjọba Amúnisìn (RDS), tí ó jẹ́ wípé gbé àwọn ẹ̀rọ-gbohùngbohùn sí ìta gbangba níbi tí àwọn ènìyàn yóò ti tẹ́tí sí ìròyìn òkèèrè ti Iléeṣẹ́ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Ìjọba Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: By 1950, the Radio Diffusion Service took on a new name — the Nigerian Broadcasting Service (NBS) — and later, the Nigerian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC), with broadcast stations in the different regions of the country. NBC later metamorphosed into the Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria (FRCN) in 1978.
yor: Ní ọdún-un 1950, RDS gbé aṣọ tuntun wọ̀ — ó di Iléeṣẹ́ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (NBS) — nígbà tí ó ṣe, ó di Iléeṣẹ́ Alájọṣepọ̀ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (NBC), pẹ̀lú ìkànnì ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ ní àwọn ẹ̀ka tí Nàìjíríà pín sí. NBC pàpà paradà di Iléeṣẹ́ Alájọṣepọ̀ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Ìjọba Àpapọ̀ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà (FRCN) lọ́dún-un 1978.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know In 1950, RDS changed its name to the National Broadcasting Service (NBS) and, when it was changed, it became the National Broadcasting Corporation (NBC), with coverage of broadcasts in all areas which Nigeria shares. NBC became the Federal Communications Network of Nigeria (FRCN) in 1978.

en: "The first radio station in Nigeria was established in Ibadan in 1939.
yor: "Iléeṣẹ́ Rédíò àkọ́kọ́ ní Nàìjíríà tí a dá sílẹ̀ ní Ìbàdàn ní ọdún-un 1939.
mt0: The first radio station in Nigeria was established in the war of 1939.

en: The next station was created in Kano in 1944," according to Legit media online.

mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: RayPower FM, the first private radio station in Nigeria, was established in 1994, and by 2007, the masses could get international transmission broadcast worldwide, according to Legit.

mt0: Legit says that RayPower FM, the first radio station in Nigeria, was established in 1994, and since 2007, listeners have been hearing world news.

en: Radio has always served as a tool to check decision-makers, establish and provide access to information and motivate and inspire the people.

en: In 2019, African Independent Television and RayPower FM were shut down by the National Broadcasting Commission (NBC) for incisive broadcast and propaganda against the government.

mt0: In 2019, the National Broadcasting Committee (NBC) shut down African Independent Television and RayPower FM because it broadcast a program that would be against the government.

en: Also in 2019, Jay FM in Port Harcourt was shut down for allegedly making broadcasts against the government.
yor: Bákan náà ní ọdún- 2019, Jay FM tíó wà ní Port Harcourt di ṣíṣánpa lẹ́yìn tí a fi ẹ̀sùn ìtako ìjọba kàn án.
mt0: In 2019, Jay FM in Port Harcourt was shut down after being accused of corruption.

en: Radio Nigeria truck advertises itself as "the network for the millennium," and joins radio practitioners around the globe in celebrating World Radio Day 2020.

mt0: Radio Nigeria announced itself as "the largest radio station in the world," and joined the world radio executives for the 2020 World Radio Day celebrations.

en: Since 2011, Boko Haram, the Islamist jihadist militancy in northeast Nigeria, has created a climate of fear and division as their brutal attacks have led to thousands of deaths and millions of displacements.

en: To further continue to uplift Nigeria, the management of FRCN Lagos Operations put together a series of events to commemorate World Radio Day 2020.

mt0: In the wake of Nigeria's earthquake, the FRCN Ministry of Energy announced a single plan to prepare for the World Climate Change Day in 2020.

en: It kicked off with an essay contest calling for 1,200 words on "why I love listening to the radio" for secondary school students.
yor: Eré gbogboó bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìdíje àròkọ ọlọ́rọ̀ 1,200 tí ó dá lóríi "ìdí tí mo fi nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí láti máa gbọ́ rédíò" fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ iléèwé gíga.
mt0: The whole thing began with a competition of 1,200 letters based on "why I like to listen to radio" for high school students.

en: Students of mass communications also submitted a 5-minute documentary on the importance of radio in achieving sustainable development goals. Two winners emerged from both entries.
yor: Àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìmọ̀ iṣẹ́ ìròyìn náà ṣe ètò alálàyé oníṣẹ̀ẹ́jú 5 tí ó dá fìrìgbagbòó lóríi pàtàkìi ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ fún ìmúṣẹ àwọn ìlépa ìmúdúró ìdàgbàsókè. Àwọn àkópa méjì ló jáwé olúborí.

en: I think I was 5 years old when I got my first radio.

en: I fiddled with a few buttons and it came on.

en: Then I was astonished to hear voices resonating from this "box" and thought there were people trapped in it.

en: On February 12, secondary school pupils, students of mass communication, ace broadcasters and key personnel from the media industry as well as everyday radio fans converged on the Lekki Coliseum in Lagos for a symposium to talk about the importance of radio for development.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 12 oṣù Èrèlé, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ilé ẹ̀kọ́ gíga, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìmọ̀ iṣẹ́ ìròyìn, ọ̀jẹ̀ sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ àti àwọn alẹ́nulọ́rọ̀ nínú iṣẹ́ ìròyìn àti àwọn olólùfẹ́ẹ̀ rédíò péjúpésẹ̀ sí Lekki Coliseum ní Èkó fún àpérò láti jíròrò nípa pàtàkìi ẹ̀rọ-ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ fún ìdàgbàsókè.
mt0: In December 12, academics, journalists, academics, and academics from the journalism and academic communities gathered in Lekki Coliseum in Ethiopia to discuss the importance of the satellite for development.

en: In the wake of the International Year of Indigenous Languages in 2019 and the International Decade of Indigenous Languages 2022-2032, many Africans have started to take a wide range of actions to advance African languages.

en: Writing the Yorùbá language in the borrowed Latin script may soon become a thing of the past as one Yorùbá man, Chief Tolúlàṣẹ Ògúntósìn, based in Benin, West Africa, has invented a writing system to encode the Yorùbá language.

en: The distinct alphabet came to him through divine inspiration in his dreams, according to Chief Ògúntósìn in a Whatsapp interview with Global Voices.

en: He now travels across Yorùbáland — spanning Benin to Nigeria — to promote his "talking alphabet" as sent to him by his ancestors.
yor: Ní báyìí, níṣe ni ó máa ń ṣe ìrìnàjò jákèjádò Ilẹ̀-Yorùbá — láti Bẹ̀nẹ̀ títí dé Nàìjíríà — láti polongo "alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì tí ó ń sọ̀rọ̀ " rẹ̀ bí àwọn alálẹ̀ ti ṣe fi rán an.

yor: Olóyè Ògúntósìn nígbàgbọ́ wí pé Odùduwà, tí ó jẹ́ bàbá-ńlá ìran Yorùbá lo alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà ní ayé àtijọ́ — àmọ́ ó ti di ohun ìgbàgbé.

en: African linguists assert that if Africa is to grow, it must have its own orthographies or writing systems.

en: A civilized and ancient Niger-Congo language like Yorùbá should not rely on a borrowed orthography to encode its thoughts and philosophy.
yor: Èdè tí ó wà lábẹ́ ìsọ̀rí Niger-Congo tí ó jẹ́ èdè ìran tí ó ti wà lọ́jọ́ tó ti pẹ́ tí ó sì lajú bí èdè Yorùbá ò gbọdọ̀ gbọ́kàn tẹ ìlànà àyálò fún kíkọ èrò àti ìmọ̀ ìrírí ayé rẹ̀.

en: Read more: Yorùbá loan words: How languages evolve

en: In 1843, Reverend Samuel Àjàyí Crowther of the Christian Missionary Society developed the Yorùbá orthography by adopting Latin script with diacritics — or accent marks.
yor: Ní ọdún 1843, Àlùfáà Sámúẹ́lì Àjàyí Crowther òṣìṣẹ́ Ẹgbẹ́ Iṣẹ́ Ìránṣẹ́ Ẹ̀sìn Ìgbàgbọ́ (CMS) ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ èdè Yorùbá nípa yíya ìlànà Látíìnì lò pẹ̀lú àfikún àwọn àmì ohùn — tàbí àmì ìró ọ̀rọ̀.
mt0: In 1843, Alufa Samuel Ajayi Crowther a worker of the Church Service (CMS) developed the alphabetic system of Yoruba by using the Latín alphabet with the surrounding sound signs — or sounds.

en: Ever since, thousands of books have been published in Yorùbá using Latin script instead of Ajami, an Arabic script used before 1843 to write in West African Indigenous languages such as Yorùbá and Hausa.
yor: Láti ìgbà náà, ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ìwé ti jẹ́ títẹ̀ jáde ní èdè Yorùbá nípasẹ̀ lílo ìlànà kíkọ Látíìnì dípò Ajami, tí í ṣe ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ Lárúbáwá tí ó ti jẹ́ lílò tẹ́lẹ̀tẹ́lẹ́ rí fún kíkọ èdè Ìwọ̀-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ bí i èdè Yorùbá àti Haúsá kí ó tó di 1843.
mt0: Since then, thousands of books have been translated into Yoruba using the Latin alphabet, which was the first Latin alphabet used for the Eastern African language such as Yoruba and Hausa until 1843.

en: Some language advocates contend that using Latin, a foreign script, to encode African languages, keeps the continent in an enslaved mindset.
yor: Àwọn alágbàwí èdè gbà wí pé lílo ìlànà Látíìnì, tí ó jẹ́ ìṣọwọ́kọ láti ilẹ̀ òkèèrè, fún kíkọ àwọn èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ sílẹ̀, fi ilẹ̀ náà sínú ipò ẹrú.
mt0: Archaeologists believe that the use of the Latein system, which is a translation from a foreign country, to write the languages of the East, has put the country in a position of slavery.

en: Instilling this new writing system follows a history of ancient writing systems in Africa, like Egyptian hieroglyphics, the Adrinka collection of the Akan tribe of Ghana, Ethiopian Ge'ez, the Nsibidi ideographic script of West Central Africa which date back to 5000 BC, as well as Vai alphabet scripts are of African origin.
yor: Ìpolongo ìlànà ìṣọwọ́kọ tuntun yìí wáyé ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú àwọn ìṣọwọ́kọ ayébáyé Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, bí i hieroglyphics ti Íjípìtì, Àkójọ Adrinka ti ìran Akan ní Ghana, Ge'ez ti Ethiopia, ìṣọwọ́kọ ìyàwòrán Nsibidi ti Àárín Gbùngbùn Ìwọ̀-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ tí ó ti wà fún bí 5000 ọdún k'á tó bí Jésù, àti alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Vai ni Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ jẹ́ orísun wọn.
mt0: The introduction of the new alphabet was based on the ancient alphabets of the East African world, such as hieroglyphics of Egypt, the alphabet of the Ghanaan languages, the Ge'ez of Ethiopia, the Nsibidi alphabet of the Eastern North African region that has been in use for over 5000 years before Jesus, and the Vai alphabet in the East African region is their source.

en: Divining a 'talking alphabet'

en: However, as a Yorùbá chief, he focused his cultural work on uniting the seven grandchildren of Odùduwa, serving as a mediator.

en: In 2017, Chief Ògúntósìn, in the company of prominent traditional rulers in Yorùbáland and the diaspora, paid a visit to Rauf Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá, the one-time governor of Nigeria’s Ọ̀ṣun State, in Òṣogbo, the state capital, to solicit support for his newly found Odùduwà alphabet.

mt0: In 2017, Olóyè Ògúntósìn, pẹlu awọn ọba Aláṣẹ igbá-keji òrìṣà Ilẹ̀-Yorùbá nílé àti lẹ́yìn odi, ṣe àbẹ̀wó to Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Rauf Arẹ́gbẹ́ṣọlá, who was once the governor of the Eastern Province, in the capital of the eastern Nigerian city of Òṣogbo, to ask for approval for the new Railway Station.

en: In a bid to make the Odùduwà alphabet popular, Chief Ògúntósìn has written a book and produced a documentary on the orthography — with snippets uploaded on the internet for public viewing — as well as an abandoned cartoon project which did not see the light of day due to lack of funds.

en: Copies of the educational pamphlets were printed in Igbo, Hausa, English, and French languages respectively. However, more support is crucial to disseminate the alphabet to a wider audience.
yor: Ẹ̀da ìwé ẹ̀kọ́ alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà wà ní èdè Igbo, Hausa, English, àti Faransé lẹ́sẹẹsẹ. Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, àtìlẹ́yìn kì í pọ̀ jù fún ìpínkárí alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì náà.
mt0: The alphabet is written in Igbo, Hausa, English, and French. However, the alphabet is not very widespread for the alphabet.

en: The Odùduwà alphabet is a welcome development.
yor: Ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó mú ìwúrí dání ni alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà náà.

en: Nevertheless, the shift from writing in Latin to the new system will be a major challenge.
yor: Ṣùgbọ́n, sísún láti ìlànà Látíìnì sí ìlànà tuntun ni yóò mú ìpèníjà ńlá lọ́wọ́.
mt0: But, shifting from the old system to the new system will bring a big increase in sales.

en: That said, the Odùduwà alphabet is a great step in the right direction toward the development and growth of the Yorùbá language — in what Yorùbá people will call their own.
yor: Kò jẹ́ bó ṣe jẹ́, ohun tí yóò mú ìlọsíwájú àti ìdàgbàsókè bá èdè Yorùbá ni alífábẹ́ẹ̀tì Odùduwà — ohun tí ìran Yorùbá yóò pè ni tiwa-ń-tiwa.

en: Yorùbá loanwords: How languages evolve

mt0: If you can't translate the translation, just say you don't know

en: Do you say àkàrà or bean cake?
yor: Ṣé àkàrà ni ò ń pè àbí bean cake?
mt0: Is it a cake or a cupcake?

en: Àkàrà or Nigerian bean cake is a staple breakfast in Nigeria, July 11, 2013. Photo by Atimukoh via Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.
yor: Àkàrà tàbí beans cake ní Nàìjíríà jẹ́ oúnjẹ àárọ̀ ní Nàìjíríà, ọjọ́ 11, oṣù kéje, ọdún 2013. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Atimukoh láti orí i Wikimedia Commons, àṣẹ CC BY 2.0.

en: Relationships between languages have existed for hundreds of years.
yor: Àjọṣepọ̀ láàárín onírúurú èdè ti wà láti ayébáyé.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: Think of the word "restaurant," borrowed from the French language into English.
yor: Fún àkàwé, kí á wo gbólóhùn bí i "restaurant," tí ó jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀ tí a yá láti inú èdè Faransé wá sínú èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.
mt0: In the text, look at a sentence like "restaurant," which is a word that was borrowed from French to English.

en: Today, this loanword — a word adopted from one language into another without translation — circulates in English as if it was never borrowed.
yor: Lóde òní, ọ̀rọ̀-àyálò yìí — ìyẹn gbólóhùn tí a gbà lò láti inú èdè kan sí inú èdè mìíràn láì tú ìmọ̀ rẹ̀ — kò l'óǹkà nínú èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì àfi bí ẹni pé kì í ṣe ọ̀rọ̀ tí a yá lò.
mt0: Today, this phrase — which is a response taken from one language to another without having to explain it — is not used in English as it is not a common phrase.

en: These linguistic borrowings can be attributed to immigration, commerce, and trade as people were exposed to a wide range of ethnolinguistic environments.
yor: Àwọn èdè àyálò wọ̀nyí wáyé látàrí àbápàdé onírúurú ènìyàn kárí ayé, bí wọ́n ṣe ń ṣíkiri, ṣe ọrọ̀ Ajé, àti káràkátà.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know These languages have been created by the inter-human communication, when people moved, spoke, and spoke to each other.

en: Through these interactions, people were exposed to various linguistic contexts, and words and phrases were borrowed to accommodate these encounters.
yor: Látàrí ìtàkùrọ̀sọ tí ó wáyé láàárín àwọn onírúurú ènìyàn wọ̀nyí, èdè wọnú èdè, gbólóhùn àti àpólà ọ̀rọ̀ di àyálò.
mt0: Because of the importance of communication between these people, languages, phrases, and phrases become separate.

en: The Yorùbá case is no exception.
yor: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí kò yọ ìran Yorùbá sílẹ̀.
mt0: This event did not remove Yoruba.

en: Spoken widely by about 40 million speakers in Nigeria, Yorùbá language has been influenced by the English language spoken by the British, who held colonial power in Nigeria from 1914 to 1960.
yor: Ó tó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ènìyàn 40 tíó ń fọ èdè Yorùbá ní orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà, irú èdè Yorùbá ti dàpọ̀ mọ́ ṣapala èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì, tí í ṣe èdè ìjọba amúnisìn àná láti ọdún 1914 sí 1960.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: More than half of the vocabulary words used in Yorùbá are borrowed from English. Think of the word "cup", it was domesticated as kó̩ò̩pù.
yor: Ó tó ìdajì gbólóhùn èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì tí a yà lò nínú èdè Yorùbá. Kí a wo ọ̀rọ̀ bí i "cup" Ó di kó̩ò̩pù.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: The word "phone" is fóònù, "ball" is bó̩ò̩lù, and "television" is te̩lifís̩ó̩ò̩nù, among others.
yor: A pe "phone" ní fóònù, "ball" di bó̩ò̩lù, "television" ni te̩lifís̩ó̩ò̩nù, àti bẹ́ẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: These English words that were "loaned" to Yorùbá expanded its vocabulary over time.
yor: Àwọn gbólóhùn "àyálò" wọ̀nyí mú èdè Yorùbá fẹjú sí i.
mt0: These "suggestions" simply took the Yoruba language away from it.

en: There are also instances of the Yorùbá language borrowing words from the Hausa language, spoken by 44 million people in the northern part of Nigeria.
yor: Bákan náà ni àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò inú èdè Hausa tí àwọn ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 44 ènìyàn ní Àríwá ilẹ̀ Nàìjíríà ń sọ lọ sua.
mt0: Similarly, the Hausa language spoken by approximately 400,000 people in Nigeria is being spoken.

en: This language borrows heavily from Arabic, as well, with words like àlùbáríkà ("blessing"), àlùbó̩sà ("onion") and wàhálà ("trouble").
yor: Èdè yìí yá ọ̀kẹ́ àìmọye ọ̀rọ̀ lò láti inú èdè Lárúbáwá, àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ bí i àlùbáríkà ("ìbùkún"), àlbásà ("àlùbọ́sà") àti wàhálà ("ìyọnu").
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: The beauty of Yorùbá loanwords is that speakers now use them in their day-to-day conversations as they get absorbed into the language.
yor: Ohun tí ó jẹ́ ìwúrí ní ti àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò nínú èdè Yorùbá ni bí àwọn ènìyàn ṣe ń lò wọ́n nínú ìtàkùrọ̀sọ lójoojúmọ́ bí wọ́n ṣe ń ṣàn wọ inú èdè náà.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: It is not uncommon to hear people say, Bá o̩mo̩ ye̩n mú bó̩ò̩lu è̩  or "Help the child take the ball" in English.
yor: Wà á gbọ́ gbólóhùn bí i, Bá o̩mo̩ ye̩n mú bó̩ò̩lu è̩ tàbí "Help the child take the ball" lédè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.
mt0: You may hear such a response, Help the child take the ball, or "Help the child take the ball" in English.

en: Although the underlined word bó̩ò̩lu is not native to the Yorùbá language, speakers manage to make it fit.
yor: Adi, ọmọ-ọ̀rọ̀ tí a falà sí lábẹ́ bó̩ò̩lu jẹ́ tiwantiwa nínú èdè Yorùbá, àwọn aṣàfọ̀ mọ bí wọ́n ṣe ń lò ó.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know Adi, a word which is a constitutional language in Yoruba, the elders know how to use it.

en: One of the challenges with the Yorùbá language with regard to loanwords is that native speakers themselves love translating Yorùbá words into English and using them in sentences instead of the original Yorùbá word.
yor: Ìpèníjà kan tí èdè Yorùbá ní nípa ti ọ̀rọ̀ àyálò ò ju ti ògbufọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ wuuru tí àwọn aṣàfọ̀ èdè Yorùbá máa ń ṣe láti túmọ̀ àwọn gbólóhùn èdè Yorùbá sí ti Gẹ̀ẹ́sì tí wọ́n máa ń lò nínú ìpèdè dípò ojúlówó èdè Yorùbá.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: An example is the word àkàrà  — most Yorùbá speakers translate it to bean cake in daily interactions —, especially with foreigners.
yor: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, àkàrà — tí àwọn ọmọ Yorùbá ti túmọ̀ sí bean cake — pàápàá nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀jomitoro-ọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú àlejò.
mt0: For example, akara — which the Yoruba call bean cake — is especially popular in conversations with visitors.

en: Using words in their original forms helps ensure that culture — kept alive through language — continues to thrive.
yor: Lílo ọ̀rọ̀ ní èdè pọ́nbélé máa ń mú kí àṣà — ó gbòòrò — tí yóò sí máa jẹ́ kí èdè ó di ìtẹ́wọ́gbà.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: For instance, no one calls Japan’s sushi by any other name — sushi is sushi.
yor: Bí a bá wò ó báyìí, kò s'ẹ́ni jẹ́ pe sushi Japan lórúkọ mìíràn — sushi ni sushi ń jẹ́.
mt0: If you look at it, no one says sushi Japan in another way — sushi is sushi.

en: If this was the case for many Yorùbá words, too, its language and culture could flourish beyond Nigeria and the Yorùbá-speaking world.
yor: Bí èyí bá rí bẹ́ẹ̀ fún àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ Yorùbá náà, èdè àti àṣà rẹ̀, yóò gbilẹ̀ kọjá orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà àti ibi tí wọ́n ti ń fọ èdè Yorùbá kárí ayé.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: For example, àmàlà is a famous Yorùbá food, even in the diaspora.
yor: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, àmàlà jẹ́ oúnjẹ tí ó ilẹ̀ Yorùbá lókìkí, pàápàá ní òkè òkun.
mt0: For example, a curry is a food that is native to the northern part of the country, particularly in the mountains.

en: This word could easily find its way into the lexicon of other languages if Yorùbá speakers insisted on it.
yor: Gbólóhùn yìí ti rá pálá wọnú ìlò ọ̀rọ̀ èdè mìíràn bí àwọn aṣàfọ̀ Yorùbá bá tẹnu mọ́ ọn.
mt0: This statement calls for the use of other languages if Yoruba speakers do not understand it.

en: Translating it to "yam flour" lessens its status and linguistic root — its "Yorubaness."
yor: Títúmọ̀ rẹ̀ sí "yam flour" dín agbára ìpèdè náà kù — yóò sọ "ipò Yorùbá nù."
mt0: If you cannot translate it to "yam flour" simply say you don't know.

en: Think of the anglicized Yorùbá word "fanimorious", which is becoming more popular and appears in the Urban Dictionary.
yor: Bí a bá wo gbólóhùn èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì tí a yí padà sí èdè Yorùbá "fanimorious", tí ó ti ń lókìkí tí ó sì ti wà nínú Ìwé Ìtumọ̀ Ìgbàlódé.
mt0: If you can't translate the Greek sentence back to Yoruba, just say you don't know.

en: It means "appealing", or "beautiful", and comes from the word fanimó̩ra in Yorùbá.
yor: Ó túmọ̀ sí “bójúmu,” tàbí “rẹwà,” tí ó súyọ láti fanimó̩ra tí í ṣe gbólóhùn Yorùbá.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: This could be phono-morphological: Yorùbá language does not allow final word consonants and consonant clusters.
yor: Èyí f'ara pẹ́ ìbáṣepọ̀ fonọ́lọ́jì àti mọfọ́lọ́jì: èdè Yorùbá kì í fàyè gba ìhunpọ̀ kọ̀nsónántì àti kí ọ̀rọ̀ parí pẹ̀lú kọ̀nsónántì.
mt0: This includes telephone and mobile communication: Yoruba does not allow connections to computers and does not allow a conversation to end with a computer.

en: As a result, the English suffix -ious was added to the Yorùbá root word.
yor: Torí ìdí èyí, a fi àfòmọ́ ìparí -ious èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì kún ọ̀rọ̀ ìpìlẹ̀ Yorùbá.
mt0: For this reason, the Greek word -ious was added to the Yoruba language. If you cannot translate, just say you don't know.

en: However, the fact remains that the word stems from the Yorùbá language. This is a win for the Yorùbá.
yor: Síbẹ̀, òtítọ́ farahàn wípé láti ara èdè Yorùbá ni ó ti sú yọ. Ìgbéga ni èyí jẹ́ fún Yor Yorùbá.
mt0: But, it is a fact that it has been taken from Yoruba. This is a blessing for Yoruba.

en: Recently, several other Nigerian English words were added to the Oxford English Dictionary.
yor: Ní kò pẹ́ kò pẹ́ yìí, ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì bí a ti ṣe ń lò ó ní Nàìjíríà di àfikún nínú ìwé ìtúmọ̀ èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì ti Oxford.
mt0: In the meantime, English as used in Nigeria became a part of Oxford's English textbooks.

en: Yorùbá will make giant strides only if its speakers contribute to its growth; Its usage in the media is also important as the world becomes increasingly more digitized.
yor: Ọpọ́n èdè Yorùbá yóò sún síwájú bí àwọn tó ń fọ èdè náà bá lọ́wọ́ sí ìdàgbàsókè rẹ̀; ìlò rẹ̀ nínú iṣẹ́ ìkọ̀ròyìn pọn dandan ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú bí ayé ṣe ń lu jára wọn bí ajere lóde òní.
mt0: Many Yoruba will be lost if those who speak it get involved in its development; its use in journalism is necessary in comparison with the way the world is rushing their phones like a foreigner today.

en: Consequently, this will spur further research on the Niger-Congo language.
yor: Ní ìparí, èyí yóò túbọ̀ mú kí iṣẹ́ ìwádìí èdè Niger-Congo ó rinlẹ̀.
mt0: In the evening, this will further delay the Niger-Congo linguistic research.

en: Lost in translation: Why Google Translate often gets Yorùbá — and other languages — wrong
yor: Sísọnù sínú ògbufọ̀: Ìdí tí Atúmọ̀ Google ṣe ń kùnà — nínú títúmọ̀ èdè Yorùbá — àti àwọn èdè mìíràn
mt0: Example: Why Google Translate sucks — in Yoruba translation — and other languages.

en: Most translations done by machines render some words wrong
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ògbufọ̀ tí ẹ̀rọ ṣe ni kò nítumọ̀.
mt0: Many medicines made by machines are not meaningful.

en: Wikimedia User Group Nigeria, October 2018 via Wikimedia Commons CC.BY.2.0.

mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: The English language has dominated online discourse as the "universal" language of communication since the inception of the internet.
yor: Èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì ti jẹ gàba lórí ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ tí ó ń wáyé ní orí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere gẹ́gẹ́ bí èdè "gbogbo àgbáyé" fún ìtàkùrọ̀sọ láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀ ẹ̀rọ ayélujára.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know English has been dominant on communication in the mobile phone sector as a "world language" for the purpose of starting a mobile phone conversation.

en: As of February 2020, over half of the websites on the internet are in English, according to WebTech3.
yor: Nínú oṣù Èrèlé ọdún 2020, gẹ́gẹ́ bí WebTech3 ti ṣe fi hàn, ìdajì ibùdó ìtakùn àgbáyé tó wà lórí ayélujára ni a kọ ní èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.
mt0: In February 2020, as WebTech3 showed, the world's largest online marketplace was written in English.

en: But as more people get online who speak different languages, it has sparked a linguistic digital revolution — immediate access to English translations of multiple languages with the click of a button.
yor: Àmọ́ bí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn tí ó ń sọ oríṣìíríṣìí èdè àgbáyé ṣe ń bọ́ sórí ayélukára-bí-ajere, ó ṣẹ́ ẹtà ìjà fún èdè ẹni — ìráàyè sí ìṣògbufọ̀ sí onírúurú èdè tí yóò ṣẹ̀ ní mọnawáà.
mt0: But as many people who speak foreign languages come to the world because of their wealth, it creates a war for the language - a barrier to translation to foreign languages that will be created in the future.

en: Many tech companies have recently put effort into documenting non-English words on the internet, paving the way for the digitization of multiple languages. Google, Yoruba Names, Masakhane MT and  ALC are examples of companies and start-ups that have been trying to marry technology with non-English languages.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iléeṣẹ́ onímọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ti ṣe iṣẹ́ ribiribi ní ti ìṣàkọsílẹ̀ àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ tí kì í ṣe èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì sórí ayélujára, tí ó ń ṣe olùlànà onírúurú èdè lórí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá lọ́nà ìgbàlódé. Google, Yoruba Names, Masakhane MT àti ALC jẹ́ àpẹẹrẹ àwọn iléeṣẹ́ ńlá àti àwọn iléeṣẹ́ kéréje tí ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ tí ó ti mú ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn èdè tí kì í ṣe èdè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.
mt0: Many software companies have been involved in the translation of non-English words on the internet, which has become the dominant language on mobile devices in the modern world. Google, Yoruba Names, Masakhane MT and ALC are examples of a recently started companies that have integrated technology with non-English languages.

en: In late February 2020, Google announced that it would add five new languages to its Google Translate services, including Kinyarwanda, Uighur, Tatar, Turkmen and Odia, after a four-year hiatus on adding new languages.
yor: Kí oṣù Èrèlé ọdún 2020 ó tó tẹnu bepo, Google filọ̀ wípé òun yóò fi èdè tuntun márùn-ún kún iṣẹ́ Atúmọ̀ Google rẹ̀, àwọn èdè náà ni Kinyarwanda, Uighur, Tatar, Turkmen àti Odia, lẹ́yìn ìsinmi ọdún mẹ́rin tí wọ́n fi èdè tuntun kún un kẹ́yìn.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know In early 2020, Google announced that it would add five new languages to its Google Translate service, including Kinyarwanda, Uighur, Tatar, Turkmen and Odia, after a four-year freeze.

en: A man looks perplexed while reading a text online. Photo by Oladimeji Ajegbile, open-source via Pexels.

en: But have you ever clicked on the translation option and realized that the English translation is, at best, just OK?

mt0: But have you written down a dictionary that says that one is better than the other?

en: And at worst, not accurate at all?

en: There are many controversies and difficulties when it comes to doing this kind of language translation and access work.

en: Twitter offers Yorùbá language translation into English via Google Translate as much as possible, and usually, the outcome isn’t totally bad — perhaps a few words are correct.

en: The reason for these challenges is that tech companies usually collect their linguistic data for English translation sourced from the internet.

en: This data may work for some languages, but languages like Yorùbá and Ìgbò, two main languages from Nigeria, are challenging, due to the inadequate or inaccurate accent marks to indicate tones on these words.

en: In response to why it has taken Google four years to add five new languages, a company spokesperson explained:

en: Google Translate learns from existing translations found on the web, and when languages don’t have an abundance of web content, it’s been difficult for our system to support them effectively.

en: However, due to recent advances in our machine learning technology, and active involvement from our Google Translate Community members, we’ve been able to add support for these languages.

en: As a result, good translations don’t compute because these errors are not flagged as inadequate.

mt0: So, a prescription for a fever is not common because there is no way to know these procedures.

en: Most translations done by machines render some words wrong, especially words that are culturally nuanced.

en: For example, Yorùbá words ayaba and obabìnrin have their meanings situated in a cultural context.
yor: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, gbólóhùn Yorùbá bí i ayaba àti ọbabìnrin ní ìtumọ̀ tó yàtọ̀.
mt0: For example, the word "queen" in Yoruba has a different meaning.

en: Most machines translate both words as "queen".

mt0: Many devices simply add two letters to the word "queen".

en: However, from a traditional-cum-cultural vantage point, it is essential to note that the meanings of ayaba and obabìnrin are different: Ọbabìnrin means "queen" in English while ayaba is "wife of the king".
yor: Síbẹ̀, tí a bá ti ọ̀nà ìṣe-àti-àsà wò ó, ó ṣe kókó láti sọ wí pé ìtúmọ̀ ayaba and ọbabìnrin yàtọ̀ síra wọn: Ọbabìnrin túmọ̀ sí "queen" lédè Gẹ̀ẹ́sì nígbà tí ayaba jẹ́ "wife of the king".
mt0: However, if we look at it from the artistic point of view, it is easier to say that the meanings of the princess and the queen are different: The queen is referred to as "queen" in English while the queen is referred to as "wife of the king".

en: Even with these translation complications, technology has helped with the advancement of  African languages in digital spaces, spurring the coinage of new words.
yor: Pẹ̀lú àwọn àìṣedéédéé wọ̀nyí, ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ti ṣe ìrànwọ́ fún ìdàgbàsókè àwọn èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ lórí àwọn gbàgede orí ayélujára, tí ó ti mú ìṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀ tuntun wáyé.

en: African languages have grown with the influx of new gadgets like smartphones and tablets, as new words are coined to name these new technological tools and concepts.
yor: Èdè Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ti gòkè àgbà látàrí àwọn lílo àwọn ẹ̀rọ ìgbàlódé tuntun bí i ẹ̀rọ-ìléwọ́ àti ẹ̀rọ ọpọ́n ayárabíàṣá, tí ó sì ń bí àwọn gbólóhùn tuntun tí a fi ń pe àwọn irinṣẹ́ ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tuntun wọ̀nyí.

en: This process has thus expanded the usage and functionality of these languages.

en: With the emergence of new technologies, the vocabularies of many African languages have become more sophisticated.

mt0: Because of these new devices, many Eastern European languages can be translated.

en: For instance, the Yorùbá language has some tech-influenced words such as erọ amúlétutù ("air conditioner"), erọ Ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ("phone") and erọ Ìlọta ("grinder").
yor: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, èdè Yorùbá ní àwọn gbólóhùn tí ó ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ bí i ẹ̀rọ-amúlétutù ("air conditioner"), erọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ("phone") and ẹ̀rọ-ìlọta ("grinder").
mt0: For example, Yoruba has phrases related to technology such as air conditioner, phone and grinder.

en: Similarly, the Igbo language has words such as ekwè nti ("telephone") and ugbọ̀ àlà ("vehicle").
yor: Ẹ̀wẹ̀wẹ̀, èdè Igbo náà ní ọ̀rọ̀ bí i ekwè nti ("telephone") àti ugbọ̀ àlà ("vehicle").
mt0: Examples of these words include telephone and vehicle.

en: These societies have given these gadgets names based on the functions they perform.

en: In courses on broadcasting and advertisement in Yorùbá, students learn that most people call TV erọ Amóhùnmáwòrán.

mt0: In the course of broadcasting and marketing in Yoruba, students learned that television is what most people call TV.

en: This coinage generates many questions and opinions — some students argue that video cameras and recorders can also be called erọ amóhùnmáwòrán based on their functionalities.

en: In 2019, Google opened its first AI research center in Accra, Ghana, focused on improving “Google Translate's ability to capture African languages more precisely,” according to CNN.

mt0: In 2019, CNN reported, Google opened its first AI research lab in Accra, Ghana, aiming to "bring Google Translate to the Eastern Hemisphere as fluent as English."

en: The ritual known as the Holy Communion or Eucharist has Orthodox Christian worshipers drinking consecrated wine by a shared spoon, while Catholics eat thin slices of bread directly from the hand of the priest.

The traditional religious practice of offering and drinking the Lord's blood or the Holy Food is a practice where believers who follow the ancient faith will often share a certain amount of poison, but although this is a practice, the Anglican Churches often served a prayer offering which is given by the altar.

en: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends avoiding large gatherings and increased levels of personal hygiene and sanitation in order to minimize the spread of the virus by touch, exchange of bodily fluids, and through the air.

yor: Nínú àtẹ̀jáde ọjọ́ 9, Iléèjọsìn Àtijọ́ Greek sọ wí pé òun kò ní yí ọwọ́ ìlànà-ìsìn padà kí ó bá ìgbésẹ̀ ààbò mu.

en: Alarms were raised when the official website of the Prespa-Pelagonia Diocese published a translated article by Russian website Pravoslavie.ru (meaning "Orthodox Christianity") claiming it's "impossible for believers to be infected during church rituals".

en: He stressed in the article that the rule of using the same spoon instituted in the 7th century Bizantium has so far done no harm, because "faith in God protects both the parishioners and the priests".

mt0: Last month, more than 7,400 people reported to have contracted COVID-19 in South Korea — a country that seems to be beginning to wipe out the disease — reported to have contracted the disease at the Shincheonji Church.

en: Meanwhile, the Orthodox Diocese of Korea announced changes in its liturgical practices in accordance with the recommendations of the Ministry of Health:
yor: Ní tirẹ̀, Àjọ Ìlànà-ìsìn Àtijọ́ ti Korea ṣe ìfilọ̀ nípa àwọn àyípadà tó dé bá ìsìn rẹ̀ ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú àfilélẹ̀ Iléeṣẹ́ Ètò Ìlera:
mt0: In its own words, the Korean Traditional Religions Association offers a detailed description of the changes that have occurred to the religion in alignment with the interpretation of the Ministry of Justice:

en: 1. During the Divine Liturgy all believers will wear masks.
yor: 1. Gbogbo onígbàgbọ́ yóò wọ ìbomúbẹnu lásìkò tí ìsìn bá ń lọ lọ́wọ́.

mt0: 2. When they enter the church, they will buy their hands with the bracelets in the church entrance.

en: 3. They will not shake hands with anyone.
yor: 3. Wọn kò ní gba ẹnìkan lọ́wọ́.
mt0: They don't take anyone.

en: 4. They will not kiss the hand of the Clergy.
yor: 4. Wọn kò ní f'ẹnu ko Àlùfáà ìjọ lọ́wọ́.
mt0: 4. They don't want to obey the law.

en: 5. They will not kiss the Icons, but they will bow before them.

mt0: 5 They don't speak to the Greeks, but they laugh at them.

en: 6. They will not use the liturgical books at the time of prayer.

mt0: 6. They don't use religious texts during prayer.

en: 7. They will not receive the Antidoron from the Clergy, but on their own as they leave the church.

en: Nigeria has confirmed five new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total number of coronavirus patients to eight,  according to the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control.

Osagie Ehanire fìdí i rẹ múlẹ̀ ní ọjọ́ 16, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na pé wọ́n ti rí ẹni kẹ́ta tí ó kó kòkòrò àìfojúrí COVID-19, ìyen "ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà kan tí ó lé ní ẹni ọgbọ̀n tí ó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ dé láti United Kingdom ní ọjọ́ 13, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na".

en: As numbers of COVID-19 cases continue to rise in Nigeria, the government has yielded to public outcry on March 18 by placing travel restrictions on citizens from 13 countries with over 1,000 domestic cases of coronavirus: China, Italy, Iran, South Korea, Spain, Japan, France, Germany, Norway, the United States, the United Kingdom, Netherlands and Switzerland.

en: Dr. Whitewalker insists that a travel ban is a normal epidemiological intervention in order to stem the tide of transmission during a pandemic like this:

en: On March 17, the Senate, Nigeria's upper legislative house, initially called for a ban on flights from coronavirus high-risk countries like the United Kingdom and China, before extending the restrictions the following day.

en: A 70-year-old woman who had spent five months in the United Kingdom returned to Nigeria, on March 11.

yor: Lẹ́yìn ìgbà díẹ̀ tí ó dé, ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní àmì àìsàn kòkòrò àrùn COVID-19 bí i òtútù àti ikun tí ó pọ̀ lápọ̀jù ní ọjọ́ 13, oṣù Ẹrẹ́na, wọ́n sì sáré gbé lọ sí Teaching Hospital ti ìpínlẹ̀ Enugu (ESUTH) Colliery Parklane, ní gúúsù ìlà-oòrùn Nàìjíríà.

en: However, in a letter written to Enugu's state governor, the woman's daughter alleged that her mother was "stigmatized" by the hospital staff who placed her in a “dilapidated” isolation centre overgrown with “grass and debris”.

en: On March 17, David Hundeyin, a journalist with News Wire, reported the poor handling of a suspected COVID-19 case at Dangote Oil Refinery Company in Ibeju-Lekki, Lagos, which has precipitated panic among workers.

mt0: In February 17, David Hundeyin, a news anchor for News Wire, reported a lack of confirmation on the claim that a person who was confirmed to have COVID-19 in the Dangote factory in Ibeju-Lekki, Ebonyi, has been tested positive for the virus.

en: On March 12, an Indian pipefitter from Dangote Refinery flew into Nigeria from Mumbai, after a brief stopover in Cairo, Egypt.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ kejìlá oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà, òṣìṣẹ́ iléeṣẹ́ Dangote kan tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ ilẹ̀ India tí ó ń tún ọ̀pá omi ṣe wá sí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà láti Mumbai, lẹ́yìn tí ó dúró díẹ̀ ní Cairo, ní orílẹ̀-èdè Egypt.
mt0: In the early February, a former Dangote employee who was a worker in India who was a tanker worker came to Nigeria from Mumbai, after a short stay in Cairo, Egypt.

en: Hudeyin's investigation revealed that the pipefitter developed "a fever, a dry cough, a sore throat and significant breathing difficulty," a day after his return from India.
yor: Ìwádìí Hudeyin fi hàn pé ọkùnrin náà tí ó ń tún ọ̀pá omi ṣe bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí i ní "ibà, ikọ́ gbígbẹ, ọ̀fun dídùn àti àìlè mí délẹ̀ ", ní ọjọ́ kejì tí ó dé láti India.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know. The investigation by Hudeyin shows that the man who was carrying the boat started to approach him with "a fever, a stomachache, a mild fever, and a lack of appetite," on the second day he came from India.

en: Yet, “it is unclear whether anyone at Dangote Refinery attempted to establish contact” with appropriate health officials.
yor: Síbẹ̀, "kò tí ì hàn bóyá ẹnikẹ́ni ní iléeṣẹ́ Dangote ti gbìyànjú láti kàn sí" àwọn elétò ìlera tí ọ̀rọ̀ náà kàn.
mt0: But "it is not clear whether anybody in Dangote's office has tried to contact" the officials who said the sentence.

en: Hudeyin further lamented that the firm took advantage of "the lax regulatory environment" in Nigeria "to put its own interests first", which puts the life of staff as well as the general public at risk.
yor: Hudeyin sọ̀rọ̀ síwájú pé ilé iṣẹ́ náà ń lo àǹfààní "àyíká òfin tí kò múnádóko tó" ní Nàìjíríà "láti fi èrè tirẹ̀ síwájú", èyí sì ń fi ẹ̀mí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ rẹ̀ àti gbogbo àwùjọ sínú ewu.

en: This report forced refinery management to release a report stating that the said patient has been moved to the Infectious Disease Hospital in Yaba, Lagos.
yor: Ìròyìn yìí mú kí iléeṣẹ́ náà gbé èrò wọn jáde pé àwọn ti gbé aláìsàn náà lọ sí ilé ìwòsàn tí wọ́n ti ń ṣètọ́jú kòkòrò Àkóràn ní Yaba, ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó.
mt0: The report led the agency to believe that the suspect was taken to the investigation center in Yaba, Ecuador.

en: How is COVID-19 reshaping the political and global future of China?

mt0: How does the coronavirus pandemic affect China's political and economic system?

en: Poster displaying a map of China on the four characters reading 武汉肺炎 meaning "Wuhan pneumonia" (which is still used in Chinese), as the epidemic was initially known, before it was given the name of COVID-19.
yor: Àwòrán tó ń fi ààlà-ilẹ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè China hàn lórí ọmọ ọ̀rọ̀ mẹ́rin tí kíkà rẹ̀ jẹ́ 武汉肺炎 tí ó túmọ̀ sí "àrùn ẹ̀dọ̀fóró Wuhan" (tí ó ṣì jẹ́ lílo ní èdè Chinese), gẹ́gẹ́ bí a ti ṣe mọ àjàkálẹ̀ náà ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀, kí ó tó yí orúkọ padà sí COVID-19.

en: Image used with permission.

en: What started at a seafood market as a local health issue has grown into a national health crisis in China.
yor: Ohun tí ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ nínú ọjà oúnjẹ inú odò, gẹ́gẹ́ bí i ọ̀ràn àìlera ìbílẹ̀, ti wá di nǹkan tó rànká Orílẹ̀-èdè China.
