en: After the Wuhan coronavirus was identified in December 2019, a chain reaction was set in motion that has profoundly shaken Chinese society and challenged Beijing’s political stability.
yor: Lẹ́yìn ìfẹsẹ̀múlẹ̀ ìjẹyọ kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà ní Wuhan nínú Oṣù Kejìlá Ọdún 2019, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ló ṣẹ̀ ní ṣísẹ̀-n-tẹ̀lé ló ṣú yọ tó sì fi àwùjọ ilẹ̀ Chinese làkàlàkà tí ó sì tún dojú ìpèníjà kọ ìdúróṣinṣin ètò ìṣèlú Beijing.
mt0: After the earthquake in Wuhan in December 2019, many events took place in the immediate aftermath of the earthquake, which further damaged the economy of China and further damaged Beijing's political stability.

en: Gripped by its obsession with information control, the Chinese government, both local and central, delayed the release of life-saving information for weeks.
yor: Kíkúndùn ìṣàkóso ìròyìn ti fún ìjọba lọ́rùn, àti ìjọba ìbílẹ̀ àti ìjọba àpapọ̀ ní àárín gbùngbùn, ló máa ń fa ìdádúró fún àgbéjáde ìròyìn tí yóò ṣe ará ìlú láǹfààní fún ọ̀sẹ̀ pípẹ́.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: When they suddenly announced drastic measures to prevent the spread of the epidemic in late January, for many it was much too late as the Chinese New Year kick-off celebrations had already begun.
yor: Nígbà tí wọ́n wá sọ jí láti ṣe ìkéde lórí àwọn ọ̀nà tí yóò dẹ́kun ìtànká àjàkálẹ̀ náà, ó ti bọ́ sórí, nítorí ayẹyẹ ọdún tuntun ìran Chinese ọlọ́dọọdún ti gbérasọ.
mt0: When they came to say to stop the disaster, it came to pass, because the Chinese New Year celebrations were over.

en: Doctors and scientists are still researching and debating the possible origin of the previously unknown Wuhan coronavirus, which causes COVID-2019, a respiratory virus that infects the lungs and can lead to pneumonia.
yor: Àwọn Dókítà àti àwọn onímọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ sì ń ṣe ìwádìí àti ìfọ̀rọ̀jomitoro-ọ̀rọ̀ lórí ohun tí ó lè jẹ́ orísun àrùn tí wọ́n mọ̀ nígbà náà lọ́hùn-ún gẹ́gẹ́ bí kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà ti Wuhan, tí ó padà wá ṣe okùnfà COVID-19, kòkòrò àìfojúrí tó ń mú kí ènìyàn má leè mí sókèsódò tí ó sì ń fa àrùn ẹ̀dọ̀fóró.
mt0: Doctors and scientists are also investigating and making predictions about what could be the source of the disease they know at the time, such as the Wuhan coronavirus, which has spread to the rest of the world and caused the spread of COVID-19, a coronavirus that causes a lack of immunity and causes a heart attack.

en: One possible theory is that it comes from snakes or bats that are consumed as a delicacy in China and were sold at the Huanan wet market in Wuhan where the virus is believed to originate.
yor: Ìdámọ̀ràn ohun tí ó lè fa sábàbí àrùn náà kan fi yé wí pé kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà jẹ yọ látàrí ẹran ejò tàbí ẹran àdán tí àwọn ará China máa ń jẹ l'óúnjẹ, tí wọ́n ń tà ní ọjà Huanan wet ní agbègbè Wuhan níbi tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ní èrò wí pé ibẹ̀ ni orísun kòkòrò àìfojúrí yìí.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: One of the key questions determining the spread of the virus is its transmissibility: whether it can jump from human to human, and how many people can be infected on average by the same virus carrier.
yor: Ìbéèrè kan tí ó nílò ìdáhùn ni ti ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ àrùn yìí: bóyá ó leè rànká láti ara èèyàn kan sí ìkejì, àti ìyè èèyàn mélòó ló leè kó àìsàn yìí látara ẹni tí ó bá ti ní i.
mt0: One question that needs answer is the way the disease is transmitted: can it be passed from one person to another, and how many lives can be lost if one person has it.

en: The latest medical evidence indicates there is human-to-human transmission, and what is concerning is that it seems to happen before the virus carrier develops symptoms, thus making detection incredibly challenging.
yor: Ẹ̀rí láti ìmọ̀ ìlera tó fẹsẹ̀múlẹ̀ ṣe ìṣípayá àrànkán láti ara ènìyàn kan sí ìkejì, tí ó fi jẹ́ wí pé kòkòrò náà yóò ti wà lágọ̀ọ́ ara fún ìgbà díẹ̀ kí ẹni tí ó kó o ó tó máa rí àwọn ààmì rẹ̀ lára, tí èyí ò sì mú mímọ ẹni tí ó bá ti lu gúdẹ àrùn náà rọrùn.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know. Scientific evidence shows that the virus remains in the body for a short time before the person who knocks it notices its symptoms, which doesn't make it easier to recognize the person who has been bitten.

en: As for the rate of transmission, called “basic reproduction number” by epidemiologists, it is believed to be between 2 to 3 in late January, meaning one person infects two to three persons, but the numbers are still being discussed and require further research should proper data be made available.
yor: Ní ti bí àrùn náà ti ń ràn, èyí tí àwọn onímọ̀ nípa àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn ń pè ní “òǹkà ìpìlẹ̀ ìbísí“, gbà pé ó wà láàárín 2 sí 3 ní ìparí Oṣù Kìn-ín-ní, ẹni tí ó ní i yóò kó o ran ẹni méjì sí mẹ́ta, ṣùgbọ́n ìfikùnlukùn àti ìwádìí kò dúró, ìyẹn bí àwọn ìwífún-alálàyè tí ó wúlò bá wà ní àrọ́wọ́tó.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: As the figure of infected people rises daily, a major health crisis has developed in China’s central province of Hubei and its capital Wuhan that have a combined population of nearly 60 million people.
yor: Bí òǹkà àwọn tí wọ́n ti ní kòkòrò yìí ṣe ń lọ sókè sí i lójoojúmó, àáríngbùngbùn Orílẹ̀-èdè China tí i ṣe Hubei àti Olú-ìlú rẹ̀ tí í ṣe Wuhan ti ní ìdojúkọ tó gogò lórí ètò ìlera, tí àpapọ̀ àwọn tí wọ́n ń gbé lágbègbè yìí sì jẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ́rùn ní ìlọ́po 60.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: As cases have been confirmed all over China, all medical staff are on alert, adding pressure on a medical system that is often insufficient for such a large and aging population.
yor: Bí iye àwọn tí ó ti kó àrùn yìí ṣe ń pọ̀ káàkiri Orílẹ̀-èdè China, àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ elétò ìlera ti wà digbí, tí wọ́n sì tún kóná mọ́ ètò ìlera tí kò sùwábọ̀ tó fún ìtọ́jú àwọn ọ̀kẹ́ àìmọye arúgbó tó kún ìlú.
mt0: Since the number of cases of the disease has increased across China, the authorities have become more efficient, and have become more aware of the lack of a vaccine for the thousands of sick people spreading the disease.

en: But the Wuhan coronavirus is not just a health crisis, it is also a major political moment of truth.
yor: Ṣùgbọ́n àrùn kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà Wuhan náà kì í ṣe ìkọlù ètò ìlera lásán, ó jẹ́ àkókò òtítọ́ ètò ìṣèlú tí ó lákaakì.
mt0: But the Wuhan earthquake is not a disaster, it is a real disaster of the economy.

en: Trust in the government that claimed there was nothing to worry about until very late in the game has eroded public confidence significantly, and not just in Hubei province.
yor: Ìgbẹ́kẹ̀lé ìjọba tí ó sọ fún àwọn ará ìlú wí pé kò s'éwu l'óko àfi gìrì àparò ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀, títí tí ẹ̀pa ò fi bóró mọ́, tí àwọn ará ìlú kò sì ní ìfọkàntán nínú àwọn ìjọba wọn mọ́, àti pé, kì í ṣe ní agbègbè Hubei nìkan ni èyí ti ṣẹlẹ̀.

en: The two Cape Verdean mobile telecommunications operators, CV Móvel and Unitel T+, announced today a joint campaign that will make available a free package of 2,000 MB of internet to encourage citizens to stay at home, as a form of prevention of COVID-19.

en: The mad rush by scientists and researchers to test potential treatments for COVID-19 in scientific trials has revived a heated debate over the use of humans in critical drug trials in Africa.

en: On April 1, two French researchers, Dr. Jean-Paul Mira and Camille Locht, suggested on a live television broadcast that trials of a potential vaccine should first take place in Africa, according to Al Jazeera.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ 1, oṣù kẹrin, àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí ọmọ ilẹ̀ Faransé méjì, Oníṣègùn Jean-Paul Mira, àti Camille Locht, dá a lábàá lórí ètò kan ní orí ẹ̀rọ-amóhùnmáwòrán wí pé Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ni ó yẹ kí wọn ó ti kókó dán egbògi àjẹsára tí yóò ká apá àrùn kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà sàn wò, gẹ́gẹ́ bí Al-Jazeera ti ṣe jíyìn ìròyìn náà.
mt0: When the 1st of April, two French researchers, Dr. Jean-Paul Mira and Camille Locht, appeared on a television program saying that the United States should have tested a vaccine that could treat the side of the tuberculosis, according to Al-Jazeera.

en: Dr. Mira, head of the intensive care unit at Cochin Hospital in Paris, compared the current situation to “certain AIDS studies, where among prostitutes, we try things because we know that they are highly exposed and don't protect themselves.”
yor: Oníṣègùn Mira, olórí ẹ̀ka ìtọ́jú àfẹ́jù ti Cochin Hospital tí ó wà ní Paris, fi ọ̀rọ̀ náà wé “àwọn ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò fún Àrùn Kògbóògùn ÉÈDÌ, tí ó jẹ́ wí pé lára àwọn olówòo nàbì ni a ti kọ́kọ́ dán an wò, a gbìyànjú àwọn nǹkan kan nítorí a mọ̀ dájú wí pé wọn kì í dá ààbò bo ara wọn, àti pé ó rọrùn fún àrùn ìbálòpọ̀ láti lúgọ sí ara wọn.”
mt0: Dr. Mira, head of the Cochin Hospital in Paris, said, "The experimental studies of the Ebola virus, which was first tested on a few patients, were focused on some things because we knew that they didn't shield themselves, and that it was easier for the virus to spread to themselves."

en: The two researchers made these comments in the context of a discussion of trials in Europe and Australia to see if the BCG tuberculosis vaccine could be effective against the novel coronavirus.
yor: Àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí méjèèjì mẹ́nu lọ́rọ́ nígbà tí àsọgbà ọ̀rọ̀ kan wáyé lórí ìṣàyẹ̀wò egbògi àjẹsára BCG fún ikọ́-àwúpẹ̀jẹ̀ ní Yúróòpù àti Australia láti mọ̀ bóyá yóò ṣiṣẹ́ ìwòsàn fún kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà àkọ́kọ́ irú ẹ̀.

en: The attitude of these researchers echoes a long, grim history of medical experimentation and exploitation in Africa, where African leaders have colluded with pharmaceutical companies — often based in Europe or the United States — to conduct trials on the most vulnerable people in society.

en: By April 3, Dr. Mira had apologized for his comments, but only after major pushback and pressure from the France-based anti-racism group SOS Racisme. Dr. Locht’s employer, however, dismissed the outrage on Twitter as "fake news", saying that the remarks had been taken out of context.
yor: Nígbà tí ó di ọjọ́ 3, Oṣù Kẹrin, Oníṣègùn Mira ti ṣe ìtọrọ àforíjì fún àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ tí ó sọ, àmọ́ lẹ́yìn tí àwọn ẹgbẹ́ SOS Racisme kọ ẹ̀yìn sí i ni ó ṣe èyí. Òṣìṣẹ́ẹ oníṣègùn Locht, bákan náà, da àwọn ẹ̀hónú orí Twitter dànù gẹ́gẹ́ bí i "ìròyìn ẹlẹ́jẹ́ ", nítorí wí pé àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ náà kò rí bí wọ́n ti ṣe ń sọ ọ́.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know On April 3, the Attorney General took a complaint over his remarks, but after the SOS Racism group called it "racist rumors." Attorney General Locht, too, called the tweets "racist rumors" because they didn't look like they were being told.

en: That same week, Congolese virologist Jean-Jacque Muyembe, who worked on the frontlines of the Ebola epidemic in Democratic Republic of Congo, announced that DR Congo "is prepared to take part in testing of any future vaccine against the coronavirus", according to News 24.
yor: Ní àárín ọ̀sẹ̀ yẹn kan náà, onímọ̀ nípa àrùn àìfojúrí ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Congo Jean-Jacque Muyembe, tí ó ń léwájú nínú ìgbógunti àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn ibà ìdà ẹ̀jẹ̀ Ebola ní orílẹ̀-èdè Ìlú Ìjọba Àwaarawa Olómìnira Congo, filọ̀ wí pé DR Congo "ti ṣe tán láti kópa nínú irúfẹ́ ìdánwò egbògi tí yóò pa kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà tí kò bá à wáyé lọ́jọ́ iwájú", bí News 24 ti jábọ̀.
mt0: In the same week, a Congolese expert on Ebola, Jean-Jacque Muyembe, who is leading the investigation of the spread of the disease in the Republic of the Democratic Republic of Congo, announced that DR Congo "is ready to take part in a trial of a drug that will kill the first cases of Ebola that will not be reported tomorrow," according to News 24.

en: Muyembe, the head of the nation’s pandemic task force and national health institute, told a news conference:
yor: Muyembe, olórí ìgbìmọ̀ amúṣẹ́ṣe lórí àjàkáyé àrùn náà àti Iléeṣẹ́ ètò ìlera orílẹ̀-èdè náà, sọ níbi àpérò àwọn oníròyìn kan:
mt0: Muyembe, a leading advisor to the crisis and the National Health Service, said in a statement to journalists:

en: We've been chosen to conduct these tests...
yor: Wọ́n ti yàn wá láti ṣe àwọn àyẹ̀wò wọ̀nyí...
mt0: They were chosen to do these researches...

en: The vaccine will be produced in the United States, or in Canada, or in China.
yor: Ìlú Ìṣọ̀kan Amẹ́ríkà tàbí Canada tàbí ní China ni a ó ti ṣe egbògi àjẹsára náà.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know Where did the drugs come from?

en: We're candidates for doing the testing here.
yor: Àwa ni ẹni ayàn fún iṣẹ́ àyẹ̀wò náà níbí.
mt0: We are the only person to do that research.

en: Once again, the remarks drew ire from Congolese citizens and netizens around the world condemning Dr. Muyembe’s openness to hosting clinical trials in DR Congo, where the rates of infection for COVID-19 are still relatively low.
yor: Lẹ́ẹ̀kan sí i, àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ wọ̀nyí fa ìrúnú àwọn ọmọ Congo àti àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára jákèjádò ilé ayé tí wọ́n dá Oníṣègùn Muyembe ní ẹ̀bí nítorí ó faramọ́ ìṣàyẹ̀wò egbògi ní DR Congo, níbi tí iye àwọn tí ó ti kó àrùn COVID-19 kò tí ì fi bẹ́ẹ̀ pọ̀.
mt0: However, these statements have caused anger among Congolese and online users across the world, because they support the investigation of drugs in DR Congo, where the number of people who have contracted COVID-19 has not gone up so much.

en: Within hours, Dr. Muyembe clarified his statements in a video message, confirming that the vaccine would only be trialed in DR Congo after it had been done in countries such as the US and China:
yor: Láàárín wákàtí díẹ̀, Oníṣègùn Muyembe yànnàná ọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ̀ nínú àwòrán-àtohùn kan, tí ó fi ìdíi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ wí pé ó di ìgbà tí wọ́n bá ti kọ́kọ́ yẹ iṣẹ́ egbògi náà wò ní US àti China ni yóò tó jẹ́ lílò ní DR Congo:
mt0: Soon after, Mr Muyembe reiterated his remarks in a statement, arguing that the first phase of the drug would be used in the US and China.

en: A grim history of medical experiment in Africa
yor: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwá tó burú jáì nípa ìdánwò egbògi ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀
mt0: The following is a very serious inquiry into drug testing in the United Kingdom. If you cannot translate it simply say you don't know.

en: Medical experimentation in Africa — often conducted under the guise of the "greater good" and of finding cures for deadly diseases like meningitis and HIV/AIDS — has sounded ethical and moral alarm bells for years — particularly over informed consent and forced medical procedures.
yor: Ìdánwò egbògi ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ — tí ó sábà máa ń wáyé lábẹ́ ẹ̀tàn "ìfẹ́ẹ gbogboògbò” tí ó pọn dandan ní ojúnà àti wá ìwòsàn fún àrùn aṣekúpani bí i àrùn yírùnyírùn àti àrùn kògbóògùn HIV/AIDS — ti lu agogo ìtanijí ìwà-ọmọlúwàbí fún àìníye ọdún — pàápàá jù lọ lórí ìgbàṣẹ lọ́wọ́ àwọn ènìyàn kí wọn ó tó ṣe ìdánwò àti ìlànà ìṣètò ìlera onítúláàsì.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: These trials are often funded by leading health organizations like the World Health Organization, the United States’ Centers for Disease Control and the National Institute of Health.
yor: Àwọn iléeṣẹ́ tí ó jẹ́ asíwájú nínú ètò ìlera lágbàáyé bí i Àjọ Elétò Ìlera Àgbáyé, Àjọ Aṣàkóso Àrùn ti orílẹ̀-èdè Amẹ́ríkà àti Iléeṣẹ́ Ètò Ìlera Ìjọba Àpapọ̀ ni ó máa ń kó owó sílẹ̀ fún irú àwọn iṣẹ́ báyìí.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: In Zimbabwe, in the 1990s, over 17,000 HIV-positive women were tested without informed consent in trials for the anti-retroviral drug AZT funded by the CDC, WHO and the NIH.
yor: Ní orílẹ̀-èdè Zimbabwe, ní àárín àwọn ọdún tí ó ré kọjá kí a tó wọ Ẹgbàá ọdún, ó lé ní 17,000 àwọn obìnrin tí ó ní àrùn kògbóògùn ni ó ṣe ìdánwò láì fi àṣẹ fún àwọn elétò ìdánwò wí pé àwọn fi ọwọ́ si í kí wọn ó lo àwọn fún iṣẹ́ ìwádìí àyẹ̀wò egbògi-agbógunti ìtànká àrùn kògbóògùn AZT lágọ̀ọ́ ara tí CDC, WHO àti NIH kó owó lé lórí.
mt0: In Zimbabwe, in the past decade, almost 17,000 women with tuberculosis have been tested without being approved by the testing teams to use them for the AZT tuberculosis screening effort which CDC, WHO and NIH have funded.

en: In the 1990s, the pharmaceutical giant Pfizer tested an experimental drug called Trovan on 200 children in Kano, Nigeria, during an epidemic of bacterial meningitis.
yor: Bákan náà ẹ̀wẹ̀, àgbà ọ̀jẹ̀ iléeṣẹ́ apooògùntà Pfizer dán oògùn kan wò tí a pè ní Trovan ní ara àwọn èwe 200 ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Kano, orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà, nígbà tí àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn yírùnyírùn ṣẹ́ yọ.
mt0: Similarly, the Pharmaceutical company Pfizer tested a drug called Trovan in 200 patients in Kano, Nigeria, when the fever started to subside.

en: Several families filed and won a lawsuit against Pfizer on the basis of violation of informed consent.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìdílé ni ó pe Pfizer ní ẹjọ́ lórí àìgbàṣẹ lọ́wọ́ àwọn kí wọn ó tó lo àwọn ọmọ àwọn fún ìdánwò.
mt0: Many families have filed suit against Pfizer over their failure to allow them to use their children for tests.

en: Medical experimentation is not only entrenched in the history of racism and colonialism — it also sets a dangerous precedent by eroding the critical trust between citizens and health authorities.
yor: Ìdánwò egbògi kì í ṣe èyí tí ó dá lórí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwá nípa ti ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà àti ìfipámúnisìn nìkan — bákan náà ni ó ń ṣe okùnfàa ìṣòro àìfọkàn tán láàárín àwọn aṣojú ètò ìlera àti ará ìlú.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: "Both European colonialism and biomedicine reciprocally extended and strengthened the reach of the other," writes Patrick Malloy in an academic paper entitled, "Research Material and Necromancy: Imagining the Political-Economy of Biomedicine in Colonial Tanganyika."
yor: Patrick Malloy kọ sí inú àpilẹ̀kọ ajẹmákadá tí a pe àkọ́lée rẹ̀ ní, "Èròjà Iṣẹ́-ìwádìí àti Ìbókùúsọ̀rọ̀: Ìgbéyẹ̀wò ìrònú nípa ètò Ìṣèlú-tòun Ọrọ̀-ajé tí ó ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ìṣoògùn ìgbàlódé ní ayé ìfipámúnisìn ní Tanganyika" pé "Àti ìfipámúnisìn àti ìṣoògùn ìgbàlódé ní í jọ ń parapọ̀ ṣe, tí ìk-ín-ní ń kín ìlọsíwájú ìkejì lẹ́yìn."
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know Patrick Malloy wrote in a book called "Research and Propaganda: Investigation of the Truth-Speaking Agenda in the Tanganyika Democratic Republic" that "the political corruption and the traditional medicine are almost always connected, one being a barrier to the other."

en: From malaria to other "plague-like" conditions, colonial authorities often subjected African subjects to the non-consensual practice of specimen-sample collection and "...African blood was appropriated to feed colonial-era medical research", Malloy writes.
yor: Láti ayée àmòdi sí ayé irú àwọn "àjàkálẹ̀-àrùn báwọ̀n-ọnnì", àwọn aṣojú ìjọba ìfipámúnisìn sábà máa ń fi àwọn Ọmọ Adúláwọ̀ ṣe ohun èlò fún ìdánwò láì gba àṣẹ, Malloy kọ pé "...ẹ̀jẹ̀ Ọmọ Adúláwọ̀ ni ó dára jù lọ láti fi bọ́ iṣẹ́ ìwádìí egbògi ayé ìjọba amúnisìn".
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: He continues:
yor: Ó tẹ̀síwájú nínú ọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ̀:
mt0: He continued in his sentence:

en: In Tanganyika as well as other African colonies, this meant that colonial subjects could be called upon to surrender tissue samples, literally portions of themselves, to the medical authorities.
yor: Ní Tanganyika àti ní apá ibòmíràn ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, èyí túmọ̀ sí wí pé ní ìgbàkúùgbà ni àwọn amúnisìn leè ké sí àwọn tí wọ́n ń jẹ gàba lé lórí láti yànda àwọn pádi ẹ̀jẹ̀, tí ó dúró fún ẹ̀yà àbùdá ara wọn fún aṣojú ètò ìlera tí yóò jẹ́ lílò fún ìdánwò.
mt0: In Tanganyika and other parts of the South African continent, this means that in the evening the hunters can invite those who are sleeping on the ground to retrieve blood samples, which remain for their own species for the chief of the testing committee.

en: These practices overlapped with horrifying rumors in East Africa about “gangs” of people employed by Europeans who would kidnap Africans to withdraw their blood to make a gum-like medicine known as mumiani.
yor: Àwọn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ báwọ̀nyí kò yàtọ̀ sí gbọ́yìí-sọ̀yìí ọ̀rọ̀ tí àwọn ènìyàn ń jẹ ní ẹnu ní Ìlà-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ nípa "àwọn ẹgbẹ́ " tí ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ fún àwọn Òyìnbó tí iṣẹ́ẹ ti wọn kò ju kí wọn ó máa jí Ọmọ Adúláwọ̀ gbé lọ láti gba ẹ̀jẹ̀ tí wọn yóò fi ṣe oògùn kan bí òjíá tí a pè ní mumiani.
mt0: If you cannot translate this sentence simply say you don't know

en: The Swahili term invokes the image of the "vampire" or "bloodletter" — which has also become synonymous with “exploitation.”
yor: Ọ̀rọ̀ ìperí ní èdèe Swahili àkàwé oògùn náà ni “amùjẹ̀” tàbí “agbẹ̀jẹ̀-fún-ìwòsàn” — tí ó ti di “ìmórí-ẹni-sábẹ̀” báyìí.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: This grim history has sown seeds of deep mistrust in vaccinations, medical trials and experiments in Africa, and continues to haunt decisions made by health authorities working in sync with government officials and global pharmaceutical companies.
yor: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwá tí ó burú jáì yìí ti gbin èso àìfọkàn tán nínú àwọn egbògi àjẹsára, ìṣàyẹ̀wò àti ìdán oògùn wò ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, tí ó sì ń farahàn nínú iṣẹ́ àwọn aṣojú ètò ìlera tí ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ papọ̀ pẹ̀lú ìjọba àti àwọn iléeṣẹ́ alooògùntà ní àgbáyé.
mt0: The recent disaster has created a significant shift in the fields of innovative medicine, research and trials in the United Kingdom, and has become a major challenge for agencies working with governments and international health organizations.

en: That 1990s meningitis trial debacle in Kano, Nigeria, sowed so much distrust that it later made it very difficult to promote critical polio testing. Anti-polio vaccine rumors flourished.
yor: Ìdánwò oògùn àrùn yírùnyírùn ìgbàa nnì ní Kano, orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, gbin ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àìnígbágbọ̀ tí kò mú kí ìpolongo ìdánwò oògùn àrùn rọmọlápárọmọlẹ́sẹ̀ ó rinlẹ̀.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. The experimental tuberculosis trial in Kano, Nigeria, created a lot of doubts that didn't lead to a announcement of a tuberculosis trial.

en: Those rumors got disseminated as news and eventually translated into a regional policy banning the polio vaccine in Nigeria in 2003.
yor: Àhesọ nípa egbògi àjẹsára agbógunti àrùn rọmọlápárọmọlẹ́sẹ̀ fọ́n ká sí ìgboro. Àwọn àhesọ ọ̀rọ̀ náà di pínpín ká bí ìròyìn tí ó ṣe atọ́nà ètò ìmúlò ìjọba agbègbè tí ó f'òfin de ìlòo egbògi àrùn rọmọlápárọmọlẹ́sẹ̀ ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ní ọdún-un 2003.
mt0: The debate about the availability of a prescription drug for tuberculosis has become increasingly polarised. The debate has become increasingly polarised as reports have taken the lead in the debate over the controversial initiative of the Nigerian government to approve the use of a prescription drug in 2003.

en: Recovering from colonial hangovers
yor: Ìmúláradá lẹ́yìn ‘orí fífọ́’ ìfipámúnisìn
mt0: Following the 'disappearance' of the prisoner, a debate took place. If you cannot translate, just say you don't know.

en: So, what does this all mean for potential COVID-19 trials in Africa?
yor: Pẹ̀lú ohun tí a ti sọ, kí ni gbogbo ìwọ̀nyí yóò fà fún ìdánwò egbògi àrùn COVID-19 ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ?
mt0: With all of the above, what will all of you want to do for the testing of the COVID-19 drug in the United States?

en: Netizens and activists have resoundingly expressed the view that “Africans are not guinea pigs.”
yor: Àwọn ènìyàn ní orí ayélujára àti ajìjàngbara gbogbo ló ti pẹnupọ̀ wí pé "àwọn Ọmọ Adúláwọ̀ kì í ṣe eku ẹmọ́ òyìnbó".
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know

en: WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has labeled the attitude of the two French doctors a "hangover" from a "colonial mentality" and declared:
yor: Ọ̀gá àgbà Àjọ Ètò Ìlera Àgbáyé (WHO) Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus ti pe ìhùwàsí àwọn oníṣègùn méjèèjì náà sí "orí fífọ́ " tí ó dá lórí “làákàyè ìfipámunisìn”, ó sì fi léde:
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Africa can't and won't be a testing ground for any vaccine.
yor: Kò leè jẹ́ Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àti pé kì í ṣe Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ni yóò jẹ́ ibi ìdánwò fún èyíkéyìí irúfẹ́ egbògi.
mt0: If you cannot translate it simply say you don't know.

en: However, deep-seated fear and distrust of medical experimentation has also turned contact tracing and testing to stem the spread of the highly contagious coronavirus into an uphill battle for health care workers.
yor: Síbẹ̀, ìbẹ̀rùbojo àti àìfọkàn tán ìdánwò egbògi ti mú kí dídá àwọn ẹni tí ó ti lùgbàdè àrùn àfòmọ́ kòkòrò àìfojúrí kòrónà mọ́ láwùjọ àti ìṣàyẹ̀wò ó nira fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ elétò ìlera.
mt0: But, the lack of a vaccine and a lack of a routine testing has led to the reduction of the number of people who have contracted the tuberculosis in the community and the investigation is difficult for authorities.

en: In Côte d'Ivoire on April 6, protesters burned down a COVID-19 testing center, claiming its location in a crowded area was not appropriate.
yor: Ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Côte d'Ivoire ní ọjọ́ 6, Oṣù kẹrin, àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ti iná bọ ibi àyẹ̀wò àrùn COVID-19 kan, ìdí tí wọ́n fi ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ ni wí pé agbègbè tí èró pọ̀ sí ni wọ́n sọrí ibi àyẹ̀wò náà sí tí kò sì bójúmu.
mt0: In Côte d'Ivoire on April 6, firefighters burned down a COVID-19 test site, because they believed the area was crowded and without oxygen.

en: The attack was "reminiscent of attitudes during Ebola outbreaks in West and Central Africa when some people attacked health workers, suspicious that they were bringing the disease to their communities, rather than offering crucial medical care", BBC reported.
yor: Iléeṣẹ́ BBC jábọ̀ wí pé, "ìkọlù náà “mú ‘ni rántí ìhùwàsí àwọn ènìyàn ní àsìkò tí àrùn ibà Ebola ń jà rọ̀ìnrọ̀ìn ní Ìwọ̀-oòrùn àti Àárín gbùngbùn Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ níbí tí àwọn kan ti ya bo àwọn oníṣẹ́ ètò ìlera, pẹ̀lú ìmúfuradání wí pé wọn ń kó àrùn náà wọ àdúgbòo àwọn, bókànràn-an kí wọ́n fún àwọn ní ìtọ́jú tí ó lẹ́tikẹ".
mt0: The BBC reported that the inquiry "has revealed the response of people in the areas where Ebola is spreading very quickly, where some people have taken advantage of officials with false accusations that they are carrying the disease into their bodies, encouraging them to get a quick treatment."

en: Yet, in the throes of the 2018 Ebola outbreak in DR Congo, critical human trials administered to Ebola patients "under an ethical framework" — under the medical guidance of Dr. Muyembe and the government of DR Congo — ultimately saved lives.
yor: Jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ, nínú rògbòdìyàn àjàkálẹ̀-àrùn ibà Ebola ọdún-un 2018 ní DR Congo, àwọn àyẹ̀wòkan àyẹ̀wòkàn tí a ṣe ní ara àwọn ẹni tí ó ti lu gúdẹ àrùn Ebola "tí ó tẹ̀lé àlàkalẹ̀ ìwà-ọmọlúwàbí kan" — lábẹ́ ìtọ́nàa Oníṣègùn Muyembe àti ìjọba orílẹ̀-èdèe DR Congo — dóòlà ẹ̀mí àwọn ènìyàn níkẹyìn.
mt0: Moreover, in the 2018 Ebola outbreak in DR Congo, a preliminary examination of the bodies of those who have contracted the disease "after a confirmed case" — under the supervision of the President Muyembe and the government of DR Congo — killed four people.

en: By November 2019, a vaccine had been approved after thousands of Congolese with Ebola were tested.
yor: Nígbà tí ó máa fi di Oṣù Kọkànlá ọdún-un 2019, tí a ti ṣe àyẹ̀wò fún ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Congo tí ó ju ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ, a fi òǹtẹ̀ lu egbògi àjẹsára kan.
mt0: Since October 2019, a study of more than a thousand Congolese people has been completed, a drug has been developed.

en: WHO was expected to declare the DR Congo Ebola-free on April 12, but after more than 50 days without a single case, a 26-year-old man contracted Ebola and died on April 10.
yor: Ó yẹ kí WHO ó ṣe ìkéde wí pé àrùn ibà ìdà ẹ̀jẹ̀ Ebola kò sí ní DR Congo mọ́ ní ọjọ́ 12 Oṣù Kẹrin, ṣùgbọ́n lẹ́yìn 50 ọjọ́ tí kò sí ẹni tí ó lùgbàdìi àrùn yìí, ọmọkùnrin tí ọjọ́ oríi rẹ̀ jẹ́ ọdún 26 kó àrùn ibà ìdà ẹ̀jẹ̀ Ebola ó sì filẹ̀ ṣ'aṣọ bora ní ọjọ́ 10 Oṣù Kẹrin.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Now, in addition to Ebola and an ongoing humanitarian crisis, DR Congo must turn its attention to mitigating the spread of the coronavirus.

mt0: In this case, amid Ebola and the growing debate about rights of youth, the DR Congo must ensure that the spread of the tuberculosis virus which is a serious threat to the health of the population is stopped.

en: There are currently 62 efforts underway to find a vaccine for COVID-19. Responsible, ethical vaccine trials take time and attention.
yor: Àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ 62 tí ó ń gbèrò láti wá egbògi àjẹsára fún àrùn COVID-19 ló ń lọ lọ́wọ́. Àyẹ̀wò àti ìdánwò egbògi àjẹsára tí yóò ṣiṣẹ́ dé góńgó tí a gbé ṣe lọ́nà tí ó bá ìwà-ọmọlúwàbí mu máa ń gba àsìkò.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know 62 efforts are under way to find a cure for COVID-19. Trials and tests for a cure that will work towards the endpoints already tested for a child-friendly vaccine are being completed.

en: Will big pharmaceutical companies maintain the same ethical standards in Africa that they usually adhere to in trials conducted in the West?
yor: Ǹjẹ́ àwọn iléeṣẹ́ apooògùntà ńlá yóò dìrọ̀ mọ́ àwọn òfin ìwà-ọmọlúwàbí ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ bí wọ́n ti ṣe ń ṣe bí wọ́n bá ń ṣe ìdánwò ní Ilẹ̀ òyìnbó?
mt0: Should large drug companies be able to adhere to the laws of child abuse in the United States as they are doing in the United Kingdom?

en: On October 22, Burundian security forces battled with an armed anti-government group — reportedly RED-Tabara, based in the Democratic Republic of Congo — around the Kibira forest border area.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 22, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà, àwọn ẹ̀ṣọ́ aláàbò Burundi wà á kò pẹ̀lú ẹgbẹ́ agbébọrìn alátakò ìjọba kan — tí à ń pè ní RED-Tabara, tí ó fi Democratic Republic of Congo ṣe ilé — ní agbègbè ibodè igbó Kibira.
mt0: In October 22, Burundian troops were fighting against a government opposition group called Red-Tabara, which is based in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

en: Armed groups have often used this area to move through the region.
yor: Àwọn ẹgbẹ́ ọlọ́tẹ̀ agbébọrìn ti máa ń fi ibí yìí kiri àgbègbè náà.

en: In the battle, 14 insurgents were said to be killed, while security forces suffered about 10 casualties.

mt0: In the clash, 14 passengers were killed, and 10 soldiers were killed.

en: Later that day, police detained the four Iwacu journalists and their driver, Adolphe Masabarakiza, when they went to report at the Musigati commune, Bubanza province, to speak to people who had fled the fighting.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ yẹn náà, àwọn ọlọ́pàá fi àwọn akọ̀ròyìn Iwacu mẹ́rin àti awakọ̀ wọn Adolphe Masabaakiza sí àtìmọ́lé, nígba tí wọn lọ kóròyìn jọ ní àdúgbò Musigati, ní Bubanza, níbi tí wọ́n ti fẹ́ bá àwọn ènìyàn tí ó sá kúrò ní àdúgbò nígbà tí ìjà náà bẹ́ sílẹ̀.
mt0: When they were going to gather at Musigati, in Bubanza, the police took the reports and their driver Adolphe Masabaakiza to prison. If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: At first, they were detained without charge, and Christine Kamikazi was reportedly hit when arrested.
yor: Lákọ̀ọ́kọ́, a fi wọn sí àtìmọ́lé láì fi ẹ̀sùn kàn wọ́n, tí a sì lu Christine Kamikazi nígbà tí wọ́n mú wọn.
mt0: First, they were taken to prison without charges, and Christine Kamikazi was killed when they were taken.

en: Police confiscated their phones and materials and the intelligence services demanded account passwords in order to search their phones.
yor: Ọlọ́pàá gba ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ àti àwọn ohun èlò iṣẹ́ wọn tí àwọn ọ̀tẹlẹ̀múyẹ́ sí béèrè fún gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé sí orí ẹ̀rọ wọn láti yẹ̀ ẹ́ wò fínnífínní.
mt0: Police have recovered the telephones and other supplies which the suspects requested to be turned on to their phones to be viewed on video.

en: The journalists were then transferred to other cells with deplorable conditions.
yor: Àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà di ẹni tí à ń gbé kiri lọ sí túbú mìíràn tí kò sunwọ̀n.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know

en: On October 26, in Bubanza province, they were finally charged with "complicity in threatening state security".
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 26 oṣù Kẹwàá, ní Bubanza, a jàjà fẹ̀sùn "Ìlọ́wọ́sí ìdúkokò mọ́ ààbò ìlú" kàn wọ́n.
mt0: In February 26, in Bubanza, a petition called "Helping to destroy the city" was filed.

en: On October 31, the public prosecutor confirmed this and accused them of having information on the insurgents’ attack.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 31, oṣù Kẹwàá, abánirojọ̀ náà fi ẹ̀rí èyí lélẹ̀ ó sì fẹ̀sùn kàn wọ́n ní pé wọ́n mọ̀ sí ìkọlù àwọn kọ̀lọ̀rànsí ẹ̀dá náà.
mt0: In October 31, the judge released the evidence and accused them of knowing about the illegal exploitation of the advice.

en: Various organizations promptly called for their release, including Human Rights Watch, International Federation of Journalists, Olucome, African Journalists’ Federation and the Association Burundaise des Radiodiffuseurs.
yor: Àwọn iléeṣẹ́ ní ẹ̀ka-ò-jẹ̀ka ni ó ti pè fún ìdásílẹ̀ wọn, títí kan Human Rights Watch, International Federation of Journalists, Olucome, African Journalists’ Federation àti Àjọ Burundaise des Radiodiffuseurs.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: However, the National Communications Council said at the time that it could not discuss the matter.
yor: Síbẹ̀, Iléeṣẹ́ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àpapọ̀ sọ wí pé àwọn kò tíì lè sọ sí ọ̀ràn náà báyìí.
mt0: But the United States Response Agency said that they cannot say whether they can provide this help.

en: Iwacu criticized this reaction, recalling that they were first held without charge and that the council is supposed to support journalists.
yor: Iwacu bu ẹnu àtẹ́ ohun tí àjọ náà sọ, ní pé wọn kò fẹ̀sùn kankan kàn wọ́n nígbà tí wọ́n mú wọn àti pé ojúṣe àjọ náà ni láti gbèjà àwọn akọ̀ròyìn.
mt0: Iwasaki rejected the sentence, saying that they didn't want to be charged when they were taken and that the sentence was simply to avoid gossip.

en: Many people expressed support online and signed a petition. International media discussed it as a threat to press freedom, while Iwacu continues to follow the situation closely.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn ní ó gbè lẹ́yìn àwọn akọ̀ròyìnnáà tí wọ́n sì fi ọwọ́ bọ ìfẹ̀sùnkàn lórí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára. Àwọn iléeṣẹ́ oníròyìn ríi gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìfojú-ẹ̀tọ̀ sí òmìnira oníròyìn gbolẹ̀, tí Iwacu sì ń tọ okùn ọ̀ràn náà lọ pẹ́kípẹ́kí.
mt0: Many people follow the reports and spread the rumors on social media. The media agencies see it as a separate agency from the news reporting agency, and Iwacu is taking the advice very seriously.

en: Journalist Esdras Ndikumana tweeted:

en: Burundi: 4 Iwacu journalists (and their driver) accused of "complicity in threatening the interior security of the state" for having covered a rebel incursion in Bubanza languish in the this province’s prisons (Drawing by Yaga)
yor: Burundi: àwọn akọ̀ròyìn Iwacu mẹ́rin (àti awakọ̀ wọn) ni a fi ẹ̀sùn "ìlọ́wọ́sí ìdúkokò mọ́ ààbò ìlú" kàn nítorí wọ́n lọ kó ìròyìn ìkọlù tí ó wá sáyé tí wọ́n sì di ẹ̀rọ ọgbà ẹ̀wọ̀n Bubanza (Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Yaga)
mt0: Burundi: Four Iwacu journalists (and their driver) have been charged with "interference in the electoral process" because they went to report a shooting that went wrong and turned into a weapons factory in Bubanza (Photo by Yaga)

en: After appealing the decision on their detention, the date for their court hearing was set for November 18, To their surprise, they were summoned on November 11, to appear before judges for questioning — but without lawyers.
yor: Lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n ti ní ẹjọ́ tí ó fi àwọn sí inú àtìmọ́lé náà kò tẹ́ àwọn lọ́rùn, a dá ọjọ́ ìgbẹ́jọ́ wọn sí ọjọ́ 18, oṣù Kọkànlá, kàyéfì ni ó jẹ́ fún wọn nígbà tí wọ́n gbé wọn lọ sílé ẹjọ́ ní ọjọ́ 11, oṣù Kọkànlá kí wọn ó wá gbọ́wọ́ pọ̀nyìn rojọ́ níwájú adájọ́ — láì sí àwọn agbẹ́jọ́rò.
mt0: After the trial which took them to the hospital did not reach the prisoners, the date of their trial was set to 18 October, and they were ordered to go to court on 11 October to appear before the judge without a jury.

en: They refused to answer without legal assistance, asking why their lawyers had not been informed beforehand, and then returned to detention, to be heard on November 18.
yor: Wọ́n kọ̀ wọn kò fèsì nítorí kò sí àwọn agbẹ́jọ́rò wọn níkàlẹ̀, wọ́n sì dá wọn padà sí àtìmọ́lé, kí ọjọ́ 18 tí a dá fún ìgbẹ́jọ́ ó kò.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: On November 20, the decision came that the four journalists would remain in detention, but the driver was provisionally released.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 20 oṣù Kọkànlá, ìpinnu dé tí wí pé àwọn akọ̀ròyìn mẹ́rẹ̀ẹ̀rin yóò padà sínú àtìmọ́lé, àmọ́ wọ́n dá awakọ̀ sílẹ̀.
mt0: In October 20, a decision came that the thirteen reporters would return to the prison, but the driver was released.

en: The prosecution originally called for a 15-year prison sentence.
yor: Ìdájọ́ tí a fún wọn tó ọdún 15 nínú ẹ̀wọ̀n.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: President Pierre Nkurunziza said during a press conference on December 26 that he wanted a fair trial but he could only intervene as a last resort, even though he could use his power to grant a presidential pardon.
yor: Ààrẹ Pierre Nkurunziza sọ níbi àpéjọ àwọn akọ̀ròyìn kan tí ó wá sáyé ní ọjọ́ 26 oṣù Kejìlá wí pé ohun ohun kò ní fẹ́ dídijú mọ́rí dájọ́ àmọ́ ó dìgbà tí a bá ti ṣánpá tí kò ṣe é ṣán mọ́ ni òun yóò tó ká a lérí, pẹ̀lú pé ó lè fi àṣẹ tí ó ń bẹ ní ìkáwọ́ rẹ da ẹjọ́ náà nù.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: On January 30, in Bubanza, the four journalists were sentenced to two and a half years in prison and a fine of a million francs each ($521 United States dollars) under article 16 of the Penal Code, while the driver was acquitted.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ 30, oṣù Kìn-ín-ín ní Bubanza, a rán to àwọn akọ̀ròyìn mẹ́rẹ̀ẹ̀rin náà lọ sí ẹ̀wọ̀n ọdún méjì àti àbọ̀ pẹ̀lú kí ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan ó sanwó ìtanràn ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún owó francs ($521 owó orílẹ̀ èdè Amẹ́ríkà) lábẹ́ òfin 16 ti Òfin Ọ̀daràn, tí awakọ̀ sì gba ilé-e rẹ̀ láì sanwó ìtanràn.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know On 30 January in Bubanza, the thirteen journalists were sent to prison for two years and a sentence of a thousand francs (US$521) under Article 16 of the Criminal Code, and the driver took his house without paying a sentence.

en: The prosecution could not prove any actual link or contact with the rebels, so the charge was changed to "impossible attempt at the complicity in undermining state security", that is — that they intended to threaten state security but it was not possible.
yor: Ìdájọ́ náà kò fi hàn ní pàtó wí pé àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà mọ ohunkóhun nípa ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà, látàrí èyí ẹ̀sùn náà yíra padà di "ìgbésẹ̀ ìlọ́wọ́sí ìdúkokò mọ́ ààbò ìlú tí kò ṣe é ṣe", ìyẹn ni pé — wọ́n pète láti dúnmọ̀rurumọ̀ruru mọ́ ààbò ìlú àmọ́ ó ṣòro láti gbé ṣe.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: Iwacu pointed out that the reporters went to the area after authorities had publicly mentioned the incident, were accredited, and there were no restrictions on the area.
yor: Iwacu ṣàlàyé wí pé àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà lọ síbi ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà lẹ́yìn tí àwọn aláṣẹ tí fi léde, wọ́n gba ìwé àṣẹ kò sì sí òfin tí ó ní kẹ́nìkan ó máa dé agbègbè ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: The key element used as evidence against the journalists was a WhatsApp message sent by one of the reporters to a friend, which said they were going to "help the rebels".
yor: Ẹ̀rí kan ṣoṣo tí wọ́n rí dìmú tí ó kó àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà sí yáwúyáwú ni àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ orí WhatsApp tí ọ̀kan lára àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà fi ṣọwọ́ sí ọ̀rẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ kan, tí ó sọ wí pé àwọn fẹ́ lọ "ran àwọn ọlọ́tẹ̀ ìjọba náà lọ́wọ́ ".
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: They argued it was clearly a dry joke —  the government has often conflated critics, political opponents, and armed groups to justify generalized crackdowns. But the text was taken literally as evidence against them.
yor: Àmọ́ ẹ̀fẹ̀ lásán ni wọ́n fi ṣe — ìjọba ti máa ń sábà kó àwọn alátakò, ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú àti àwọn agbébọnrìn papọ̀ láti jàre irú ìgbésẹ̀ báyìí. the àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ náà ni a fi kàn wọ́n mọ́lẹ̀.
mt0: But they're using a weak desire. The government often uses agencies, political parties and travelers to fight such a situation.

en: Reporters Without Borders (RSF) said the journalists should be able to report on sensitive topics without fear of reprisals, particularly ahead of Burundi's May 20 election.
yor: Reporters Without Borders (RSF) sọ wí pé àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà lẹ́tọ̀ọ́ láti jábọ̀ ìròyìn tí ó kan gbogbo ìlú gbọ̀ngbọ̀n láì fòyà ìgbẹ̀san, papàá ní ìgbaradì ìbò orílẹ̀-èdèe Burundi ọjọ́ 20 oṣù karùn-ún tí ó ń bọ̀ lọ́nà.
mt0: Reporters Without Borders (RSF) says the journalists are entitled to report the spread of rumors across the country without a border fence, but in the Burundian presidential election on 20 October.

en: They made a petition calling for their release, which had almost 7,000 signatures in early May.
yor: Wọ́n kọ ìwé ìfẹ̀sùnkànni kan tí ó ń pè fún ìdásílẹ̀ wọn, èyí tí ènìyàn tí ó tó 7,000 tọwọ́bọ̀ ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ oṣù Karùn-ún.
mt0: They wrote a letter calling for their registration, which 7,000 people signed in the beginning of March.

en: European Union deputies, the European Parliament, and UN human rights experts are among those who called for their release.
yor: Àwọn igbá-kejì àjọ European Union, Ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba Yúróòpù, àti àwọn àgbà UN nípa ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn wà lára àwọn tí ó ti pè fún ìdásílẹ̀ wọn.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know The European Union, the European Council, and the United Nations on human rights are among those who have been called to submit their proposals.

en: On February 20, the journalists appealed, questioning the quality of the legal process, including the change to the original charge without proper notification.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ 20 oṣù Kejì, àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà ní ìdájọ́ náà kò-tẹ́ àwọn lọ́rùn, tí wọ́n sọ wí pé aláìṣẹ̀ ni wọ́n ń fìyà jẹ, àti àyípadà pàjáwìrì tí ó déédéé bá ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n kọ́kọ́ fi kàn wọ́n.
mt0: On February 20, the reports said the court had rejected the cases, saying they were being treated as illegally, and a change of sentence that was consistent with the first charge.

en: On May 6, the journalists appeared at an appeal hearing, after approximately six months in jail.

en: After controversial 2015 elections — in which Nkurunziza returned for a third term that many argued as unconstitutional — there was a failed putsch. The media environment quickly deteriorated.
yor: Lẹ́yìn ètò ìdìbò tí ó dá wàhálà sílẹ̀ ti ọdún-un After 2015 — èyí tí ó gbé Nkurunziza padà sípò fún ìgbà kẹta tí àwọn ènìyàn sọ wí pé ó tasẹ̀ àgbẹ̀rẹ̀ sófin — ìfipágbàjọba tí kò yọrí sí rẹ. Iṣẹ́ àwọn akọ̀ròyìn de polúkúmuṣu.
mt0: After the controversial 2015 election - which brought Nkurunziza back to power for the third time - the government failed to reach agreement. The press work went on.

en: Several radios stations — the most relied upon for information in Burundi — were closed and some were attacked. Dozens of journalists fled and some suffered torture, such as Esdras Ndikumana.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iléeṣẹ́ agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ — tí àwọn ènìyàn fẹ́ràn fún ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ ìròyìn tí kò figbákanbọ̀kan ní Burundi — ni a ṣán pa. Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ akọ̀ròyìn lló júbà ehoro tí àwọn mìíràn bíi Esdras Ndikumana jẹ mo-yó-ìyà
mt0: Many broadcast channels — which people wanted to help with Burundi's unreliable news — were destroyed. Many journalists were killed, while others like Esdras Ndikumana were innocent.

en: Numerous journalists have also experienced violence from security forces, particularly when reporting on topics deemed “sensitive” by the state.
yor: Ọ̀gọ̀rọ àwọn akọ̀ròyìn ni ó ti ní ìrírí ìyà lọ́wọ́ àwọn ẹ̀sọ́ agbófinró ìlú, pàápàá jù lọ bí wọ́n ń bá kó ìròyìn tí ó “pọn dandan” jọ.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: In late 2015, cameraman Christophe Nkezabahizi was killed by police along with three family members, in an operation against protests after the contentious election.

mt0: In 2015, police killed photographer Christophe Nkezabahizi with three children in a riot that ended with a murder claim.

en: In July 2016, Jean Bigirimana was forcibly disappeared, reportedly arrested by intelligence services (SNR), with a limited police investigation.

mt0: In July 2016, Jean Bigirimana became a suspect, it is likely that the Ministry of Natural Resources (SNR) killed him, without having the police investigate the case.

en: This year, on January 16, reporter Blaise-Pascal Kararumiye with Radio Isanganiro (Meeting Point Radio) was arrested following a report on local government finances. On April 28, journalist Jackson Bahati was hit by a police officer while reporting.

en: International media have not been spared, with BBC and VOA banned in 2019. RSF ranked Burundi 160 of 180 countries for press freedom — down 15 from 2015.

en: In Nigeria, the political advocacy sphere is a caustic landmine.

en: Advocates with a strong social media presence — especially on Twitter — have to develop a tough skin to deal with the avalanche of gbas gbos (Nigerian Pidgin for “throwing punches”) in digital spaces.

en: Two online social media movements in Nigeria lend powerful insights into the experiences of advocacy and gender: The #BringBackOurGirls movement, led by Dr. Oby Ezekwesili; and #ArewaMeToo, led by Fakhriyyah Hashim, both experienced gendered political hatred that greatly affected the integrity of their messages.
yor: Àwọn ajìjàgbara orí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà méjì ní Nàìjíríà fi ìrírí àwọn àgbàwí àti ìkórìíra ìwà abo hàn: #BringBackOurGirls, tí Dókítà Oby Ezekwesili jẹ́ aṣíwájú; àti #ArewaMeToo, tí Fakhriyyah Hashim jẹ́ agbátẹrù, gbogbo wọn ni wọ́n ní ìrírí ìkórìíra tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin abo nínú agbo òṣèlú tí ó ń fa ìlọsíwájú wọn sẹ́yìn.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. The two petitions in Nigeria showed a lack of equality and equality among citizens: #BringBackOurGirls, which is led by the Democratic Party's Oby Ezekwesili; and #ArewaMeToo, which is led by Fakhriyah Hashim, all of which showed a lack of equality among citizens in the government that led to their removal.

en: Six years ago, on April 15, 2014, about 200 school girls between the ages of 15 and 18, were forcefully abducted by Boko Haram, an Islamist terrorist group, from Government Girls Secondary School in Chibok near Maiduguri, in northeast Nigeria.

en: Dr. Obiageli (Oby) Ezekwesili, a former vice president of the World Bank, and one-time minister of education in Nigeria, started tweeting about the Chibok girls the day they were kidnapped.

en: She was motivated to take action due to a previous attack on schoolboys at the Federal Government College of Buni Yadi in Yobe State, northeastern Nigeria on February 25, 2014.

en: However, it was not until April 23, when, as a guest at a UNESCO event in Port Harcourt, in the oil-rich Niger Delta region, did her cry for the release of the schoolgirls grab national and international attention:

mt0: However, until the 23rd of October, when UNESCO took it under its supervision in Port Harcourt, a site filled with oil in the Niger Delta region, it has been allowed to become a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

en: And on May 7, 2014, former American first lady Michelle Obama posted an image of herself on Twitter holding a sign with the hashtag #BringBackOurGirls.

en: By October 2016, 21 girls were reunited with their families. And by May 2017, Boko Haram militants released 82 girls from captivity.

yor: Adamua, ẹni tí ó ń gbé ní ìpínlẹ̀ Kano tí í ṣe àríwá-ìlà-oòrùn orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà, ti ṣáájú kọ búlọ́ọ̀gù nípa ìrírí rẹ̀ tí ó banilẹ́rù.

mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: #ArewaMeToo became northern Nigeria’s version of the global #MeToo movement. (Arewa is the Hausa word for “North”) — igniting a storm of online discussion on rape and other forms of gender-based violence.
yor: #ArewaMeToo di ẹ̀dà ìgbésẹ̀ Èmi Náà àgbáyé #MeToo ní àríwá Nàìjíríà. (Árẹ̀wá ni èdè-ìperí fún “Àríwá” ní èdè Haúsá) — tí ó tan ìjì àsọgbà ọ̀rọ̀ lórí ìfipábánilòpọ̀ àti irú àwọn ìwà-ipá sí àwọn obìnrin ní orí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-wọn-bí-ajere.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: Violence against women is rampant throughout Nigeria. However, Relief Web asserts that between November 2014 and January 2015, northeastern Nigeria, especially Borno State, recorded the most violence against women.
yor: Ìwà-ipá sí obìnrin wọ́pọ̀ jákèjádò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà. Síbẹ̀, Relief Web sọ wí pé ní àárín oṣù Belu ọdún-un 2014 àti oṣù Ṣẹẹrẹ ọdún un 2015, àríwá-ìlà-oòrùn Nàìjíríà, pàápàá jù lọ Ìpínlẹ̀ Borno, ní àkọsílẹ̀ ìwà-ipá sí obìnrin ti pọ̀ jọjọ.
mt0: Female rape is common in Nigeria. However, Relief Web says in the period between October 2014 and April 2015, northern Nigeria, particularly in Borno, had a record number of female rape cases.

en: In the Muslim-majority north, discussions about these taboo topics are difficult, often forcing victims into silence.
yor: Ní agbègbè àríwá tí àwọn Mùsùlùmí pọ̀ sí jù lọ, àsọgbà nípa orí ọ̀rọ̀ èèwọ̀ wọ̀nyí ṣòro, tí ó máa pàpà sọ àwọn tí ó ń jìyà ìpalára sì ìpa kẹ́kẹ́.

en: The online rage of #ArewaMeToo propelled the NorthNormal offline protests in Bauchi, Kano, Niger.

en: According to Hashim, NorthNormal grew out of the #ArewaMeToo hashtag, and has two objectives: advocating for “the domestication of the Violence against Persons Prohibition Act (VAPP),” and championing the conversation on “various forms of gender-based violence and rape culture across northern Nigeria.”
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Hashim ti ṣe wí, NorthNormal súyọ láti ara àmì #ArewaMeToo, tí ó sì ní èta méjì: ìgbàwí fún "ìṣàmúlò Ìfòfinde Ìwà-ipá sí àwọn Ènìyàn (VAPP)", àti ìléwájú nínú ìtàkùrọ̀sọ "onírúurú ìwà-ipá sí obìnrin àti àṣà ìfipábánilòpọ̀ jákèjádò àríwá Nàìjíríà".
mt0: As Hashim said, NorthNormal has withdrawn from the #ArewaMeToo movement, which has two sections: a call for "voluntary assistance to victims of sexual exploitation (VAPP)", and a stance on "the spread of sexual exploitation and prejudice against women and women in Nigeria".

en: The Violence Against Persons (Prohibition) Act 2015 was signed into law on May 23, 2015.
yor: Àbà Òfin Ìwà-ipá sí Àwọn Ènìyàn (Ìfòfindè) ọdún-un 2015 di títọwọ́bọ̀ lọ́jọ́ 23, oṣù Èbìbí, ọdún-un 2015.

en: Under the VAPP Act — an improvement on the provisions of Nigeria’s penal code — acts of violence against women are punishable offences.

en: Though I mustered all of that and did not retreat to any cave, I did begin feeling demoralised about Northern Nigeria’s governanace and response to sexual violence...
yor: Àmọ́pé mo fi gbogbo rẹ̀ ṣe osùn mo fi para n ò sì jẹ́ kí ó fà mí sẹ́yìn, mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní í ní ìrẹ̀wẹ̀síọkàn nípa ìṣèjọba Àríwá orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà àti bí wọ́n ṣe fi ọwọ́ mú ìwà ìfipábánilò...
mt0: But I took it all for a joke and didn't let it get to me, I started to have a serious understanding of the government of Nigeria and how they took control of the illegal immigration system.

en: After every episode of attacks, we did gather more strength and energy to push back because the backlash made us see how society enforced the culture of silence and if we allowed our lips to be sealed then that would be the real tragedy.
yor: Lẹ́yìn ìkọlù kọ̀ọ̀kan, a máa ń ní okun àti agbára láti tẹ̀síwájú nítorí ìtakò mú wa rí bí àṣà ìdákẹ́ rọrọ ti ṣe rinlẹ̀ tó ní àwùjọ àti pé bí a bá fi àyè gba ìpanumọ́, a jẹ́ wí pé oko ìparun ni à ń fi orí lé.
mt0: After each loss, we have the strength and energy to continue because the shock has shown us how the culture of silence has become a norm and that if we allow for silence, we are going to be a waste of time.

en: Sadly, Hashim and Ezekwesili still struggle with the excruciating "lack of empathy" that characterises discourse about gender-based violence on- and offline.
yor: Ó ṣeni láàánú, Hashim àti Ezekwesili ṣì ń janpata pẹ̀lú ìyà “àìsí àánú ọmọlàkejì” tí ó dìrọ̀ mọ́ ọ̀ràn ìwà ìjìyà àwọn obìnrin lórí ayélujára àti lójú ayé tòótọ́.
mt0: If you cannot translate, Hashim and Ezekwesili simply say you don't know.

en: According to Hashim, this "deliberate maligning of a cause that only seeks better for victims of sexual violence" is incredibly difficult to grasp.
yor: Ní ti Hashim, "ìmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ ṣààta ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó ń gbèrò láti fi ohùn fún àwọn tí ó ń jìyà ìfarapa" nira láti gbá mú.
mt0: In Hashim's case, "the knowledge but especially the work he is trying to convey to those who are fighting" is difficult to get.

en: This article is part of the project, "the identity matrix: platform regulation of online threats to expression in Africa".
yor: Àròkọ yìí jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àkànṣe iṣẹ́, "Orísun ìdánimọ̀: òfin gbàgede orí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára bí ajere tí ń gbégi dínà ìdàgbàsókè ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ ní Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀".
mt0: This article is one of the sections of the work, "Source of evidence: the regulation of the Internet as a business that uses a gateway to lower the growth rate of speech in the United States."

en: These posts interrogate identity-driven online hate speech or discrimination based on language or geographic origin, misinformation and harassment (particularly against female activists and journalists) prevalent in the digital spaces of seven African countries: Algeria, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Sudan, Tunisia and Uganda.
yor: Àtẹ̀jáde yìí ṣe ìbéèrè ipa ìdánimọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin tàbí ìyàsọ́tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ tí ó dá fìrìgbagbòó lórí èdè tàbí agbègbè ilẹ̀ ayé, àṣìwífún àti ìyọlẹ́nu (pàápàá jù lọ ìyọlẹ́nu àwọn ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọnìyàn àti akọ̀ròyìn l'óbìnrin) lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára bí ajere tí ó wọ́pọ̀ ní orílẹ̀ èdè Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ méje: Algeria, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Sudan, Tunisia àti Uganda.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: The project is funded by the Africa Digital Rights Fund of The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA).
yor: Africa Digital Rights Fund ti Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA) ni ó kówó fún à kànṣe iṣẹ́ yìí.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know Africa Digital Rights Fund of Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA) is funding this project.

en: In Assad-controlled Syria, the official narrative is ‘no COVID-19 cases’
yor: Ní àwọn ìlú tí ó wà lábẹ́ ìsàkóso Assad ní ilẹ̀ Syria, àwọn alákòóso sọ báyìí pé ‘kò sí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ààrùn kòrónà kankan’
mt0: In Syria, under the rule of Assad, officials say that there is no infection of the virus.

en: After nine years of a deadly civil war, the health system in Syria is barely functional.
yor: Lẹ́yìn ọdún mẹ́sàn-án ogun abẹ́lẹ́ tó gbóná girigiri, ètò ìlera ní orílẹ̀-èdè Syria ò ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ gbópọn mọ́.
mt0: After a decade of fighting, the political situation in Syria has not changed.

en: In territories controlled by President Bashar al-Assad, authorities deny the presence of COVID-19.
yor: Ní àwọn ìlú tí ó wà lábẹ́ ìsàkóso Ààrẹ Bashar al-Assad, àwọn Aláṣẹ wọn ti tako ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ààrun COVID-19.
mt0: In cities under the rule of Bashar al-Assad, the authorities have rejected the coronavirus outbreak.

en: According to Johns Hopkins University, the country has confirmed 439 cases and 21 deaths as of July 15.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Fáfitì John Hopkins ̣ sọ, Orílẹ̀-èdè ọ̀hún ti sàwárí ìsẹ̀lẹ̀ Òjìlénírinwó-dínkan pẹ̀lú ikú ènìyàn mọ́kànlélógún títí di ọjọ́ kẹẹ̀ẹ́dógún osù Agẹmọ.
mt0: According to John Hopkins, the United States has searched for the disaster of Hurricane Irma with the death of 11 people until the end of August.

en: But narratives on the ground reveal the ways in which the state has denied and repressed the realities of COVID-19.
yor: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ìròyìn tí ó wà nílẹ̀ báyìí tí ṣe àfihàn bí ilẹ̀ náà ṣe takú wọnle tí wọ́n sì ń ṣẹ́ ìdánilójú pé ààrùn COVID-19 wà lóòótọ́.
mt0: But the reports in this country show that the country is stable and that they are making a claim that the COVID-19 virus is present.

en: Walid Abdullah, 23, says the state has even gone so far as to suggest terminating the lives of suspected COVID-19 patients.
yor: Walid Abdullah ọmọ ọdún mẹ́tàlélógún, sọ ọ́ di mímọ̀ pé ìlẹ̀ yìí tilè ṣe é débi pé wọ́n ń dába gbígba ẹ̀mí àwọn aláàárẹ̀ tí wọ́n bá funra sí pé wọ́n ní COVID-19.
mt0: Walid Abdullah, a 28-year-old man, told him that the country is going to be able to afford to kill those who claim to have COVID-19.

en: Global Voices is using a pseudonym upon request to protect his identity.
yor: Ohùn Àgbáyé ń lo orúkọkórúkọ láti dààbò bó.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Speaking to Global Voices by phone, Abdullah explained that on May 13, he called Daraa National Hospital, in southern Syria, to inform them about a suspected case of coronavirus.
yor: Nínú ìtàkùrọsọ pẹ̀lú Ohùn Àgbáyé lórí ago, Abdullah ṣe é ní àlàyé pé ní ọjọ́ kẹtàlá ọsù èbìbí, òun pé Ilé ìwòsàn Àpapọ̀ ti Daraa ní ìha Gúúsù ilẹ̀ Syria láti fi ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ààrun kòrónà kan tó wọn létí.
mt0: In a statement to the World on the Air, Abdullah said that on the 15th of October, he told the United Nations Monitoring Center in Daraa in southern Syria to report a nuclear disaster.

en: When he asked what steps should be taken, the government hospital employee who answered the phone said: "Shoot him — we have no cure for him", according to Abdullah.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Abdullah ṣe sọ, nígbà tí ó bèèrè ìgbésè tí ó yẹ ní gbígbé, òṣìṣẹ́ ìjọba tí ó gbé ìpè náà sọ pé " Yìnbọn pà á, a kò ní ìwòsàn fún"
mt0: Abdullah said, when he asked for the necessary steps for the evacuation, the official who received the call said "No, we don't know."

en: He quickly ended the call.
yor: Ó yára fi òpin sí ìpè náà.
mt0: He ended the conversation.

en: Obviously, the idea of shooting a suspected COVID-19 patient was out of the question.
yor: Dájú, kò sí ọ̀rọ̀ nínú yíyin ìbọn pa ẹni tí a fura sí pé ó ní àrun COVID-19.
mt0: However, there is no evidence of a fatal shooting of a person who is suspected of having COVID-19.

en: "Death by COVID-19 is more honorable than to set foot in any public hospital",  Abdullah told Global Voices.
yor: Abdullah sọ fún Ohùn Àgbáyé "Ikú nípasẹ̀ COVID-19 sàn ju dídá ẹsẹ̀ wọ ilé ìwòsàn ìjọba lọ"
mt0: Abdullah told the World News "Deaths from COVID-19 are more than a foot's worth of admissions to the government office."

en: This harrowing testimony is corroborated by other sources.
yor: Èrí ìbanilọ́kanjẹ́ eléyìí tún kín in lẹ́yìn láti àwọn orísun mìíràn.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: In a March 10 report published in The Voice of the Capital, an independent Syrian newspaper, medical personnel from the Syrian Ministry of Health claimed that "deliberate termination operations are taking place at the al-Mujtahid government hospital in the capital, Damascus, for those who are believed to be carrying the virus, through giving them additional doses of the drug [anesthetic]".
yor: Àtẹ̀jáde ọjọ́ kẹwàá, oṣù Ẹrénà kan ti The Voice of the Capital, Iwé ìròyìn Olómìnira kan ní ilẹ̀ Syria sọ di mímọ̀, pé àwọn elétò ìlera láti Ilé-iṣẹ́ Ètò Ìlera ilẹ̀ Syria sọ pé "Iṣẹ́ Ìmọ̀-ọ́n-mọ̀ṣekúpani ń wáyé ní ilé ìwòsàn ìjọba Al-Mujtahid ní olú ìlú ilẹ̀ náà, Damascus, fún àwọn tí wọ́n ní ìgbàgbọ́ pé wọ́n ní àrùn ọ̀hún ní tòótọ́, nípa fífún wọn ní àpọ̀jù oògùn tí ó máa ń rani níy"è.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: This claim also appeared on social media:
yor: Èyí pẹ̀lú fi ara hàn ní orí ìkànnì alátagbà:
mt0: This is especially true in the early hours of the morning.

en: Another person from al-Mouwasat Hospital in Damascus was also quoted in the same article confirming this claim:
yor: Ẹlòmìíràn láti ilé ìwòsàn Mouwasat ni Damascus ni ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ tún jẹ́ dídì mọ́ ọwọ́ nínú àtẹ̀jáde kan náà tí ó sọ pé:
mt0: A spokesman from the Mosque of Mouwasat in Damascus also cited his words in a statement saying:

en: "These terminations are conducted in complete secrecy and are carried out by doctors dedicated to following up on cases of suspected virus infection".
yor: "Iṣẹ́ Ìmọ̀-ọ́n-mọ̀ṣekúpani ń wáyé ní ibi kọ́lọ́fín pátápátá, àwọn dókìtà tí wọ́n ṣe iṣẹ́ ìtọpinpin àrùn ọ̀hún ni wọ́n sì ń ṣe é".
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: The Assad regime's desperate approach to dealing with COVID-19 parallels callous strategies used in Assad’s war, which left 586,100 people dead, nearly 100,000 detained and forcibly disappeared, and 5.6 million refugees around the world.
yor: Ìgbésẹ̀ sáà ìṣèjọba Assad sí ìdẹ́kun àrùn COVID-19 yìí burú jáì, ó fi ara jọ ète tí wọ́n lò nígbà Ogun abẹ́lé Assad tí ó gba èmí ènìyàn tí ó lé díẹ̀ ní mílíọ̀nù, tí Ẹgbẹ̀rún lónà ọgọ́rùn-ún tí ó wà látìmọlé parẹ́ síbẹ̀, tí mílíọ́nù márùn-ún àbọ̀-ó-lẹ́ sì di ogunléndé káàkiri àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè àgbáyé.

en: Virus outbreak and regime survival
yor: Ìbẹ́sílẹ̀ Àjàkálẹ̀ Àrùn àti Ìtèsíwájú Ìsèjọba
mt0: The beginning of the epidemic and the opposition to government

en: The Assad regime owes its survival to its key allies, including Iran. With few allies in the region, Iran has leaned on Syria as well.
yor: Sáà ìṣèjọba Assad yìí ti sọ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ìlú tí ó yí i ká sínú ìdààmú tí ó fi mọ́ orílẹ̀-èdè Iran náà, pẹ̀lú bí ó ṣe jẹ́ pé ilẹ̀ Syria ni ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ìlú tí ó yí i ká fi ń mí.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: In February, Iran became one of the world's most COVID-19 affected countries and is a likely source of infection in Lebanon, Iraq and Syria, where Iranian troops have had physical contact through military cooperation.
yor: Ní osù Èrèlé, Orílẹ̀-èdè Iran di ọ̀kan nínú àwọn orílè-èdè tí Covid-19 ti ṣọṣẹ́ jùlo, ìbi tí ààrùn náà gbà wọ ilẹ̀ wọn ni ó ṣeéṣe kí ó jẹ́ Lebanon, Iraq àti Syria, níbi tí ìfarayíra ti ṣelẹ̀ nípasẹ̀ àjọṣepọ̀ àwọn Ológun.
mt0: In the month of April, Iran became one of the most affected countries by Covid-19, where the spread of the disease is likely to be Lebanon, Iraq and Syria, where sanctions have been imposed by the United Nations.

en: Additionally, Iranian pilgrims and religious tourists, continued to visit Damascus-based shrines up until the first week of March, as reported by Zaki Mehchy, co-author of a March study published by the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE).
yor: Ní àfikún, àwọn Arìnrìnàjò-ẹ̀sin àti àwọn Arìnrìnàjò-ìgbafẹ́ láti Iran náà tẹ̀síwájú láti máa ṣe àbẹ̀wọ̀ sí àwọn ojúbọ ní Damascus títí di ọ̀ṣẹ̀ kíní osù ẹrénà (march) gẹ́gẹ́ bí Zaki Mechy tí ó jẹ́ ara àwọn Òǹkòwé March Study ti London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) ṣe sọ.
mt0: In the meantime, religious and religious visitors from Iran are planning to visit Damascus until the end of March, according to Zaki Mechy, a member of the March Study Group of the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE).

en: However, the Assad regime has pursued a policy of misinformation, prevarication and denial in terms of the number of COVID-19 casualties.
yor: Síbẹ̀, Ìṣèjọba Assad ń tẹpẹlẹ mọ́ sísọ òfegè ìròyìn àti irọ́ lórìṣirísi bẹ́ẹ̀ ni ó tún ṣe àdínkù iye àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ti ní COVID-19.
mt0: But the government of Assad is keeping a close eye on rumors and lies about the situation and has also reduced the number of people who have COVID-19.

en: In a March 13 interview with the official Syrian News Channel, Minister of Health Nizar Al-Yaziji insisted on denying the existence of any COVID-19 cases in Syria, saying:
yor: Ní ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwọ̀ pẹ̀lú ẹ̀ka ìròyìn ìjọba ilẹ̀ Syria ní ọjọ́ kẹtàlá Osù Ẹrẹ́nà, Mínísítà ètò ilera ilẹ̀ náà Nizar Al-Yaziji kọ̀jálẹ̀ lórí pé kò sí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ COVID-19 ní ilẹ̀ Syria, ó sọ pé:
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: "Thank God that the Syrian Arab Army has cleansed the Syrian soil from many germs:"
yor: "A dúpé̩ ló̩wó Ọló̩run pé àwọn È̩ka Ológun ti fọ ilè̩ Syria mó kúrò ló̩wó̩ àrùnkárùn:”
mt0: We are certain that the Eighth Empire has taken Syria out of the war.

en: The Syrian Ministry of Health did not announce its first case of COVID-19 until March 22, causing resentment and anger among Syrians who noted that the Assad regime lied and pursued a policy of denial.
yor: Mínísítà ètò ìlera ilè̩ Syria kò tilè̩ kéde ìṣè̩lè̩ ààrùn COVID-19 àkó̩kó̩ ilè̩ náà títí di ọjó̩ kejìlélógún Osù Ẹré̩nà (March 22), èyí si ń fa ìbínú àti ìtutọ́sókè fojú gbà á ní àárín àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Syria tí wọ́n ṣe àkíyèsí pé ìṣèjọba Assad ń parọ́, ó si ń tako ìròyìn ododo.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: In an article published on an independent  Syria 24 news site in response to Yaziji’s claims, one citizen poignantly asked, "didn’t you say in your statement that all germs have been eliminated?"
yor: Nínú ìwé àpilẹ̀kọ tí wọ́n fi sí orí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà-oníròyìn kan ní ilẹ̀ náà, ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ará ìlú fèsì sí ọ̀rọ̀ Yaziri, ó sọ pé “ṣé o kò sọ nínú ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ tẹ́lẹ̀ pé gbogbo àrùn ni ó ti jẹ́ fífọ̀ kúrò ni"
mt0: In a newspaper article, one of the residents of the city asked Yaziri, "hasn't you told me before that all the infections have been removed?"

en: However, the regime has continued to report implausibly low numbers.
yor: Síbẹ̀ náà ìṣèjọba yìí ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní sí ṣe àdíkù òǹkà iye àwọn tí wọ́n ní àrùn náà nínú àtẹ̀jáde wọn.
mt0: But the government has started to increase the number of people with the disease in their reports.

en: In a statement dated April 1, the Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces called on the international community to put pressure on the regime to disclose verified data regarding COVID-19 cases.
yor: Nínú àtẹjáde kan tí ọjọ́ kíní osù Igbe Àjọ tí ó pè fún Àtúnṣe Ìṣejọba Syria àti àwọn Ẹgbẹ́ Alátakò késí àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè àgbáyé láti fíná mọ́ ìṣejọba ọ̀hún, pé kí wọn ó gbé òótọ́ òǹkà iye àwọn tí wọ́n ní àrùn COVID-19 jáde.
mt0: In a statement dated early this month, the Syria Transitional Committee and the United Nations urged nations across the world to adhere to the quarantine rules, to increase the number of cases of COVID-19.

en: Stressing the assumed existence of a large number of casualties, the coalition wrote:
yor: Ó gbé èrò rẹ̀ jáde lórí iye tí ó yẹ kí ó jẹ́ òótọ́, àjọ náà kọ báyìí pé:
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: A broken health care system
yor: Ètò ìlera tí ó ti dẹnu kọlẹ̀
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: Recognizing the pandemic is embarrassing for the Assad regime because it forces authorities to admit that the health system is non-existent.
yor: Gbígbà pé àjàkálẹ̀ ààrun yìí wà lóòótọ́ bu ìsejọba Assad kù nítorí pé òhun ni yóò jẹ́ kí àwọn aláṣe wọn ó fi tipá gbà lóòtọ́ pé wọn kò ní èka ètò ìlera.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: According to the LSE study, the maximum number of COVID-19 infections that can be treated in the Syrian health sector is estimated to be only 6,500 in a nation of 17.5 million inhabitants.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) ṣe sọ, àpapọ̀ iye àwọn aláàárẹ̀ COVID-19 tí wọ́n le wò ní ilẹ̀ náà kò ju ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́fà ààbọ̀ lọ (6500) nínú ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ èníyán tí ó tó mílíọ̀nù mẹ́tàdínlógún àbọ̀ tí ó ń gbé ní ilẹ̀ náà.
mt0: According to the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE), the total number of cases of COVID-19 in the country is not more than 6,500 (6,500) in the population of 6.6 million people.

en: If casualties exceed this capacity, the health system, already worn out by the war, is likely to collapse.
yor: Ó ní bí iye àwọn aláàrẹ́ bá ti ju iye yìí lọ, ipá orílè-èdè náà ti pin nìyẹn, omi sì le tẹ̀yìn wọ̀gbín lẹ́nu.
mt0: If the number of heads is more than this, the country is divided, and the water can flow back.

en: Throughout the war, military attacks have caused widespread damage to the health sector.
yor: Ní àsìkò ogun abélé náà, àwọn ológun ti ṣe ìkọlù tí ó lágbára sí ẹ̀ka ètò ìlera wọn.
mt0: In the early days of the war, the soldiers had a massive victory in their defense.

en: Data from the World Health Organization and the Syrian Ministry of Health show that only 58 hospitals are fully operational among the country’s 111 public hospitals.
yor: Àkọsílẹ̀ láti ọdọ̀ Àjọ́ WHO àti Ilé-iṣẹ́ ètò ilera ilẹ̀ Syria sọ ọ́ di mímọ̀ pé méjìdínlọ́gọ́ta nìkan ni ètò iṣẹ́ rẹ̀ pé nínú ilé ìwòsàn ìjọba ọ̀kànléláàádọ́fà tí ó wà ní ilẹ̀ náà.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: The question about the meaning of “Gözümün gördüğü, göğsümün bildiği ile bir değil” (which can be translated as “what my eyes see is not what my heart feels”) has left its mark on social media because of Mabel's popularity among young people (some of his videos have 50 million views) and his sexual orientation.

en: Workers’ Day Celebration: House Speaker tasks Nigerian workers on productivity
yor: ---Àjọ̀dún òṣìṣẹ́: Abẹnugan ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ as̩ojú rọ òṣìṣẹ́ láti tẹramọ́ iṣẹ́ fún àbájáde rere.
mt0: - Employees' year: The chief executive of the employer encourages employees to continue their work for a positive attitude.

en: The Speaker of the Nigerian House of Representatives Mr Femi Gbajabiamila has congratulated the Nigerian workers for marking this year’s International Workers’ Day.
yor: Abẹnugan ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣ̣ojú ti Nàìjíríà, Fẹ́mi Gbàjàbíàmílà, ti kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè yìí kú orííre fún ti àjọ̀dún àyájọ́ àwọn òsìsẹ́ lágbàáyé.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know

en: Mr Gbajabiamila said although the day is being marked quietly across the globe as a result of the lockdown necessitated by the COVID-19 pandemic, there is much to remember about the sacrifices made by Nigerian workers.
yor: Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Gbàjàbíàmílà ní bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ayẹyẹ yìí wáyé láìsí ariwo ní gbogbo àgbáyé nítorí àṣe̩ kónílé–gbélé látàrí ìtànkálẹ̀ aàrun COVID-19, ohun tí a lè rántí pọ̀ nípa àwọn ìrúbọ ti àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà̀ ṣe.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: In a statement marking the Workers’ Day signed by his Special Adviser on Media and Publicity, Lanre Lasisi, the Speaker commended the Nigerian workers for their commitment and dedication to work over the years, which he said has shaped the country tremendously.
yor: Nínú àtẹ̀jáde tó ń sàmì ọjọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ èyí tí Olùdámọ́ràn rẹ̀ Pàtàkì lórí ìròyìn àti ìkéde fo̩wó̩sí, Láńre Làsísì, Abẹnugan gbóṣùbà fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà nítorí ìfarajìn àti ipa ribiribi tí wọ́n kó fún ọ̀pọ̀ ọdún sẹ́yìn, èyí tó mú ìyípadà rere bá Nàìjíríà.
mt0: In the anniversary speech of the employees which his chief advisor on news and press, Lanier Larossi, presented, Abenugan paid tribute to Nigerian employees for their contribution and contribution to the country for many years, which led to a positive change in Nigeria.

en: He, however, called on Nigerian workers to be more productive now and always, saying no matter what was achieved before now must be sustained and improved upon for the country to achieve more.
yor: Síbè̩, ó ro̩ àwọn òṣìṣé Nàìjíríà kí wọ́n túnbọ̀ máa so èso rere nísisìnyí àti gbogbo ìgbà, nítorí àṣeyorí àná nílò ìtẹ̀síwájú kí a ṣiṣẹ́ síi kí ọrílẹ̀-èdè yìí leè ní àṣeyọrí síi.
mt0: However, he advises Nigerian officials to continue to speak positively in this and all situations, because these proposals need a serious effort to be implemented in order to achieve success in the country.

en: “I want to salute the courage of Nigerian workers, who have over the years given their best to their work.
yor: ‘Mo fẹ́ kí àwọn òṣìṣé Nàìjíríà fún ọkàn-akin, àwọn tí wọ́n ti fi gbogbo ipá wọn ṣiṣé.
mt0: I want Nigerian soldiers to be brave, who have closed all their doors.

en: Indeed Nigeria and Nigerians are proud of you.
yor: Nítòótọ́, Nàìjíríà àti àwọn ọmọ Nàìjíríà fi yín yangàn.
mt0: However, Nigeria and its children destroyed you.

en: I urge the Nigerian workers to redouble their efforts at this time of our national development.
yor: Mo rọ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà láti fikún okun wọn ní irú àkókò ìdàgbàsókè orílẹ̀ èdè wa yìí.
mt0: I asked Nigerian officials to withdraw their troops in the wake of our expansion.

en: They must continue to put in their best in the work that they do for the betterment of the country.”
yor: Wọ́n gbọ́dọ̀ tẹ̀síwájú láti fi gbogbo agbára wọn ṣe iṣé tí wọ́n ń ṣe fún àǹfààní orílẹ̀ èdè’

en: --- May Day: Senate President felicitates with Nigerian workers
yor: --- Àyájọ́ àwọn Òṣìṣẹ́: Olóri ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà
mt0: Justice: The Supreme Court ordered Nigerian officials to leave the country. If you cannot translate, just say you don't know.

en: President of the Nigerian Senate, Ahmad Lawan, has felicitated with Nigerian workers as they join their counterparts the world over to mark the Workers’ Day.
yor: Ààrẹ ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà ti Nàìjíríà, Ahmad Lawan, kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè yìí bí wọ́n ṣe sowó̩pò̩ pè̩lú àwọn akẹgbẹ́ wọn lágbàáyé láti s̩e àjọ̀dún o̩jó̩ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know. The president of the National Assembly of Nigeria, Ahmad Lawan, asked the officials of the country to negotiate with their overseas colleagues to establish a new executive council.

en: Senator Lawan also congratulated Nigerian workers for sustaining their heroic struggle for the liberation of the country from poverty and underdevelopment even in the face of the daunting challenges at various workplaces.
yor: Aṣòfin Lawan tún gbóṣùbà fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ fún gudugudu méje, yàyà mẹfà tí wọ́n ń ṣe láti mú orílẹ̀-èdè kúrò nínú òṣì àti àìní idàgbàsókè àti kíkojú àwo̩n ìpèníjà amúnibè̩rù lẹ́nu iṣẹ́ onírúurú.
mt0: The Attorney General also ordered the execution of two acts, four acts of illegal immigration and the execution of the illegal telephone calls in the foreign office.

en: He acknowledged the role of workers as the creator of wealth in society and stressed that it is for this reason that they should be appreciated at all times.
yor: Ó mọ rírì ipa àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ẹni tó ń mú ọrọ̀ wá sí àwùjọ, ó tẹnumọ wípé èyí ni a ṣe gbọ́dọ̀ mo rírì wọn ní gbogbo ìgbà.
mt0: He knows the role of officials as a source of information, he insists that this is what we should expect from them all the time.

en: The best way to appreciate the enormous contributions of the Nigerian workers is to always consider their welfare as of utmost importance.
yor: Ó tẹ̣̀síwájú pé "ọ̀nà tó dára jùlọ̣ láti mọ̣ rírì ipa ribiribi tí àwọ̣̣n òṣìṣẹ́ kó ní láti mójútó ètò ìgbáyé-gbádùn wọ̣̣n.
mt0: He continued to say that "it is best to know the enormous impact of the employees' actions on our policies.

en: "As a legislature, we are ever ready to work in collaboration with the organised labour Unions to rid our statute books of any anti-labour laws," Lawan said.
yor: Lawan sọ wípé, "Gẹ̣́gẹ́ bí ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣ̣òfin, a ti ṣ̣etán láti fọwọ̣́sowọ̣́pọ̀ pẹ̣̀lú ẹ̣̣gbẹ̣́ àwọ̣̣n òṣ̣ìṣ̣ẹ́ láti ṣòfin tó lòdì sí ìwà ìbàjẹ́ sí òṣìṣẹ lẹ́nu iṣẹ́".
mt0: Lawan said, "As a legislature, we have been seeking to cooperate with hundreds of employees to pass a law that would ban violence against employees at work."

en: The Senate President said as part of the effort of the 9th National Assembly to strengthen the economy and improve the standard of living of the people, it is determined to make the country’s financial year predictable through the timely passage of the 2020 budget.
yor: Ààrẹ ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà sọ wípé, gégẹ́ bíi ara akitiyan ilé-ìgbìmọ aṣòfin kẹsàn-án láti fi okun fún ètò ọrọ̀ ajé àti láti mú ìgbé-ayé àwọn ènìyàn dára síi, ti pinu láti mú kí ètò ìsúúná ọdún yìí ṣee dáadáa nípa títètè bu ọwọ́ lu ìwé ètò ìsúná ọdún 2020.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: According to Senator Lawan, the National Assembly has in the same respect made critical amendments to some laws to ensure smooth implementation of the budget.
yor: Nínu ọ̀rọ̀ Aṣòfin Lawan, ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà bakan náà ti ṣe àtúnṣe sí àwọn òfin kò̩ò̩kan láti ri wípé ìmúlò ètò ìsúná náà lo̩o̩ bí ó ti yẹ.
mt0: In the words of the Attorney General, the Parliament also changed some laws to ensure that the financial scheme was operating as necessary.

en: He said the Legislature would continue to move relentlessly in that direction, despite the unforeseen challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.
yor: Ó sọ wípé àwọn Aṣòfin yóò máa lọ ní ìlànà yìí láìwo àwọn ìpèníjà àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn COVID-19.
mt0: He said the laws would continue to be enforced without looking at the cases of COVID-19.

en: The Senate President noted that this year’s celebration of Workers’ Day comes at a time the entire world is facing the health emergency brought about by the Coronavirus pandemic.
yor: Ààrẹ ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ṣe àkíyèsí wípé ayẹyẹ ọjọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ti ọdún yìí wáyé lásìkò tí gbogbo orílẹ̀ èdè àgbáyé ń kojú àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn òjiijì COVID-19.
mt0: The chief of the House of Representatives announced that the annual anniversary of the employees' day was held during the pandemic.

en: "It is the resilience and never-die spirit of the Nigerian people that will boost the efforts of the government to overcome the pandemic," he stated.
yor: Ó wípé "Ọkàn akínkanjú àti ẹ̀mí tí kìí kú tí àwọn ènìyàn Nàìjíríà níí ni yóò ran iṣẹ́ ìjọba lọ́wọ́ láti leè borí àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn náà"
mt0: It is said that "the courage and the courage of Nigerian people will help the government to overcome the crisis of the disease."

en: The Senate President urged the Nigerian workers, as they mark their day, to adhere strictly to all the prescribed public health protocols of social distancing, wearing of face mask, use of hand sanitizer, observance of personal hygiene, and to endeavour to stay at home and stay safe.
yor: ”Ààrẹ ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin wá rọ àwọn òṣìsẹ́ lórílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà bí wọ́n ṣe ń sàmì ọjọ́ wọn, láti máa tẹ́lé ìlànà ètò ìlera láwùjọ, fífi ààyè sáàrín ara wa, kí a máa wọ ìbòjú, kí a máa lo oun èlò ìfọwọ́ apakòkòrò, kí a máa ṣe ìmọ́tótó ara wa àti láti máa dúrọ sílé kí a sì dáàbò bo ara wa.
mt0: 'The president of the National Assembly asked Nigerian officials to follow the rules of hygiene in public, maintain a distance between us, wear glasses, use gloves, exercise appropriately, and to stay at home and shield ourselves.

The Nigeria centre for disease control (NCDC) announced this on their twitter handle @NCDC.gov.
